titleStmt.title: A learned commendation of the politique lawes of Englande vvherin by moste pitthy reasons & euident demonstrations they are plainelye proued farre to excell aswell the ciuile lawes of the Empiere, as also all other lawes of the world, with a large discourse of the difference betwene the. ii. gouernements of kingdomes: whereof the one is onely regall, and the other consisteth of regall and polityque administration conioyned. written in latine aboue an hundred yeares past, by the learned and right honorable maister Fortescue knight ... And newly translated into Englishe by Robert Mulcaster.
De laudibus legum Angliae. English and Latin

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.head: Pio lectori.
div.p:
IStius non minus pij, quÃ¡ eruditi opuÅ¿culi exemplar, nactus: quuÌ antiquitatem venerandam, vna cum eruditione ac pietate coniunxcrim: Non potui optime lector, aut patrie tam ingratus, aut antiquitatis tam in officioÅ¿us cultor eÅ¿Å¿e, vt te illius lectione diutius fraudarem. div.head: To the right woorÅ¿hipfull Ihon VValÅ¿he, EÅ¿quier, one of the Queene her learned IuÅ¿ticers of her highnes Court of Commen plees. Robert MulcaÅ¿ter wiÅ¿heth long lyfe and health.
div.p:
IT happened mee of late, (right woorÅ¿hipfull Å¿yr) to light vpon this little TreatiÅ¿e, whiche I incontinent deÅ¿ired to renne ouer, becauÅ¿e yt Å¿emed to diÅ¿courÅ¿e vpon Å¿ome poyntes of the lawes of our Countrye, wherof I my Å¿elfe then was & nowe am a Student. When I had ouer ronne it, my deÅ¿ire to read it, became nothing counteruailable with the gladnes that I hadde reade it, for my deÅ¿ire to reade it came vpon hope, to fynd Å¿ome profitable leÅ¿Å¿ons for my Å¿tudy, but my gladnes after reading Å¿prang of ye excellency of thargumeÌt, wheron I did not dreame, neither to fynd Å¿o riche a TreaÅ¿ure in Å¿o Å¿imple an habite. And becauÅ¿e I wiÅ¿hed all menne to haue parte of my delight, me thought it good to tranÅ¿late it into EngliÅ¿he forth of Lattine, in whiche toung it was fyrÅ¿te written.
The aucthour of the book was one maiÅ¿ter ForteÅ¿cue knight Seriaunt at the law, and for his Skill and vertues preferred by kinge Henry the .vi. to be Chauncellour of this realme. The entrie of the booke it Å¿elfe Å¿heweth where, and vppon what occaÅ¿ion it was written. It was written in Berry in Fraunce, where Prince Edwarde Å¿onne to Henry the vi. afterward Å¿laine at TewkeÅ¿bury by Edward the .iiii. dyd then remayne with his mother Queene Margaret in the houÅ¿e of Renate her father duke of Angeow and king of Cicile, during the tyme that Edward the fourth reigned in this Realme and Henry the .vi. was fledd into Scotland. The occaÅ¿yon was this: The Chauncellour beiÌg fledde into Fraunce with the yong Prince & perceiuing his delight to be all bent to Chyualrye as a thing of greateÅ¿t neede conÅ¿ydering he ment by force the reÅ¿titucioÌ of his father, and thereby his own, to the kingdome of England, tooke occaÅ¿ion (for that his hope was to Å¿ee the Prince reigne heare) to moue him to a diuiÅ¿ion of his affaires, & as he armed him Å¿elfe againÅ¿t ye enemy, Å¿o to adourne him Å¿elfe againÅ¿te his being kinge with Å¿kill
of lawes, whiche doe preÅ¿erue eche Å¿tate Å¿o in peace that it maye if neede be, warre, and Å¿o garde it in warre, that it may haue peace in eie. Thargument is this, that the Å¿kill of the Countrie lawes is neadefull for the Prince, althoughe not Å¿o deepe as the purpoÅ¿ed profeÅ¿Å¿ours, yet Å¿o full as to their honour may & ought to fall in Princes. And for that the Prince Å¿hould think ye thing to be a Princely knowledge, he taketh occaÅ¿ioÌ by comparing the gouernement of this Realme wt others, and the lawes of this lande with the Ciuill, with whome it is of all men lightly compared and the betterneÅ¿Å¿e of poyntes wherein they bothe trauayle, and prouiÅ¿ions by the one wiÅ¿elyer foreÅ¿eene then by the other, to proue the Å¿ingularitie of this Å¿tate whiche it behoued the Prince to learne Å¿eyng hee was lyke to Å¿ucceade hys father, and to vnderÅ¿taÌd the lawes, whiche maketh the Å¿tate to bee Å¿o Å¿inguler. The particularies I referre to the booke, wherof thus much I doe and no leÅ¿Å¿e coulde well Å¿aye. Why I dyd chooÅ¿e your woorÅ¿hip to be protectour of my laboures, I Å¿hall not neede tedyouÅ¿ly to touche, it Å¿halbe Å¿uffycient to Å¿aye that in choiÅ¿e of manye, I
pycked you alone, not doubting your lyking in allowynge Å¿eeing myne eleccion in dedycatynge and Å¿o commyttinge to thalmightye the good preÅ¿eruacion of your worÅ¿hip I humblye take my leaue, this xii. of October

div.head: The introduction into the matter.

div.p:
DVring ye cruell rage of ye late mortall warrez wtin the royalme of EnglaÌde, wheÌ the moÅ¿t vertuous and godly king Henry the Å¿ixt wt Queene Margaret his wife ye kiÌgz daughter of IheruÅ¿alem and Scicile, & their onely Å¿onne Edwarde prince of Wales were forced to fly the land: & the kiÌg himÅ¿elf afterward in the Å¿ame ciuil tumult falling into the blody hands of his deadly enemies his own Å¿ubiectz was of them coÌmitted to priÅ¿oÌ, wher he a loÌg tyme remained in Å¿traite captiuitie, the queene & ye priÌce her Å¿onne thus baniÅ¿hed out of their countrey, making their abode in ye duchy of Berry, a dominion of ye foreÅ¿aid kiÌg of IeruÅ¿.
The Prince Å¿hortlye after growing to mannes Å¿tate, applied him Å¿elfe wholy to the feates of armes, muche delytinge to ryde vpon wilde and vnbroken horÅ¿es, not Å¿paring wt Å¿purres to break their fiercenes. He practyÅ¿ed alÅ¿o Å¿ometymes wt the pyke, Å¿ometimes wt ye Å¿worde, & other warlyke weapons after the maner & guyÅ¿e of warriors accordinge to the vÅ¿e of martial diÅ¿cipline, to aÅ¿Å¿aile & Å¿trike his companioÌs, I mean ye yong meÌ ye attended vpoÌ hys êson. Which thing wheÌ a certein auÌcieÌt knight, being chauÌcellour to ye forÅ¿aide kiÌg of EnglaÌd Å¿aw, who alÅ¿o in ye miÅ¿erable tyme did there remain in exile, hee Å¿pake thus to ye priÌce.

SEuieÌte duduÌ in regno Anglie nephandiÅ¿Å¿ima rabie illa, qua piiÅ¿Å¿imus ibidem rex H. Å¿extus, cum Margareta Regina conÅ¿orte Å¿ua, filia regis IheruÅ¿alem et Scicilie, ac eorum vnigenito Edwardo principe Wallie inde propulÅ¿i Å¿uÌt, Å¿ub qua et demum rex ipÅ¿e. H. a Å¿ubditis Å¿uis depreheÌÅ¿us, carceris diutinuÌ paÅ¿Å¿us eÅ¿t horrorem, duÌ regina ipÅ¿a cum Å¿obole, patria Å¿ic extorrens, in ducatu BerrenÌ predicti Regis IheruÅ¿alem dnÌio morabaÌtur.
Princeps ille mox vt factus eÅ¿t adultus, militari totum Å¿e contulit diÅ¿ciplinae, et Å¿epe ferocibus et quaÅ¿i indomitis inÅ¿edens caballis, eos calcaribusâª vrgens, quando
que lancea, quando
que mucrone, aliis quo

que , iuxta martis gimnaÅ¿ij. rudimenta, delectabatur. Quod cernens miles quidam grandaeuus, predicti regis Angliae Cancellarius, qui etiam ibidem Å¿ub hac clade exulabat: PrincipeÌ Å¿ic affatur.

div.head: Â¶FirÅ¿t he moueth the Prince to the knowledge of the lawe. Chap. 1,

div.p:
YOur Å¿inguler towardenes moÅ¿t gracious priÌce, maketh me right gladde, when I beholde how erneÅ¿tlye you dooe embrace martiall feates. For it is conuenieÌt for youre grace to be thus delyted, not onlye for that you are a Å¿ouldyour, but muche rather for that you Å¿halbe a kiÌg. For yt is the offyce and duytie of a Kyng to fight the batailes of his people, and alÅ¿o rightlye to iudge them, as in the viii. chapiter of the firÅ¿te booke of Kinges you are plainelye taught. Wherfore I would wiÅ¿h your grace to be wt as erneÅ¿t zeal geueÌ to ye Å¿tudie of ye lawz as you ar to ye knowledge of arms,
becauÅ¿e that like as warres by force of chiualrye are ended, euen Å¿o iudgementes by the lawes are determined. which thing IuÅ¿tinian the Emperour well and wiÅ¿ely and aduiÅ¿edly pondering, in the beginninge of the preface of his book Å¿aith thus. It behoueth the emperiall maieÅ¿ty not onli to be garded with armez, but alÅ¿o to be armed with lawes, to the end yt he mai be able rightly to execute ye gouernemÌt of bothe times, aÅ¿well of warre as of peace. Howbe it for youre more earneÅ¿t endeuoir to the Å¿tudy of the law, the exhortatioÌ of the chiefeÅ¿t lawmaker MoyÅ¿es, Å¿ometyme capytaine of the Synagoge ought to be of much more force with you, then the
woordes of IuÅ¿tinian, wheras in the xvii. chapiter of the book of Deuteronomie hee doothe by the auctority of god Å¿traitlye charge the kinges of IÅ¿raell to be readers of ye lawe al the daies of theire lyfe Å¿ayeng thus. When the kyng Å¿hall Å¿itte vppon the princelye Å¿eate of hys kingdome, hee Å¿hall write him out thys lawe in a booke, takynge the copye thereof of the prieÅ¿tes the Leuites: and he Å¿hal haue it with him, and hee Å¿hall read it al the dayes of hys life, that he may learne to feare the lorde his god, & to keepe his commaundementes and ordinaunces written in this lawe.

And Helynandus expouÌ dyng the Å¿ame Å¿aith thus.
A Prince therefore muÅ¿t not be ignorant of ye law, neither is it tollerable yt hee vnder the pretence of warrefare Å¿houlde be vnÅ¿kilfull in the lawe. And a littel after he is coÌmauÌ ded, Å¿ayeth hee, to receyue the coppye of the lawe of the prieÅ¿tes the Leuites, that is to Å¿aye, of catholik and learned men. Thus muche he: For the booke of Deuteronomie is the booke of the lawes, wherwith the Kynges of IÅ¿raell were bounde to rule and gouerne theyre Subiectes. Thys booke doth MoyÅ¿es commaunde kinges too reade, that they may learne to feare God, and keepe his commaundementes, which are writen in the lawe.
Beholde the effecte of the lawe is to feare God.

Whereunto man cannot attayne, oneleÅ¿Å¿e he firÅ¿te knowe the will of God, whiche is written in the lawe. For the principall poynte of all Å¿eruyce is to knowe the wyll and pleaÅ¿ure of the lord or maiÅ¿ter to whome Å¿eruyce ys due. Howbeit the lawmaker MoyÅ¿es firÅ¿t iÌ this charge mencioneth the effecte of the lawe, that is the feare of God: and nexte he allureth vs to the keepinge of the cauÅ¿e thereof, that is to Å¿aye, of Goddes commaundementes. For in the mynde and intent of the exhorter the effect goethe before the cauÅ¿e.

But what feare is thys whyche the lawes do propouÌ to ye obÅ¿eruerz therof?
Surely it is not that fear, wherof it is written, that perfect charitie or loue expellethe feare. Yet thys Å¿ame feare, thoughe it bee bond & Å¿eruile, oftentimes prouoketh kinges to the reading of the lawes: but it procedeth not out of the law. But that feare wherof MoyÅ¿es here Å¿peaketh, whiche alÅ¿o procedeth out of the lawes is the Å¿elfe Å¿ame feare, that the prophet Å¿peaketh of Å¿aynge. The feare of the lorde is holy, & endureth for euer & euer. This is Å¿uch a louiÌg feare as natural children beare to their deare pareÌtz commenly termed the reuerence of ye child toward his parents, Whereunto there is no puniÅ¿hement due, as a thinge wrought by loue. For this feare proceedeth out of the lawes,
which teach to do the wil of god, Å¿o that it deÅ¿erueth no puniÅ¿hement. But the glorye of the Lorde is vppon them that feare hym, and he doth glorify them. Yea thys feare is eeuen that Å¿ame feare, whereof Iob after that he had dyuerÅ¿lye Å¿earched for wiÅ¿edome, Å¿ayeth thus. Beeholde the feare of the lord is perfecte wiÅ¿edome, and to forÅ¿ake euill is vnderÅ¿tandinge. That the forÅ¿akinge of euill is the vnderÅ¿tandinge of the feare of god, this do the lawes teache, whereby it foloweth that the Å¿ame fear procedeth out of them.

Gaudeo vero Å¿e reniÅ¿Å¿ime Princeps Å¿uper nobiliÅ¿Å¿ima indole tua: videns quanta auiditate militares tu amplecteris actus, conuenit naÌ
que tibi taliter delectari, nedum quia miles es, Å¿ed amplius quia rex futurus es. Regis neÌpe officiuÌ pugnare eÅ¿t bella populi Å¿ui, et eos rectiÅ¿Å¿ime iudicare, vt primo regum cap. viii. clariÅ¿Å¿ime tu doceris. Quare vt armorum, vtinam et legum Å¿tudiis, Å¿imili zelo te dedituÌ coÌteÌplarer
Cum vt armis bella, ita legibus iudicia peragantur que IuÅ¿tinianus AuguÅ¿tus equiÅ¿Å¿ima librans mente in initio prohemii libri Å¿ui inÅ¿titutionum ait. ImperatoriaÌ mageÅ¿tatem non Å¿olum armis decoratam, Å¿ed et legibus oportet eÅ¿Å¿e armatam, vt vtrumque tempus bellorum et pacis recte poÅ¿Å¿it gubernari. TuÌ vt ad legum Å¿tudia Å¿eruide tu aÌheles, Maximus legis lator ille MoyÅ¿es olim Synagoge dux multo forcius CeÅ¿are te iÌuitat
dum regibus IÅ¿rael diuina autoritate ipÅ¿e precipiat, eorum leges legere omnibus diebus vite Å¿ue, Å¿ic dicens: PoÅ¿tquam Å¿ederit rex in Å¿olio regni Å¿ui deÅ¿cribet Å¿ibi Deuteronomij Leges in volumine, accipiens exeÌplar a Å¿acerdotibus Leuitice tribus, & habebit Å¿ecuÌ leget
que illud omnibus diebus vite Å¿ue, vt diÅ¿cat timere dnÌm deuÌ Å¿uuÌ, & cuÅ¿todire verba & ceremonias eius que in lege Å¿cripta Å¿uÌt. Deutero. ca. xvij. quod exponens HelynaÌdus dicit.
Princeps ergo noÌ debet iuris ignarus eÅ¿Å¿e, nec pretextu militiae legeÌ permittitur ignorare. Et poÅ¿t pauca, a Å¿acerdotibus Leuitice tribus, aÅ¿Å¿umere iubetur exemplar legis, id eÅ¿t a viris catholicis et litteratis. Hec ille: Liber quippe Deute. eÅ¿t liber legum, quibus Reges IÅ¿raell Å¿ubditum Å¿ibi populum regere tenebantur. Hunc librum legere, iubet MoyÅ¿es Reges, vt diÅ¿cant timere deuÌ & cuÅ¿todire mandata eius quae in lege Å¿cripta Å¿unt.

Ecce timere deuÌ effectus eÅ¿t legis, quem non conÅ¿equi valet homo, niÅ¿i prius Å¿ciat voluntatem dei, quae in lege Å¿cripta eÅ¿t. Nam principium omnis famulatus, eÅ¿t Å¿cire voluntatem dnÌi cui Å¿eruitur. Legis tnÌ lator MoyÅ¿es, primÃ´ in hoc edicto effectum legis videlicet timorem Dei, coÌmemorat. Deinde ad cuÅ¿todiaÌ cauÅ¿ae eius videlicet mandatorum dei ipÅ¿e inuitat.

NaÌ effectus prior eÅ¿t quaÌ cauÅ¿a, in animo exhortaÌtis. Sed quis eÅ¿t timor iÅ¿te, quem promittunt leges obÅ¿eruatoribus Å¿uis?
vere non eÌ timor ille de quo Å¿cribitur: Quod perfecta caritas foras mittit timorem. Timor tamen ille licet Å¿eruilis, Å¿epe ad legendum leges, reges concitat, Å¿ed non eÅ¿t ipÅ¿e proles legis. Timor vero de quo hic loquitur MoiÅ¿es, quem et pariunt leges, eÅ¿t ille de quo dicit propheta: Timor domini Å¿anctus permanet in Å¿eculum Å¿eculi. Hic filialis eÅ¿t et non nouit penam, vt ille qui per charitatem expellitur. Nam iÅ¿te a legibus proficiÅ¿citur,
que doceÌt facere voluÌtateÌ dei, quo ipÅ¿e penaÌ noÌ meretur. Sed gloria dnÌi eÅ¿t Å¿uper metuentes euÌ, quos et ipÅ¿e glorificat. Timor auteÌ iÅ¿te, timor ille eÅ¿t, de quo Iob poÅ¿tquaÌ multifarie Å¿apieÌ tiaÌ inueÅ¿tigat Å¿ic ait. Ecce timor domini ipÅ¿a eÅ¿t Å¿apientia, & recedere a malo, intelligentia. Iob ca. xxviij. Recedere a malo quÃ´d intelligeÌtia timoris dei eÅ¿t, leges docent quo & timoreÌ hunc ipÅ¿e parturiunt.

div.head: Â¶The Princes replie to the Chauncellours motion, Chap. 2.

div.p:
THe Prince hearynge this, and Å¿tedfaÅ¿tly be holding ye old man, Å¿pake thus to him. I know good Chauncelloure that the booke of Deutronomie whereof you Å¿peake is a booke of holye Å¿cripture. The lawes alÅ¿o and ordinances therein contained are holy, of the lords makinge, and publiÅ¿hed by MoyÅ¿es: Wherefore the readinge of them is a pleÅ¿ant act of holye contemplacion. But that law, to the knowledge whereof you counÅ¿ell me, is humayne, made by menne, and intreating of worldlye matters: Wherefore though MoyÅ¿es bynde the Kinges of IÅ¿raell to the readynge of goddes law, yet that thereby hee forcethe all other Kynges
to do the like in their own lawes, that Å¿tandethe by no good reaÅ¿on, Å¿eeynge that of both the readinges the cauÅ¿e is not like.

HEc vt audiuit priÌceps, erecto in Å¿enem vultu Å¿ic locutus eÅ¿t. Scio Cancellarie quod liber Deut. quem tu commemoras, Å¿acrae Å¿cripturae volumeÌ eÅ¿t: leges quo
que & cerimoniae in eo coÌ Å¿criptae, etiam Å¿acrae Å¿uÌt a dnÌo editae: & per MoiÅ¿en promulgatae: quare eas legere Å¿aÌctae coÌteÌplacionis dulcedo eÅ¿t. Sed lex ad cuius Å¿cienciaÌ me inuitas, humana eÅ¿t ab hoiÌbus aedita, tractans & terrena: quo licet MoyÅ¿es ad Deut. lecturam reges IÅ¿rael aÅ¿trinxerit, euÌ per hoc reges alios

que lecturâ, noÌ Å¿it eadem cauÅ¿a.

div.head: Â¶Here the Chauncelour Fortifieth his aÅ¿Å¿ertion Cap. 3.

div.p:
I perceaue (ê the ChauÌ cellour) by youre aunÅ¿were moÅ¿t worthy prince howe earneÅ¿tly you haue conÅ¿idered & weighed the qualitie of my exhortacioÌ. So that heareby you doe much encourage me both more plainly, more largely & alÅ¿o more deepelye to diÅ¿courÅ¿e ye Å¿ame. Wherefore you Å¿hal vnderÅ¿tande that not only gods lawes but alÅ¿o mans are holye, forÅ¿omuche as the lawe is diffined by theÅ¿e woordes. The lawe is a holy Å¿anction
or decree, coÌmauÌding things that be honeÅ¿t, and forbiddinge ye contraries. Now ye thing muÅ¿t needs be holy which by diffinicioÌ is determined to be holye. Right alÅ¿o by deÅ¿cription is called the arte of yt whiche is good & Å¿treight Å¿o yt in this ceÅ¿pect a man may wel cal vs Sacerdotes, that is to Å¿aye, geeuers or teachers of holy things (for Å¿o by interpretacion doothe Sacerdos Å¿ignifie). ForÅ¿omuche then as the lawes are holye, it foloweth that the miniÅ¿ters and Å¿etters furth of theÌ may right wel be called Sacerdotes, that iz geuers & teachers of holy things. Further more all lawes publiÅ¿hed by men haue alÅ¿o theire auctoritie frome godde. For as the ApoÅ¿tell Å¿ayethe:
Al power is from the lord god. Wherefore the lawes that are made by maÌ which thereunto hath receaued power from the lorde, are alÅ¿o ordeined of god, as alÅ¿o appeareth by this Å¿aiyng of the auctour of al cauÅ¿es: WhatÅ¿oeuer the Å¿econde cauÅ¿e doth, the Å¿aÌe dothe ye firÅ¿t cauÅ¿e by a higher and more excellent meane. Wherefore IoÅ¿aphat the king of Iuda Å¿aiethe to his iudges: The iudgements whiche ye execute are the iudgements of god in ye ninetinth chapter of the Å¿econde booke of Chronicles. Wherby you are taughte that to learne laws though they be maÌs lawes, is toe learne holy lawes and the ordynaÌ ces of goode: Å¿o that the
Å¿tudie of them is not with out a pleaÅ¿ant Å¿weetenes of holy coÌÅ¿olacioÌ. And yet Å¿uch Å¿weete pleaÅ¿ure was not the cauÅ¿e as you Å¿uppoÅ¿e, werefore MoyÅ¿es coÌ maunded the kings of IÅ¿rael to reade the lawes of Deuteronomie. For thys cauÅ¿e moueth not kynges no more to the reading of ye boke of Deuteronomie thenne of anye of the other bookes of MoyÅ¿es in which aÅ¿wel as iÌ ye booke of Deuteronomie is plentiful Å¿tore of godly leÅ¿Å¿ons & holy inÅ¿truccioÌs. Wherin to be deuoutly occupied is a holy thing. Wherfore that there was non other cauÅ¿e of this commaundement, theÌ for that ye lawes whereby the king of IÅ¿rael is bound to rule his people, are more preciÅ¿ely coÌ teined
in ye booke of Deutronomie, theÌ in ye other bokes of ye old teÅ¿tameÌt, ye circuÌÅ¿tances of the Å¿ame coÌ mauÌdement do manifeÅ¿tly infourme vs. For whiche cauÅ¿e you ought moÅ¿te worthy prince no leÅ¿Å¿e theÌ the kings of IÅ¿raell to bee mooued and prouoked to be a diligent trauailer in the Å¿tudie of thoÅ¿e lawes, wherebye hereafter yowe Å¿hal rule your people. For that which was Å¿poken to the kinge of IÅ¿raell muÅ¿te be vnderÅ¿tande to be figuratiuely Å¿poken to euerye kinge hauinge dominion ouer godly people. And haue I not then wel and holÅ¿omelye propounded vnto you the commaundemeÌt geeuen to the kynges of IÅ¿raell concernynge the learnynge of theire lawe?
ForaÅ¿muche as not onely his example, but alÅ¿o hys like autoritie hath taught yowe and bounde you to the like dooinge in the lawes of the kyngedome, whiche god willinge you Å¿hall inherit.

AT CaÌcellariê°. Scio (inquit) ê hec qÌ iaÌ dicis, princeps clariÅ¿Å¿imÌ, quaÌ ta aduÌteÌtia exhortatioÌis mee, tu poÌ deras qualitatâ quo me noÌ infime coÌciÌ tas Å¿uê inceptis, neduÌ clariê°, Å¿ed et êfuÌdiê° quodamodo tecuÌdiÅ¿ceptare. Scire igitur te volo, quod noÌ Å¿oluÌ Deutro. leges, Å¿ed et oÌ nes leges humaÌe Å¿acre Å¿uÌt, quÃ´ lex Å¿ub his verbis diffinitur. Lex eÅ¿t Å¿aÌctio
Å¿ancta iubeÌs honeÅ¿ta, et prohibeÌs contraria Å¿anctum etenim eÅ¿Å¿e oportet, qdâ eÅ¿Å¿e Å¿anctuÌ diffinitum eÅ¿t. Ius etiam diÅ¿cribi perhibetur, quod illud eÅ¿t ars boni et equi cuius merito quis nos Å¿acerdotes appellat. Sacerdâ eniÌ quaÅ¿i Å¿acra daÌs, vel Å¿acra doceÌs per ethimologiaÌ dicitur, quia vt dicunt iura, leges Å¿acrae Å¿uÌt quÃ´ eas miniÅ¿trantes et docentes Å¿acerdotes appellantur. A deo etiam Å¿unt omnes leges editae, quae ab homine êmulgaÌtur. NaÌ cuÌ dicat ApoÅ¿tolê°,
quod omnis poteÅ¿tas a domino deo eÅ¿t, leges ab homine conditae, qui ad hoc a domino recipit poteÅ¿tatem, etiam a deo conÅ¿tituuntur, dicente auctore cauÅ¿aruÌ: quic quid facit cauÅ¿a Å¿ecunda, facit et cauÅ¿a prima, altiori et nobiliori modo. Quare IoÅ¿aphat rex Iuda, ait Iudicibus Å¿uis: iudicia qÌ vos profertis, iudicia dei Å¿unt, Å¿ecundo Paralipo. xix. cap. Ex quibus erudiris quod leges licet humanas ad diÅ¿cere, eÌ addiÅ¿cere leges Å¿acras et editioÌes dei, quo earuÌ
Å¿tudiuÌ noÌ vacat a dulcedine coÌÅ¿olationis Å¿cÌae. Nec tameÌ vt tu coniicis, dulcedo hmÌodi cauÅ¿a fuit cur MoyÅ¿es reges IÅ¿rael Deutero. legere pÌceêat. Nam cauÅ¿a hec, noÌ plus reges quaÌ plebeos, ad eius lecturaÌ êuocat, nec plê° Deuter. libruÌ quaÌ alios PeÌtateucoÌ libros legere, pulÅ¿at cauÅ¿a iÅ¿ta, cuÌ non minus libri illi, quaÌ Deutero. Å¿acris abuÌdent cariÅ¿matibus, in quibus meditari êÅ¿anctuÌ eÅ¿t. quare noÌ aliaÌ fuiÅ¿Å¿e cauÅ¿aÌ maÌdati huius, quaÌ quia iÌ DeutronomÌ plus quaÌ iÌ aliis libris veteris teÅ¿tameÌti legê­ iÌÅ¿eruntur,
quibus rex IÅ¿rael pplâm populum regere obnoxius eÅ¿t, eiuÅ¿deÌ mandati circuÌÅ¿tantiae manifeÅ¿te nos informant. Quo et te priÌceps eadeÌ cauÅ¿a, noÌ minus quaÌ reges IÅ¿rael exhortatur vt legum, quibus populum in futurum reges, tu Å¿is Å¿olers indagator. NaÌ quod Regi IÅ¿rael dictuÌ eÅ¿t, omni Regi populi videntis deum, ticipÃ¨ dictum fuiÅ¿Å¿e intelligendum eÅ¿t, an tunc non conuenienter vtiliterque propoÅ¿ui tibi mandatum Regibus IÅ¿rael latuÌ de eoruÌ lege addiÅ¿cenda?
Dum nedum eius exempluÌ, Å¿ed et eius auctoritas figuralis te erudiuit et obligauit, ad conÅ¿imiliter faciendum de legibus regni, quod annueÌte domino, hereditaturus es.

div.head: Â¶Here the Chauncelour proueth that a prince by the lawes may be made happy and bleÅ¿Å¿ed. Cap. 4.

div.p:
NOt onely to the iÌtent you Å¿hould feare god & Å¿o beecome wiÅ¿e, do ye lawes wt ye prophet call you Å¿aiyng: Come childreÌ heare me I will teache you ye feare of the lorde: but alÅ¿o that you may aÅ¿pire vnto felicitie and bleÅ¿Å¿ednes (as farre fourthe as in this life theye maye bee atteyned) do the lawes wyll you moÅ¿te gracious prince to bee Å¿tudious of them
For all the philoÅ¿ophers which haue Å¿o diuerÅ¿ly reÅ¿oned of felicitie, haue all agreed together in this oÌe point, that felicitie or bleÅ¿Å¿ednes is ye ende of al maÌs deÅ¿ire: and therefore theye cal it chief goodnes. Howbeit ye peripatetiks placed it in vertue, the Stoikes iÌ honeÅ¿tie, & the Epicures in pleaÅ¿ure. But Å¿eeing ye Stoikes defined honeÅ¿tie to be that whiche is wel & laudably done withe vertue, and the Epicures helde nothing to be pleaÅ¿ant witheoute vertue, therefore all thoÅ¿e Å¿ectes, as Å¿aiethe Leonarde Arretine in his Introduction to morall PhiloÅ¿ophie agreed in this, that it is onely vertue that cauÅ¿ethe felicitie.
Wherefore AriÅ¿totle alÅ¿o in ye Å¿eueÌth booke of his politiques defining felicitie, Å¿aieth that it is the perfect vÅ¿e of vertues. Thê° much being now preÅ¿uppoÅ¿ed I wold haue you to coÌÅ¿ider theÅ¿e things alÅ¿o ye folow MaÌs lawes are nothing els but certein rules, whereby IuÅ¿tice is perfectlye taught. But that IuÅ¿tyce which the lawes do Å¿hew is not the Å¿ame that is called Commutatiue or DiÅ¿tributiue, or any other particular vertue, but it is a perfecte vertue expreÅ¿Å¿ed by the name of IuÅ¿tice legall. Whyche the foreÅ¿aid Leonerd dothe therefore affyrme to bee perfecte, beecauÅ¿e it excludeth all vice, and teachethe all vertue. For whiche cauÅ¿e alÅ¿o it is woorthelye called
by the name of al vertue. Whereof Homere Å¿aiethe, and likewiÅ¿e AriÅ¿totle in the fifthe booke of Morall philoÅ¿ophie, that it is ye chiefeÅ¿t of al vertues, and that neither Lucyfer nor HeÅ¿perê° are Å¿o bright & beaming as it is. Moreouer this IuÅ¿tice is ye thiÌg, whereuppon al princelye care depeÌdeth and reÅ¿teth: witheoute the whiche the kinge can neither rightly iudge, nor yet duely fight. But thys beeing once obteyned and perfectly kept, then all the hole deuty required in a kyng is iuÅ¿tly perfourmed. Nowe then Å¿eeynge that the perfecte vÅ¿e of vertues is felicytie, and that IuÅ¿tice vÅ¿ed amongeÅ¿t menne whyche can not bee obteyned vnto nor learned but by the
lawe, is not onelye the effecte of vertues, but is all vertue it Å¿elfe, hereof it folowethe, that the practiÅ¿er of IuÅ¿tice is by the lawe happie, and Å¿o thereby hee is made bleÅ¿Å¿ed, forÅ¿omuche as bleÅ¿Å¿ednes or happynes and felicitie are bothe one in this Å¿hort and tranÅ¿itorie lyfe, of the whiche lyfe throughe IuÅ¿tice hee enioyeth the chiefe & principall goodnes. And yet the lawe is not hable to perfourme theÅ¿e thinges withoute the aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tence of grace, witheoute the whiche alÅ¿o you can not learn nor couet eyther lawe or vertue. For as Å¿aieth PariÅ¿Å¿. in his booke intituled Cur deus homo the inward vertue of man wherin his deÅ¿ieringe is placed is Å¿o
throughe originall Å¿inne defaced and corrupte, that it eÅ¿teemeth vicious workes for pleaÅ¿aunt, & vertuous woorkes for vnpleaÅ¿aunt. Wherefore in that Å¿ome men applye and endeuour themÅ¿elues to the loue and folowing of vertues, it proceedethe of the bountiful goodnes of god and not of the power of man. Is ther not then Å¿pecial cauÅ¿e why the lawes, whiche beinge preuented and accompanied wythe grace do performe all the premiÅ¿Å¿es, Å¿hould with all diligent trauaile be learned? Seinge that whoÅ¿o hathe perfectlye atteyned thereunto, the Å¿ame Å¿hall enioye felicitie, the ende & performaÌce, as ye PhiloÅ¿ophers Å¿ay, of maÌs deÅ¿ire by meaÌs wherof hee Å¿hall in this life be bleÅ¿Å¿ed, in ye
he nowe poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿eth ye chief goodnes therof. Doubtles if theÅ¿e thinges moue you not, whiche Å¿hal haue the rule and gouernement of a kingdom, yet the woordes of the prophet Å¿hal moue you, yea & force you to the Å¿tudie of the law, whiche words be theÅ¿e: Be ye learned you yt are iudges of the earth. Here ye êphet exhorteth not to ye learniÌg of a baÅ¿e arte or a handycraft, for he Å¿aieth not: Be ye learned you yt are the iÌ habiters of the earth, neyther doth he counÅ¿el to the learninge of knoweledge Å¿peculatiue, thoughe it bee not vnneceÅ¿Å¿arie for the inhabiters vpon the earthe. For he Å¿ayethe not generally: Bee ye learned you that dwell vppon the earthe, but by theÅ¿e wordes,
doth the prophet call kinges onely to the learninge of the law, wherby iudgements are executed, forÅ¿omuch as he Å¿pecially Å¿aith Bee ye learned you yt are iudges of ye earthe. And it folowethe: leaÅ¿t the lord waxe angrye, and Å¿o you periÅ¿he from the waye of righteouÅ¿enes. Neyther doth holy Å¿cripture (o kinges Å¿onne) commauÌd you onelye to be Å¿kilfullye inÅ¿truct in the lawes, wherby you Å¿hal purchaÅ¿e and obtein ye poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ioÌ of iuÅ¿tice but alÅ¿o iÌ an other place it biddeth you vnfainedly to loue IuÅ¿tice, wher it Å¿ayethe. O Å¿et your loue & affection vppon IuÅ¿tice you that are iudges of the earthe, in the firÅ¿te chapter of the booke of wyÅ¿edome.

NOn Å¿oluÌ vt de uÌ timeas, quo et Å¿apieÌs eris, princeps colendiÅ¿Å¿ime, vocaÌt te leges, cuÌ êpheta diceÌte. Venite filii, audite me timoreÌ dnÌidocebo vos: Sed etiaÌ vt felicitateÌ, beatitudineÌ
que ,) ê vt in hac vita naÌciÅ¿ci poterâ adipiÅ¿caris, ipÅ¿ae leges ad earum diÅ¿ciplinatuÌ te inuitaÌt.
PhiloÅ¿ophi naÌ
que oÌ nes qui de felicita te taÌ variÃ¨ diÅ¿putabaÌt, in hoc vno coÌ ueneruÌt: vz qd; felicitas Å¿iue beatitudo finis eÌ oÌnis huÌ mani appetitê°: quare et ipÌaÌ Å¿uÌmuÌ bonÌ appellaÌt: Peripatetici tnÌ coÌÅ¿tituebaÌt eaÌ in virtute: Stoici in honeÅ¿to: Et Epicurei in voluptate. Sed quia Stoici honeÅ¿tuÌ diffiniebant eÅ¿Å¿e qdâ bene Å¿it et laudabilit
er ex virtute, et Epicurâ aÅ¿Å¿erebaÌt nihil eÅ¿Å¿e voluptuoÅ¿uÌ Å¿ine virtutâ: Omnes Å¿ectae illae, vt dicit Leonardê° Arretinê° YÅ¿agogico moralis diÅ¿ciplinae, in hoc concordarunt, qdâ Å¿ola virtus eÅ¿t, que felicitateÌ operatur
Quo et PhiloÅ¿ophê° in vii. politâ (felicitateÌ difinieÌs) dicit, quod ipÅ¿a eÅ¿t êfectê° vÅ¿ê° virtutuÌ. His iaÌ pÌÅ¿uppoÅ¿itis, coÌÅ¿iderare te volo etiaÌ ea qÌ Å¿equeÌtur. Leges humaÌe noÌ aliud Å¿uÌt quaÌ regulâ quibê° êfectÃ¨ iuÅ¿ticÌ edocetur. IuÅ¿ticia vero quaÌ leges reuelaÌt, noÌ eÅ¿t illa qÌ coÌmutatiua vel diÅ¿tributatiua vocat. feu alia qÌuis êticularis virtus, Å¿ed eÅ¿t virtê° êfecta, qÌ iuÅ¿ticÌ legalâ noÌine de Å¿ignatur. QuaÌ Leonardê° pÌdcÌê° ideo dicit eÅ¿Å¿e êfectaÌ, qÌaoÌne viciuÌ ipÅ¿a eliminat, et oeÌm virtuteÌ pÌa docet quo et oiÌs virtê° ipÌa merito nuncupatur.
De qua Homerus dicit, Å¿iÌlâer similiter et PhiloÅ¿ophê° v. ethicoruÌ, Quod ipÅ¿a eÅ¿t pre clariÅ¿Å¿ima virtutuÌ et nec Lucifer nec HeÅ¿perê°, vt illa eÅ¿t admirabilis. IuÅ¿ticia vero hec, Å¿ubiectuÌ eÅ¿t omnis regalis curae, quÃ´ Å¿ine illa Rex iuÅ¿te non iudicat, nec recte pugnare poteÅ¿t. Illa vero adepta, êfectÃª
que Å¿eruata equiÅ¿Å¿ime peragitur oÌne officium Regis. Vnde cum êfectus vÅ¿us virtutum Å¿it felicitas, et IuÅ¿ticia humana, que non niÅ¿i per legeÌ êfecte naÌciÅ¿citur, aut docetur,
nedum Å¿it virtutum effectê°, Å¿ed et omnis virtus. Sequitur quod iuÅ¿titia fruens felix per legem eÅ¿t quÃ³ et per eam ipÌe fit beatus, cum idem Å¿it beatitudo & felicitas in hac fugaci vita cuius et ê iuÅ¿ticiam ipÅ¿e Å¿ummum habet bonuÌ tamen noÌ niÅ¿i per gratiaÌ lex poterit iÅ¿ta operari, ne
que legem aut virtutem Å¿ine gratia tu addiÅ¿cere poteris, vel appetere. Cum vt dicit PariÅ¿i in libro Å¿uo de Cur deus hoÌo virtus hominÌ appetitiua iÌterior,
per peccatum originale ita viciata eÌ vt Å¿ibi vicioruÌ Å¿ua uia et virtutuÌ aÅ¿pera opera Å¿apiant. Quare qdâ aliqui ad amorem Å¿ectacionem
que virtutâ Å¿e conferunt, diuiniÌ bonitatis benefici um eÅ¿t, et noÌ humanae virtutis. Num tunc leges, qÌ pÌueniente & comitante gratia, omnia pÌ miÅ¿Å¿a operaÌtur, toto conamine addiÅ¿cendae Å¿unt? dum felicitatem quae Å¿ecundum PhiloÅ¿ophos, eÅ¿t hic finis et complementum humani deÅ¿iderij, earum apprehenÅ¿or obtinebit, quÃ³ et beatus ille erit in hac vita,
eius poÅ¿Å¿ideÌs Å¿ummum bonum. Vere etÅ¿i non hec te moueant, qui regnum recturus es, mouebuÌt te etarctabunt ad diÅ¿ciplinatum legis prophetaeverba diceÌtê­ Erudimini qui iudicatis terram, noÌ enim ad eruditionem artis factiuae, aut mechanicae, hic mouet propheta: Cum non dicat, Erudimini qui colitis terram, nec ad eruditionem Å¿cientiae tantuÌ theoricae, quamuis oportuna fuerit incolis terrae, quia generaliter non dicit erudimini qui inhabitatis terram
Å¿ed Å¿olum ad diÅ¿ciplinam legis, qua Iudicia redduntur reges inuitat propheta in his verbis. Cum Å¿pecialiter ipÅ¿e dicat: Erudimini qui iudicatis terram. Et Å¿equitur: Ne quando iraÅ¿catur dominus, & pereatis de via iuÅ¿ta. Nec Å¿olum legibus, quibus iuÅ¿titiam conÅ¿equeris, fili regis imbui te iubet Å¿acra Å¿criptura, Å¿ed et ipÅ¿am iuÅ¿ticiam diligere, tibi alibi precipit, cum dicat. Diligite iuÅ¿ticiam qui iudicatis terram. SapienÌ Capitulo primo.

div.head: Â¶Ignorance of the lawe cauÅ¿ith the contempt there of. Cap. 5.

div.p: But howe can you loue IuÅ¿tice, onles you firÅ¿t haue a Å¿ufficient knoweledge in the lawes, whereby the knoweledge of it is wonne and had: For the PhiloÅ¿opher Å¿aiethe that nothinge can bee loued except it bee knowen. And therefore Quintiliane the Oratoure Å¿ayethe, that happie Å¿houlde artes bee, if artificers onelye weare iudges of them. As for that whiche is vnknowen it is wonte not onely not to be loued, but alÅ¿o to bee deÅ¿piÅ¿ed. And therefore a certaine poet thus Å¿aieth.

q.p: The plowmaÌ doth deÅ¿Å¿piÅ¿e and Å¿kof,
the thing he is not Å¿kilfull of.

div.p:
And this is the Å¿aiynge not of plowemen alone but allÅ¿o of learned, and right Å¿kilfull men. For yf vnto a naturall PhiloÅ¿opher yt neuer Å¿tudied ye mathematicall Å¿ciences a Å¿upernaturall PhiloÅ¿opher Å¿houlde Å¿aye that thys Å¿cience conÅ¿iderethe thynges Å¿euered from all mater and mouinge, accordynge to theire Å¿ubÅ¿tantiall beeynge and reaÅ¿on: or the Mathematical man Å¿houlde Å¿ay that this Å¿cyence conÅ¿iderethe thinges ioyned to mater and mouing after theire Å¿ubÅ¿taÌce but Å¿euered accordynge to reaÅ¿on, both theÅ¿e though PhiloÅ¿ophers, wil ye natural philoÅ¿opher, which neuer vnderÅ¿tood thiÌgs Å¿euered froÌ matÌ & motioÌ either
in beinge or in reaÅ¿on, vtterlye deÅ¿piÅ¿e, and theyre Å¿ciences thoughe in deede more excelent thenne his, wil hee laughe to Å¿corne, moued Å¿o to do by none other cauÅ¿e, but that hee is altogether ignoraunte in theire Å¿ciences. LykewyÅ¿e you moÅ¿t worthye prynce would wonder at one Å¿kilfull in the lawes of Englande, if he Å¿hould Å¿ay that the brother Å¿hal not Å¿uccede his half brother in their fathers inheritaunce, but rather his enheritaunce Å¿hall deÅ¿cende to the Å¿iÅ¿ter of the whole bloude, or elz it Å¿halbee intituled to the chiefe lord of the fee as his eÅ¿cheat: Herat you would muche marueill, beecauÅ¿e you knowe not the cauÅ¿e of this lawe. Howebeeit the difficultie of this caÅ¿e
nothing troubleth him yt is learned in the lawes of England. Wherfore it is a commen Å¿ayinge, that an art hath no foe but the ignoraunt perÅ¿on.

But god forbid O noble prince that you Å¿hould be an enemye to the lawes of that royalme, whyche you Å¿hall by Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿ion inherite: or that you Å¿hould deÅ¿piÅ¿e them, Å¿eeing yt ye a fore cited text of Å¿cripture inÅ¿tructeth you to the loue of IuÅ¿tyce. Wherefore moÅ¿te Å¿oueraigne Prince I doe with moÅ¿te earneÅ¿t affection require you to learne the lawes of youre fathers kingdome, whom you Å¿hall Å¿ucceede, not onelye to the intent you maye the rather auoyde theÅ¿e inconuenyences,
but alÅ¿o becauÅ¿e mannes mynde which naturally deÅ¿ireth the thing that is good, and can deÅ¿ire nothing, but in reÅ¿pects that it is good, as Å¿oone as by learninge it hathe taken holde of that whiche is good, it becommeth ioyefull, and loueth the Å¿ame: & the more that it is afterwarde occupied in the remembrance of the Å¿ame, Å¿o much it is more delited therin. Whereby you are taughte yt if you once by learning attaine to ye vnderÅ¿tanding of ye foreÅ¿aid lawes wherein you are nowe ignoraunt, Å¿eeinge they bee perfectlye good, you muÅ¿t needes loue theÌ And ye more yt you record theÌ in your miÌde, Å¿o much ye more delyte & pleaÅ¿ure Å¿hal you haue in them.

For what Å¿oeuer it is ye is loued, the Å¿ame draweth the louer of it into ye nature therof. So that as the PhiÅ¿opher Å¿ayeth, vÅ¿e or exerciÅ¿e becommeth an other nature. So a Å¿lippe of a Peare tree beeynge graffed into the Å¿tocke of an appletree, after that it hath taken, it Å¿o draweth the appletree into the nature of the Peartree, ye they bothe for euer after are rightly called a pearetree, and doe bring furth the fruite of a pearetree. In lyke Å¿orte continuall vÅ¿e and practyÅ¿e of vertu cauÅ¿eth a full perfection therof, in Å¿o muche that the practyÅ¿er of the Å¿ame is afterward named therby: as a man indued with
modeÅ¿tye, of the vÅ¿e therof is named modeÅ¿t. Hee that vÅ¿eth continencye is called continent, and one garniÅ¿hed with wiÅ¿edom is called wiÅ¿e. Wherfore you alÅ¿o moÅ¿te myghtye prince, when you are pleÅ¿antly delyted in IuÅ¿tice, and therewith indued, in reÅ¿pect of the perfeccion of the law you Å¿hal wortheli be called IuÅ¿t. For which cauÅ¿e it Å¿halbe Å¿aide vnto you: Thou haÅ¿t loued IuÅ¿tice & hated iniquitie, and therfore the lord thy God hath anointed the with ye oyle of gladnes aboue the kings of the earth thy coÌ panions.

SEd quomoÌ iuÅ¿ticiam diligere poteris, Å¿inon primo legum Å¿cientiaÌ quibus ipÅ¿a cognoÅ¿catur, vtcuÌque appreheÌderis? Dicit nam
que PhiloÅ¿ophus, quod nihil amatuÌ niÅ¿i cognitum. Quare Fabius Orator ait, qdâ felices eÅ¿Å¿ent artes Å¿i de illis Å¿oli artifices iudicarent. Ignotum vero noÌ Å¿olum noÌ amari, Å¿ed & Å¿perni Å¿olet. quÃ´ poeta quidaÌ Å¿ic ait: omnia que neÅ¿cit, dicit Å¿perneÌ da colonus. Et noÌ coloni Å¿olum vox hec eÅ¿t Å¿ed et doctorum
peritiÅ¿Å¿imorum quo
que viroruÌ NaÌ Å¿i ad PhiloÅ¿ophum naturalâ qui in mathe. nunquaÌ Å¿tuduit, methaphiÅ¿icus dicat qdâ Å¿cientia Å¿ua conÅ¿iderat resÅ¿eperatas ab oÌni materia et motu Å¿cdâm secundum eÅ¿Å¿e et Å¿ecuÌduÌ rationeÌ: Vel mathemathecus dicat, quod Å¿ua Å¿cientia conÅ¿iderat res coniunctas materiÌ ae, et motui Å¿ecundum eÅ¿Å¿e Å¿ed Å¿eêatas Å¿ecundum rationem. Ambos hos licet phoÌs, philoÅ¿ophus ille naturalis qui nuÌquaÌ nouit res aliquas Å¿eêatas a materia & motu
eÅ¿Å¿entia vel ratione Å¿pernet eorumquÃ¨ Å¿ciencias, licet Å¿ua Å¿cientia nobili ores ipÅ¿e deridebit, non alia ductê° cauÅ¿a, niÅ¿i quia eorum Å¿cientias ipÅ¿e penitus ignorat. Sic et tu princeps legis Anglie êituÌ miraberis, Å¿i dicat quod frater fratri Å¿ibi nequaquaÌ vterino, non Å¿uccedet in hereditate paterna, Å¿ed potiê° hereditas illa, Å¿oro ri integri Å¿anguinis Å¿ui deÅ¿cendet. Aut capitali domino feodi accidet vt eÅ¿caeta Å¿ua. CuÌ cauÅ¿am legis huÃ­us tu ignores, in lege tamen Angliae doctuÌ, huius caÅ¿us difficultas nullatenus
perturbat.
Quare et vulgariterdicitur: quod ars non habet inimicum niÅ¿i ignorantem.

Sed abÅ¿it a te, fili Regis, vt inimiceris legibus regni quo tu Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿urus es, vel vt eas Å¿pernes cum iuÅ¿ticiam diligere, predicta Å¿apientiae lectio te erudiat Iterum igitur at
que iterum, princeps inclitiÅ¿Å¿ime, te adiuro vt leges regni patris tui, cui Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿urus es addiÅ¿cas.

Ne dum vt inconuenieÌtias has tu euites: Sed
quia mens humana, quae naturaliter bonum appetit, et nihil poteÅ¿t appetere, niÅ¿i Å¿ub ratione boni, mox vt per doctrinam bonum appreheÌ derit, guadet et illud amat, ac quanto deinceps illud plus recordatur, tanto amplius delectatur iÌ eodem. quo doceris quÃ³d Å¿i leges predictas quas iam ignoras intellexeris ê doctrinam, cum optimae illae Å¿int, amabis eas. Et quaÌ to plus eaÅ¿dem mente pertractaueris, tanto eiÅ¿dem delectabilius tu frueris.

Nam omne quod amatur, vÅ¿u trahit amatorem Å¿uum in naturani eius. Vnde vt dicit PhiloÅ¿ophus vÅ¿us altera fit natura, Å¿ic ramunculus piri, Å¿tipiti pomi inÅ¿ertus, poÅ¿tquam coaluerit, ita pomum trahit in naturam piri, vt ambae deinceps merito pirus appellentur, fructuÅ¿
que producant piri. Sic et vÅ¿itata virtus habitum generat, vt vtens ea deinde a virtute illa denominetur, quo modeÅ¿tiae preditus,
vÅ¿u modeÅ¿tus nominatur, contineÌ tiae, continens, et Å¿apientiae Å¿apiens. Quare et tu princeps, poÅ¿tquam iuÅ¿titia delectabiliter functus fueris, habitumque legis indutus fueris merito denominaberis iuÅ¿tus, cuius gratia tibi dicetur: dilexiÅ¿ti iuÅ¿ticiam, quo et odiÅ¿ti iniquitatem, propterea vnxit te dominus deus tuus oleo letitiae pre conÅ¿ortibus tuis regibus terrae.

div.head: Â¶Here the Chauncellour briefly repeteth the effect of all his perÅ¿wacion. Cap. 6.

div.p: NOw moÅ¿te gracious prince is not all thys enoughe to moue youre highnes to the Å¿tudye of ye lawe? Seing that thereby you Å¿hal indue your Å¿elfe with IuÅ¿tice, whiche Å¿hall yelde vnto you the name of a iuÅ¿te man. And Å¿hall alÅ¿o eÅ¿chue the infamy of ignoraunce in the lawe. And further by the lawe you enioying felicity, Å¿hal be bleÅ¿Å¿ed in this life. And finallye beinge furniÅ¿hed wt a louyng feare, whiche is the wiÅ¿edome of God, you Å¿hall obtain & poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿e Charitie, whiche is a Å¿tedfaÅ¿t loue to godward, and by the meane thereof cleanynge to God, you Å¿hall by the apoÅ¿tles Å¿ayenge bee made one Spirite wyth hym.

But forÅ¿omuche as the lawe without grace cannot accoÌpliÅ¿h theÅ¿e thiÌgs it is neceÅ¿Å¿arie and requiÅ¿ite that aboue all things you make earneÅ¿te interceÅ¿Å¿ion for it: and alÅ¿o yt you beecome a Å¿tudious Å¿ercher of goddes lawe, & of the holye Å¿cripture.
For Å¿cripture Å¿aieth that all men are vaine in whoÌ is not ye knowlege of god in the xiii. chapiter of the booke of wiÅ¿edome.

Wherefore moÅ¿te noble prince while you are yet yong, & while your Å¿oule is as it were a Å¿moothe blanke table, write in it theÅ¿e thinges, leÅ¿t heereafter you happen to take pleaÅ¿ure in writiÌg leÅ¿Å¿oÌs of leÅ¿Å¿e profit therin.

For as a certeine wyÅ¿e man Å¿ayeth,
Whereof the veÅ¿Å¿el newe, did firÅ¿t receue the taÅ¿te:
Therein when it is olde, the Å¿ent will euer laÅ¿t.
What handycraÅ¿tes maÌ dothe Å¿o negligentlye regard ye profite of his child whoÌe while hee is yong, he wil not Å¿ee brought vp in Å¿uch an occupacion, as thereby hee maye afterwarde obtaine to leade a mery life. So the carpenter teacheth his Å¿onne to cutt with an axe: ye Å¿myth his to Å¿tryke wt an hammer: and whome he entendethe to make a Å¿pirituall miniÅ¿ter, him he procureth to be trained vp in learning. So likewiÅ¿e is it conuenient yt a kinges Å¿onne which Å¿hal gouern the people after his father bee in his youthe inÅ¿tructed in the lawes.

Whiche order if the ruelers of the worlde would obÅ¿erue, then the worlde Å¿hould be gouerned with muche more IuÅ¿tice then now it is. Vnto whom if you wyll followe myne exhortacion, you Å¿hall miniÅ¿ter no Å¿male example.

NOnne tunc Princeps Å¿e reniÅ¿Å¿ime, hec te Å¿atis concitant, ad legis rudimenta: cuÌ per ea, iuÅ¿titiaÌ induere valeas: quo et appellaberis iuÅ¿tus, ignorantiae quo
que legis euitare poteris ignominiam: ac per legem felicitate fruens, beatus eÅ¿Å¿e poteris in hac vita, et demum filiali timore indutus, qui dei Å¿apientia eÅ¿t, charitatem quae amor in deuÌ eÅ¿t imperturbatus conÅ¿equeris, qua deo adherens, per ApoÅ¿toli Å¿ententiam, fies vnus Å¿piritus cum eo.

Sed quia iÅ¿ta, Å¿ine gratia lex operari nequit, tibi illam Å¿uper omnia implorare neceÅ¿Å¿e eÅ¿t, legis quoque diuinae et Å¿anctarum Å¿cripturarum indagare Å¿cientiam. Cum dicat Å¿criptura Å¿acra: quod vani Å¿unt omnes in quibus non Å¿ubeÅ¿t Å¿cientia dei. Sapienciae cap. xiij. His igitur princeps, dum adoleÅ¿cens es, et anima tua velut tabula raÅ¿a, depinge eam, ne in futurum, ipÅ¿a figuris minoris frugi delectabilius depingatur.

Quia etiam (vt Å¿apiens quidam ait)
quod noua teÅ¿ta capit, inueterata Å¿apit. Quis artifex tam negligeÌs profectus Å¿uae prolis eÅ¿t, vt noÌ eaÌ dum pubeÅ¿cit artibus inÅ¿truat, quibus poÅ¿tea vitae Å¿olatia nanciÅ¿catur? Sic lignarius faber Å¿ecare dolabro, ferrarius ferire malleo, filiuÌ inÅ¿truit: et queÌ in Å¿piritualibus miniÅ¿trarâ cupit, literis imbui facit. Sic et principi filium Å¿uum qui poÅ¿t eum populuÌ regulabit, legibus inÅ¿trui duÌ minor eÅ¿t conuenit,
qualiter Å¿i feceriÌt rectores orbis, mundus iÅ¿te ampliori quam iam eÅ¿t iuÅ¿titia regeretur, quibus Å¿i tu vt iam hortor facias, exemplum non minimum miniÅ¿trabis.

div.head: Â¶Now the Prince yeldeth himÅ¿elfe to the Å¿tudye of the lawes, though he be yet diÅ¿quieted with certeine doubtes. Ca. 7.

div.p:
THus when the ChauÌ cellour had Å¿ayde, hee helde hys peace, to whom the Prince beganne on this wiÅ¿e to Å¿peake. You haue ouercome me welbe loued Chauncellour wt your moÅ¿te pleÅ¿ant talke, wherwt you haue iÌflamed
my mynde with a ferueÌt deÅ¿ire towarde the knowledge of the lawe. Howbee it ii. thynges there bee that doe toÅ¿Å¿e my mynde to and fro, and Å¿o diÅ¿quiet it, that lyke a Å¿hyppe in the raging waues, it knoweth not whiche waye to inclyne for eaÅ¿e. The one is, while it conÅ¿ydereth howe manye yeares the Å¿tudentes of the lawez beÅ¿towe therein before they canne attain to Å¿ufficient knowledge of the Å¿ame. Whiche cauÅ¿eth my mynde alÅ¿o to dreade leaÅ¿te that I Å¿houlde likewyÅ¿e Å¿pende the yeares of my youthe.

The other is whether I Å¿hall applye my Å¿elfe to the Å¿tudye of the lawes of England, or of the Ciuile
laws, which through out the whole worlde are chieflye eÅ¿teemed: For people maye not be gouerned but by righte good lawes, and as the PhiloÅ¿ophier Å¿aithe, nature coueteth that which is beÅ¿t. Wherfore I would gladlye heare your councell in this behalfe. To whome the Chauncellour made thys aunÅ¿were. TheÅ¿e matters, O Kynges Å¿onne, are not hydde vnder Å¿o deepe and darke miÅ¿teries, that they require any greate delyberacyon, or aduyÅ¿ement.
And therefore what I thinke beÅ¿t hearein I wil not hyde.

SIlente extunc Cancellario, Princeps ipÅ¿e Å¿ic exorÅ¿us eÅ¿t. ViciÅ¿ti me, vir egregie, Å¿uauiÅ¿Å¿ima oratione tua, qua et animum meum,
ardore non minimo legis feciÅ¿ti Å¿itire documenta. Sed tameÌ duobus, me huc illuc
que , agitantibus, animus ipÅ¿e affligitur: vt tanquam in turbido mari cimba, neÅ¿ciat quorÅ¿um dirigere proras. VnuÌ eÅ¿t dum recolit quot annoruÌ curriculis leges ad diÅ¿centes, earum Å¿tudio Å¿e conferunt, antequam Å¿ufficientem earundem peritiam nanciÅ¿caÌ tur: quÃ´ timet animus ipÅ¿e, ne conÅ¿imiliter ego preteream animos iuuentutis meae. Alterum eÅ¿t, an Angliae Legum vel Ciuilium
quae per orbem percelebres Å¿unt, Å¿tudio operam dabo.
Nam non niÅ¿i optimis legibus populum regere licet, etiam vt dicit PhiloÅ¿ophus, natura deprecatur optima, quare libenter Å¿uper his, quid tu conÅ¿ulis aÅ¿cultaremus.
Cui Cancellarius Non Å¿unt hec, fili Regis, tantis celata miÅ¿teriis, vt deliberatione ege ant ingenti, quare quid in his mihi viÅ¿um eÅ¿t prodere non differemus.

div.head: Â¶So muche knowledge of the lawe as is neceÅ¿Å¿ary for a Prince, is Å¿oone had. Cha. 8.

div.p: ARiÅ¿totle in the firÅ¿te booke of his naturall PhiloÅ¿ophy Å¿aith, ye then we Å¿uppoÅ¿e our Å¿elues to haue the knowlege of euerye thinge, when wee know the cauÅ¿es and beginninges therof euen to the principles, vppon the which text the comentatour Å¿aieth that the philoÅ¿opher by beginninges or principles did vnderÅ¿taÌde the cauÅ¿es efficient, by ye terme CauÅ¿es he vnderÅ¿toode cauÅ¿es finall, & by Elementes matter and fourme. But in the lawe there are no matter and fourme, as in thinges natural, and compounde.

How beit ther be in them certeine Elementes, out of the which they procede as out of mater & fourm.
TheÅ¿e are cuÅ¿toÌs, Å¿tatuts & the lawe of nature: of ye which all the â¢ awes of the roialme haue their beginning, euen as all natural thinges haue of matter & fourme, and as all things that are written and read do coÌÅ¿iÅ¿t of letters, which alÅ¿o are called elementes. But Principles, or beeginninges, whiche are as the commentarye Å¿aieth, cauÅ¿es efficient, they are certein vniuerÅ¿al propoÅ¿itions, which they that bee learned in the lawes of England and likewyÅ¿e ye Mathematicals do terme Maximes: the Rethoricians do call the Å¿ame Paradoxes: and the CiuiliaÌs terme theÌ rueles of the law. TheÅ¿e in dede caÌnot bee proued by force of
argumentes, or by demoÌ Å¿tracions logicall, but as it is Å¿aide in the Å¿econde booke of PoÅ¿teriorÌ, they are knowen by induction by the waye of Å¿enÅ¿e and memorye. Wherefore in the firÅ¿te booke of hys naturall PhiloÅ¿ophye AriÅ¿totle Å¿ayth that principles are not made of others, nor one of them of an other, but all other bee made of them. And accordinge thereunto in the firÅ¿te booke of his Topikes hee writeth, that euery principle is a Å¿ufficient proofe of it Å¿elfe.

And therefore the PhiloÅ¿opher Å¿aieth that Å¿uche as denye them ought not to bee diÅ¿puted or reaÅ¿oned withall: becauÅ¿e that as hee writeth in the Å¿ixthe
booke of his morall PhiloÅ¿ophie, there is no reaÅ¿oÌ to be geuen for principlez Wherefore whoÅ¿oeuer they be that couet to profite in ye knowlege of any faculties, they muÅ¿t nedez firÅ¿t be furniÅ¿hed wt principles. For by them are opened the cauÅ¿es finall, vnto the which by the direction of reaÅ¿on through the knowledge of ye principles we doe attaine.

wherfore theÅ¿e iii. vz priÌ ciples, cauÅ¿es, and elemÌtz beinge vnknowen, the Å¿cience whereof they are is altogether vnknowen And the Å¿ame .iii. beeinge knowen, the Å¿cience alÅ¿o whereof they are is thought to be knoweÌ, not determinatly or pÌciÅ¿ely, but Å¿uêficially after a coÌfuÅ¿e
& vniuerÅ¿all Å¿orte.

Thus wee thinke our Å¿elues to haue the knowledge of godds lawes, when wee vnderÅ¿tande our Å¿elues to knowe faith charitie, and hope, and alÅ¿o the Sacramentes of the churche, and the commaundementes of God, leauynge to the prelates of the Churche the other miÅ¿teries of theologye.

Wherefore the lord Å¿aith vntoo his diÅ¿ciples: To you it is geeuen to know the miÅ¿terie of the kyngdome of God, but to other in Parables, that Å¿eeynge they maye not Å¿ee. And the ApoÅ¿tle Å¿ayeth: Not to bee wyÅ¿er then it beehoueth.
And in another place.

Not beeinge highe in wiÅ¿edome. In like maner O moÅ¿te worthy Prince, it Å¿hall not bee needefull for you with longe Å¿tudy to Å¿earche out the Å¿ecrete miÅ¿teries of the lawe of Englande. It Å¿hall Å¿uffice for you as you haue profited in grammer, Å¿o alÅ¿o to profite in lawe.

Vntoo the perfection of grammer Å¿pringinge out of Etimologie, Orthographie, ProÅ¿odie, & ConÅ¿truction as out of .iiii. fountaines, you haue not exactlye attayned, and yet you are Å¿o Å¿ufficiently grounded in grammer that you may well be called a Gramarrien. LikewiÅ¿e Å¿hal you be wel worthy to be called a lawier, if you Å¿erch out ye priÌciplz
& cauÅ¿es of ye lawes euen to ye elementz after ye maner of a Å¿cholar or a learner. For it Å¿hal not be needefull or expedieÌt for you by the trauel of your owne wytte to Å¿tudie out the hydde myÅ¿teries of ye lawe. But let ye geare be lefte to your iudges & meÌ of lawe, whiche in the royalme of Englande are called Seriauntz at lawe and to other profeÅ¿Å¿ours of the lawe commeÌly called apprentices. For you Å¿hall better execute iudgementes by other, then by your Å¿elf. Neither hathe it bene Å¿eeÌe that any kynge of Englonde hathe pronounced iudgement with his owne mouthe. And yet neuertheleÅ¿Å¿e all the iudgements of the
royalme are his, thoughe by other they be vttered and pronouÌced. Lyke as alÅ¿o kynge IoÅ¿aphat affirmed the Å¿entences of all the iudges to bee the iudgemeÌts of god. Wherfore moÅ¿t gracious priÌce you Å¿hall in Å¿horte tyme with little labour be Å¿ufficiently learned in the lawes of EnglaÌd, Å¿o that you do applie your mynd to the obteynynge therof For Seneca in an epiÅ¿tle to Lucillus Å¿ayethe: There is nothiÌge which earneÅ¿t traueill and diligent care atchieueth not And Å¿o wel do I knowe the prompte towardnes of your nature, yâ¢ I dare be bolde to Å¿aye, that in thoÅ¿e lawes (thoughe the
exacte knowelege of theÌ Å¿uche as is required iÌ iudges can Å¿kante be gotten in the Å¿pace of xx. yeares) you Å¿hall Å¿ufficiently in one yeare attayne to Å¿omuche vnderÅ¿tandynge, as is coÌuenieÌt for a priÌce Neither in the meaÌe time Å¿hall you neglect and omitt the Å¿tudie of martiall diÅ¿cipline, wherevnto you are Å¿o feruently geuen, but durynge all the Å¿ame yeare in Å¿teade of recreatioÌ you Å¿hall vÅ¿e the practiÅ¿e thereof of at your pleaÅ¿ure.

PhiloÅ¿ophus in primo PhiÅ¿icorum dicit, quod tunc vnumquodque Å¿cire arbitramur, cum cauÅ¿as et principia eius cognoÅ¿camus vÅ¿que ad elementa. Super quem textum coÌmentator dicit qdâ AriÅ¿totê° ê principia intellexit cauÅ¿as efficientes, ê cauÅ¿as intellexit cauÅ¿as finales, et per elemeÌta materiam et formam. In legibus vero non Å¿unt materia et forma, vt in PhiÅ¿icis et compoÅ¿itis. Sed tamen Å¿unt in eis elemeÌ ta quaedam, vnde ipÅ¿ae êfluuÌt, vt ex materia et forma,
quae Å¿unt conÅ¿uetudines, Å¿tatuta, et ius naturae, ex quibus Å¿unt omnia iura regni, vt ex materia et forma Å¿unt quae
que naturalia: et vt ex litteris, quae etiam elementa appellantur, Å¿unt omnia quae leguntur.

Principia autem, quae commentator dicit eÅ¿Å¿e cauÅ¿as efficientes, Å¿uÌt quaedam vniuerÅ¿alia, quae in legibus Angliae docti, Å¿imiliter et Mathematici, maximas vocant: Rethorici, paradoxas: & CiuiliÅ¿tae, regulas iuris denominaÌt: ipÅ¿a reuera non
argumeÌtorum vi, aut demonÅ¿trationibus logicis dinoÅ¿cuntur. Sed, vt Å¿ecundo poÅ¿teriorum docetur inductione, via Å¿enÅ¿us, et memoriae adipiÅ¿cuntur, quare et primo phiÅ¿icorum philoÅ¿ophus dicit: qdâ principia non fiunt ex aliis, neque ex alterutris, Å¿ed ex illis alia fiunt; quÃ´ primo topicorum Å¿cribitur, quod vnuÌquod
que principiorum eÅ¿t Å¿ibi ipÅ¿i fides. Vnde, cum negantibus ea, dicit philoÅ¿ophus non eÅ¿t diÅ¿putandum: quia, vt Å¿cribitur vi. Ethicorum.
ad Principia non eÅ¿t ratio.

Igitur principiis imbuendi Å¿unt, quiqui gliÅ¿cunt aliquas intelligere facultates. Ex eis etenim, reuelantur cauÅ¿ae finales, ad quas rationis ductu, per principiorum agnitionem peruenitur, vnde his tribus, videlicet principijs, cauÅ¿is, et elementis ignoratis Å¿cientia de qua ipÅ¿a Å¿unt, penitus ignoratur. Et his cognitis, etiam Å¿cientiam illam cognitam eÅ¿Å¿e, non determinatÃ¨, Å¿ed inconfuÅ¿Ã´ et
vniuerÅ¿aliter arbiÌ tratur.

Sic Legem diuinam nos noÅ¿Å¿e in dicamus, dum fidem, charitatem et Å¿pem, Å¿acrameÌ ta quo
que eccleÅ¿iae, ac dei mandata nos intelligere Å¿eÌ tiamus, cetera theologiae miÅ¿teria eccleÅ¿iae preÅ¿identibus relinquentes. Quare dominus diÅ¿cipulis Å¿uis ait. Vobis datum eÅ¿t noÅ¿Å¿e miÅ¿terium regni dei, ceteris autem in parabolis, vt videntes non videant &c. Et ApoÅ¿tolus dixit, non plus Å¿apere quam oportet Å¿apere, & alibi
non alta Å¿apieÌtes. Sic et tibi priÌceps neceÅ¿Å¿e non erit ãâã miÅ¿teria legis angliae longo diÅ¿ciplinatu rimare, Å¿ufficieÌt tibi vt iÌ gramatica tu profeciÅ¿ti, etiaÌ & in legibus proficias. Gramaticae vero perfectionem que ex Ethimologia, Ortographia, ProÅ¿odia, et Syntaxi, quaÅ¿i ex quatuor fontibus profluit, non Å¿pecie tenus induiÅ¿ti, et tamen gramatica Å¿ufficienter eruditus es, ita vt merito gramaticus denominoris. ConÅ¿imilit
er quo
que denomiÌari legiÅ¿ta mereberis, Å¿i legum priÌcipia,
et cauÅ¿as, vÅ¿qÌ ad â¢
limenta, diÅ¿cipuli more indagaueris NoÌ eniÌ expediet tibi êpria Å¿enÅ¿us indagine legis Å¿acramenta rimar â¢ Å¿ed relinquaÌtur illa iudicibus tuis et aduocatis, qui in regno Angliae, Å¿eruientes ad legem appellaÌtur, Å¿imiliter et aliis iuris êitis, quos apprentiÌ cios vulgus denominat, Melius eniÌ per alios, quaÌ per te ipÅ¿um iuditia reddes, quÃ³ proprio ore nullus regum Angliae iudicium proferre viÅ¿us eÌ, et tameÌ Å¿ua Å¿unt oÌnia iudicia
regni licet per alios ipÅ¿a reddaÌtur, Å¿icut et Iudicum oiÌm Å¿ententias IoÅ¿aphat aÅ¿Å¿eruit eÅ¿Å¿e iuditia dei.

Quare tu priÌceps Å¿ereniÅ¿Å¿ime paruo tempore, parua induÅ¿tria, Å¿ufficienter eris in legibus regni Angliae eruditus, dummodo ad eius apprehentionem tu conferas animum tuuÌ. Dicit nam
que Seneca in epiÅ¿tola ad Lucillum. Nil eÅ¿t quod pertinax opera et diligens cura non expugnat. NoÅ¿co namque ingenii tui êÅ¿picacitateÌ, quo audactâ ênuncio, qd. in legibus illis licet earuÌ peritia
qualis, iudicibus neceÅ¿Å¿aria eÅ¿t, vix viginti annorum lugubris adquiratur, tu doctrinam principi congruaÌ in anno vno Å¿ufficienter nanciÅ¿ceris, nec iÌterim militarem diÅ¿ciplinaÌ ad quam tam ardeÌtâ anhelas negliges, Å¿ed ea recreationis loco, etiam anno illo tu ad libitum perfrueris.

div.head: A Kynge whoÅ¿e gouernement is politique eaÌ not chaunge the lawes of hÃ­s royalme.

div.p:
THe Å¿ecoÌd poynte, moÅ¿t worthy priÌce, whereof you Å¿taÌde in feare Å¿hall iÌ
lyke maner, and as eaÅ¿eli as the other be confuted. div.head: Howe Kyngedomes of politique gouernauÌce were firÅ¿t begonne. Cap. 13.

div.p:
SAint AuÅ¿teÌ iÌ ye xxiii. chapter of his xix. booke De ciuitate dei Å¿aith ye a People is a multitude of men aÅ¿Å¿ociated by the conÅ¿ent of lawe, and communion of wealthe. And yett Å¿uch a people beynge headleÅ¿Å¿ that is to Å¿aye without a heade, is not worthye to be called a bodie. For as in thynges naturall
when the heade is cutt of the reÅ¿idue is not called a bodie, but a truncheon, Å¿o likewyÅ¿e in thinges politique a cominalte wtout a head is in no wiÅ¿e corporate. Wherefore AriÅ¿totle iÌ the firÅ¿t booke of his ciuile philoÅ¿ophie Å¿aieth ye wheÌÅ¿oeuer oÌe is made of many, amonge ye Å¿aÌe one Å¿halbe the rueler, and the other Å¿halbe rueled. wherfore a people that wyll rayÅ¿e theÌÅ¿elfs into a kingdome, or into any other bodie politique muÅ¿t euer appointe one to be chiefe rueler of the whole bodie which in kiÌgdoÌes is called a kiÌge After this kiÌde of order, as out of the embryoÌ rieÅ¿eth a bodie natural ruled by oÌe head, euen Å¿o of a multitude of people arieÅ¿eth a kyngedoÌe whiche is a bodie miÅ¿tical gouÌned by oÌe maÌ as
by an head. And like as in a natural body, as Å¿aieth the PhiloÅ¿opher, the hart is ye firÅ¿t ye liueth, hauig wtin it bloud, which it diÅ¿tributeth among all ye other members, whereby they are quickened & doe lyue: Å¿eÌblably in a bodye politik ye inteÌt of ye people is the firÅ¿t liuely thiÌg, hauing wtin it bloud, yt is to Å¿ay, politike prouiÅ¿ion for the vtilitie & welth of the Å¿ame people, which it dealeth furth & imparteth aÅ¿wel to the head as to al ye meÌbers of the Å¿ame body wherby ye body is nouriÅ¿hed & mainteined. Furthermore the lawe vnder the which a multitude of men is made a people, repreÅ¿enteth the Å¿eÌblance of Å¿ynews iÌ ye body natural BecauÅ¿e that lyke as by
Å¿ynewes the ioynyng of the bodie is made Å¿ounde Å¿o by the lawe which taketh the name a ligando yt is to witte of byndynge Å¿uche a miÅ¿ticall bodie is knytt and preÅ¿erued together. And the members & bones of the Å¿ame bodye whereby is repreÅ¿ented ye Å¿oundenes of the wealth wherby that bodie is Å¿uÅ¿teyned, do by the lawes as the naturall bodie by Å¿ynewes reteyne eueryone their proper fuÌctions And as the head of a bodi natural caÌ not chauÌge his Å¿inewes, nor caÌ not denie or witholde from his inferiour meÌbers their peculiar powers, & Å¿eueral nouriÅ¿hmÌtz of bloud, no more caÌ a kiÌge which is ye head of a bodie politik chauÌge the lawes of ye bodie nor
withdrawe from the Å¿ame people their proper Å¿ubÅ¿taÌ ce againÅ¿t their wills and conÅ¿entes in that behalfe. Nowe you vnderÅ¿tande moÅ¿t noble prince the fourme of inÅ¿titucion of a kiÌgdome politique, wherebye you maye meaÅ¿ure the power, whiche the king therof maye exerciÅ¿e ouer the lawe and Å¿ubiectes of the Å¿ame. For Å¿uch a kinge ys made and ordeyned for ye defence of the lawe of his Å¿ubiectes and of theire bodies and goodes, whereunto he receaueth power of his people, Å¿o yt hee can not gouern his people by any other power. Wherfore to Å¿atiÅ¿fy your requeÅ¿t in yt you deÅ¿ire to be certified how it coÌmeth to pas that in ye powers of kings ther is Å¿o great diuerÅ¿itie,
Å¿uerly in mine opinion the diuerÅ¿itie of the inÅ¿titutioÌz or firÅ¿t ordinances of thoÅ¿e dignities whiche I haue nowe declared, is the onelye cauÅ¿e of this foreÅ¿ayde difference, as of the premiÅ¿Å¿es by the diÅ¿courÅ¿e of reaÅ¿on you maye eaÅ¿elye gather. For thus ye kingdome of Englande oute of Brutes retinue of the Troians whiche he brought out of the coaÅ¿tes of Italie and Greece, firÅ¿te grewe to a politique & regall dominion. Thus alÅ¿o Scotland which Å¿omtime was Å¿ubiect to Englande as a Dukedome thereof was aduauÌced to a politik and roiall kingdome. Many other kiÌgdoÌs alÅ¿o had thus their firÅ¿t begiÌninge not onely of regal but alÅ¿o of politique gouernement
Wherefore Diodorus Siculus in his Å¿econde boke of olde hiÅ¿tories thus writeth of the EgiptiaÌs. The Egiptien kings liued firÅ¿t not after ye licentious maner of other rulers, whoÅ¿e will & pleaÅ¿ure is in Å¿teede of law, but they kept theÌ Å¿elfes as priuate perÅ¿ones in Å¿ubiection of the lawes And this did they willingly, beeing perÅ¿waded that by obeyinge the laws thei Å¿hould bee bleÅ¿Å¿ed. For of Å¿uche rulers as folowed theire owne luÅ¿ts they Å¿uppoÅ¿ed many thinges to be done, whereby they were brought in daunger of diuers harmes and perylles And in his fowerth boke thus he writethe. The Ethiopian kinge as Å¿one as hee is created, he ordereth his life accordiÌg to ye laws
and doth al things after ye maner and cuÅ¿tom of hys countrey, aÅ¿Å¿igninge neyther rewarde nor puniÅ¿hment to anye man otherthen the law made by his predeceÅ¿Å¿ours appointethe He reportethe likewiÅ¿e of the kinge of Saba in Arabia the happie, and of certein other kinges, whiche in olde time honorablye reigned.

Quare vt poÅ¿tulationi tuae, quacÌtiorari cupis, vnde hoc êuenit, qd poteÅ¿tates regum taÌ diuÌÅ¿imo dÃ¨ variaÌtur
Å¿uccinctius Å¿atiÅ¿facÌ. Firme coniector, qdâ diuÌÅ¿itates inÅ¿titutionÌ, dignitatuÌ illaruÌ quas êpalaui, pre dcÌam diÅ¿crepantiaÌ Å¿oluÌ modo operaÌtur, ê ut rationis diÅ¿curÅ¿u, tu ex pÌmiÅ¿Å¿is poteris exhaurire. Sic naÌ
que regnuÌ Angliae quod ex Bruti comitiua TroianoruÌ quaÌ ex Italiae et grecoruÌ finibê° êduxit, in dominiuÌ politicuÌ, et regale êrupit. Sic et Scotia quod ei quoÌdaÌ vt ducatus obediuit, in regnum creuit politicum et regale. Alia quo

Vnde Diodorê° Siculus in Å¿ecundo libro hiÅ¿toriaruÌ priÌ Å¿caruÌ de Egiptiis Å¿ic Å¿cribit. SuaÌ primuÌ Egiptij reges vitam non alioruÌ regnantiuÌ quibus voluntas pro lege eÅ¿t, traducebant licentia, Å¿ed veluti priuati tenebaÌtur legibus, ne
