div.head: Â¶Here the prince compeÌdiouÅ¿ly abbridgeth al that the ChauÌcelour afore hath diÅ¿courÅ¿ed at large. ca. 14

div.p:
TO whom the prynce thus aunÅ¿wered. You haue good ChauÌcelloure wt ye cleare light of your declaratioÌ quite driueÌ away ye cloudy miÅ¿t, wherewith the brightnes of my mind was darkned: Å¿o that I do moÅ¿t euidently Å¿ee that no
nation dyd euer of theire owne voluntarie mind in corporat themÅ¿elfes into a kingedome for anye other intent, but only to the end that therby theye mighte with more Å¿afety then before mainteine themÅ¿elfs and enioye theire goodes from Å¿uche miÅ¿fortunes & loÅ¿Å¿es as theye Å¿toode in feare of. And of this intent Å¿houlde Å¿uche a nation be vtterly defrauded, if then their kinge mighte Å¿poyle them of their goods, whiche beefore was lawefull for no man to do. And yet Å¿houlde Å¿uch a people bee much more iniured, if they Å¿houlde afterward be gouerned bye foreyne and Å¿traunge lawes, yea and Å¿uche as they paradueÌture deadly hated & abhorred.
And moÅ¿t of all if by thoÅ¿e lawes theire Å¿ubÅ¿taunce Å¿hould bee diminiÅ¿hed, for the Å¿afegarde whereof, as allÅ¿o for the defence of theire own bodies they of theire owne free will Å¿ubmitted themÅ¿elfes to the gouernaunce of a kynge No Å¿uche power Å¿uerlye coulde haue proceeded froÌ them. And yet if theye had not beene, Å¿uche a kynge coulde haue had noe power ouer them. Nowe on the other Å¿yde I perceaue it to Å¿tande muche otherwyÅ¿e withe a kingedome whyche onely by the auctoritye of a kynge is incorporate, For Å¿uch a nation is no otherwyÅ¿e Å¿ubiecte vnto hym, but that the Å¿ame nation, whyche by his pleaÅ¿ure is made his kingdome, Å¿houlde obeye hys
lawes, and bee ruled by ye Å¿ame being nothiÌg els but his like pleaÅ¿ure. Neither haue I yet good ChauÌcellour forgoten that, whiche in your treatiÅ¿e of the nature of the law of nature you haue with pithie reaÅ¿ons clerklye prooued, coÌ cerning that the power of theÅ¿e .ij. kinges is equall. Howebeit the power of ye one, whereby hee is at libertie to deale wroÌgfully is not by Å¿uche liberty augmented and increaÅ¿ed. As to be of habilitie to decaye and die is no hability, but in reÅ¿pect of the priuation and feblenes in the thinge it is rather to bee called a diÅ¿habilitie. BecauÅ¿e that as Boetius Å¿aieth: habilitie and power is not but to good. So yâ¢ to bee of habilitie or power to do euill
(as is the kinge that regaly dothe rule, & that withe muche more libertie, then the kiÌg yt hath a politique dominioÌ ouer his people) is rather a diminution then an increaÅ¿e of power For the holie Å¿pirites whiche are nowe eÅ¿tabliÅ¿hed in glorie and can not Å¿iÌne doe in power farre excell and paÅ¿Å¿e vs, which haue a delyte and pleaÅ¿ure to runne headlonge into all kinde of wickednes. Now therefore I haue but thys one onelye queÅ¿tion to demaunde of you, whether the lawe of Englande to the Å¿tudie whereof you exhort me, bee as good and effectuall for the gouernement of that kingdom, as ye Ciuile lawe, wherebye ye holie eÌpire is gouerned,
is thought Å¿ufficient for ye gouernemente of ye whole worlde? Yf withe Å¿ounde reaÅ¿ons, and apparaunte demonÅ¿trations you reÅ¿olue me in this point, I wil Å¿treighte yeelde me to the Å¿tudie of the lawe, wytheout further troubling you with my queÅ¿tions in this mater.

CVi princeps. EffugaÅ¿ti CaÌ cell â¢ rie, declarationis tuae lumine tenebras quibus obducra erat acies mentis meae, quo clariÅ¿Å¿ime iaÌ conÅ¿picio, quod non aliopacto gens aliqua
proprio arbitrio vnquam Å¿e in regnum corporauit, niÅ¿i vt per hoc, Å¿e et Å¿ua quorum diÅ¿pendia for midabant, tutius quam antea poÅ¿Å¿iderent, quaÅ¿i propoÅ¿ito gens huiuÅ¿modi frauderetâ, Å¿i ex inde facultates eorum eripere poÅ¿Å¿it rex Å¿uus, quod antea facere vlli hominum non licebat. Et ad huc grauius multo populus talis lederetur, Å¿i deinde peregrinis legibus etiam ipÅ¿is forÅ¿an exoÅ¿is, regerentur.

Et maxime Å¿i legibus illis eorum minoraretur Å¿ubÅ¿tantia, pro cuius vitaÌ da iactura, vt pro Å¿uorum tutela corporuÌ, ipÅ¿i Å¿e regis iÌ perio, arbitrio proprio Å¿ubmiÅ¿erunt. Non potuit reuera poteÅ¿tas hmÌodi ab ipÅ¿is erupiÅ¿Å¿e, et tamen Å¿i non ab ipÅ¿is, rex huiuÅ¿modi Å¿uper ipÅ¿os nullaÌ optineret poteÅ¿tateÌ, e regione aliter eÅ¿Å¿e coÌcipio, de regno quod regis Å¿oluÌ auctoritate et potentia incorporatuÌ eÅ¿t, quia non alio pacto gens talis ei subiecta eÌ niÅ¿i vt eiê° legibê°, qÌ Å¿uÌt illiê° placita, geÌs ipÌa qÌ eodeÌ placito regnuÌ eius effecta
eÅ¿t, obteÌperaret et regenetâ. Ne
que CaÌ cellarie, a mea huc uÅ¿
que memoria elapÅ¿uÌ eÅ¿t, qdâ alias in tractatu de natura legis naturae, horuÌ duoruÌ reguÌ equaleÌ eÅ¿Å¿e poteÌtiaÌ, doctis rationibus oÅ¿teÌ diÅ¿ti, dum poteÅ¿tas qua eoruÌ alter êperaÌ agere liber eÌ, libertate huiuÅ¿modi noÌ augetur, vt poÅ¿Å¿e laugueÅ¿cere, moriue potentia non eÅ¿t Å¿ed propter priuationes in adiecto, impotentia potius denominandum. Quia vt dicit Boetius potentia non eÅ¿t niÅ¿i ad bonum, qd âª poÅ¿Å¿e male agere,
vt poteÅ¿t rex regaliter regnans, liberius quam rex politicÃ¨ dominans populoÅ¿uo, potius eius poteÅ¿tateÌ minuit, quam augmeÌ tat. Nam Å¿ancti Å¿piritus iam confirmati in gloria, qui peccare nequeunt potentiores nobis Å¿unt, qui ad omne facinus liberis gaudemus habenis. Solum igitur mihi iam Å¿upereÅ¿t a te Å¿ciÅ¿citandum, Å¿i lex Angliae ad cuius diÅ¿ciplinatum me prouocas, bona et efficax eÅ¿t ad regimen regni illius vt lex ciuilis, qua Å¿acrum regulatur imperium,
Å¿ufficiens arbitratâ ad orbis regimeÌ vniuerÅ¿i. Si me iÌ hoc demoÌÅ¿trationibus congruis indubiuÌ reddideris, ad Å¿tudiuÌ legis illius illico me conferam, nec te poÅ¿tulationibus meis Å¿uper his, apliê° fatigabo.

div.head: Â¶That all lawes are the lawe of nature, cuÅ¿tomes or Å¿tatutes. Cap. 15.

div.p:
THe Chauncelour aunÅ¿wered Å¿aiyng. You haue well committed to memorie moÅ¿t worthie prince al that I haue hitherto declared vnto you. Wherfore you are well worthy to haue this doubt openyd wherupon now you haue mooued youre queÅ¿tion.
You Å¿hal therfore vnderÅ¿taÌd yt al humayne lawes are either the law of nature, or cuÅ¿tomes, or elles Å¿tatuts, which are alÅ¿o called coÌÅ¿titutions. But cuÅ¿tomes & ye Å¿enteÌces of the lawe of nature after that they were once put iÌ writing, & by ye Å¿ufficieÌt autoritie of ye prince publiÅ¿hed and commaunded to be kept, were chauÌged iÌto ye nature of coÌÅ¿titutions, or Å¿tatuts, and did after that more penally, then before binde the Å¿ubiectes of the prince to the keepinge of theÌ by the Å¿eueritye of his commaundemeÌt. Of this Å¿orte are the moÅ¿t parte of the Ciuile lawes, whiche of the Romain priÌces are digeÅ¿ted in great volumes & by their auctoritie commauÌded to bee obÅ¿erued.
And not theye onelye are called by ye name of ye Ciuile law, but alÅ¿o al the other Å¿tatutes of eÌperours. Now then if that among theÅ¿e .iij. welÅ¿prings of all lawe I proue the preeminence of the lawe of England to excell aboue ye reÅ¿t I Å¿hal therwith proue the Å¿ame lawe to be good and effectuall for the gouernemeÌt of ye kingedome. And further if I do Å¿hewe it to bee as commodious for the wealthe of that Royalme as the Ciuile lawes are for the wealthe of the empire, then Å¿hall I make euident and plain not onely that this law is of much excellencye, but allÅ¿o that it is an electe and choÅ¿en lawe, aÅ¿well as the Ciuile lawes are: whyche is ye thinge yt you require
Wherefore to the proofe and declaracion of theÅ¿e .ij. poiÌts thus I êcede.
CAncellarius memoriae tuae princeps optime commendaÅ¿ti quae tibi hucuÅ¿que Å¿uggeÅ¿Å¿i, quare et quae iam interrogas, meritus es vt paÌ dam.

Scire te igitur volo, qd; oiÌa iura humana aut Å¿uÌt lex naturae, coÌÅ¿uetudinÌ vel Å¿tatuta qÌ et coÌ Å¿titutioÌes appellaÌ tur. Sed coÌÅ¿uetudines et legis naturae Å¿eÌteÌtiae poÅ¿tquaÌ in Å¿cripturaÌ redactae et Å¿ufficieÌti auctoritate priÌcipis promulgatae fueriÌt, ac cuÅ¿todiri iubeaÌtur in coÌÅ¿titutionuÌ Å¿iue Å¿tatutoruÌ naturaÌ mutaÌtur, et deinde penalius quaÌ aÌ tea, Å¿ubditos priÌcipis ad earuÌ cuÅ¿todiaÌ coÌÅ¿trin guÌt, Å¿eueritate maÌdati illius, qualis eÅ¿t leguÌ ciuiliuÌ pars noÌ modica, qÌ a RomanoruÌ priÌcipibê° iÌ magnis voluminibê° redigitur, et eorâ auctoritate
obÅ¿eruari maÌdatur. Vnde legis Ciuilis vt cet
er a ImperatoruÌ Å¿tatuta iaÌ pars illa nomeÌ Å¿ortita eÌ. Si igitur in his tribus quaÅ¿i oÌnis iuris fontibus legis Angliae preÅ¿taÌ tiam probauerim prefulgere, legem illam bonam eÅ¿Å¿e et efficaceÌ ad regni illius regimeÌ etiam comêbaui. Deinde Å¿i eam ad eiuÅ¿dem regni vtilitatem, vt leges ciuiles ad imperij bonum accomodam eÅ¿Å¿e lucidÃ¨ oÅ¿teÌderim, neduÌ tuÌc legeÌ illaÌ preÅ¿tanteÌ, Å¿ed et vt leges ciuiles electam (vt tu optas) etiaÌ patefeci.
Igitur hec duo tibi oÅ¿tendere Å¿atagens, Å¿ic progredior.

div.head: Â¶The lawe of nature in all countreis is al one. Cap. 16

div.p:
The lawes of England in thoÅ¿e thiÌgs whiche they by force of the law of naturÌ do ratify & eÅ¿tabliÅ¿h are neither better nor worÅ¿e in their iudgements theÌ ye lawes of al other natioÌs are in ye like caÅ¿es. For as AriÅ¿totle in ye fifth boke of his morall philoÅ¿ophie Å¿aieth. The law of nature is yt which among al people hath like Å¿treÌgth & power Wherefore hereof to reaÅ¿on any loÌger it Å¿hall not auayle. But nowe hencefurth we wil Å¿earche oute what maner of cuÅ¿toÌes & Å¿tatutz theÅ¿e of EnglaÌd ar
And firÅ¿te the qualytie of thoÅ¿e cuÅ¿tomes wee wyll conÅ¿ider.

LEges Angliae, iÌ his qÌ ipÌae Å¿aÌctiuÌt legis naturae ratioÌe, non meliores peioreÅ¿ue Å¿unt in iudiciis Å¿uis, quaÌ in coÌÅ¿imilibê° Å¿uÌt oÌnes leges ceteraruÌ nationuÌ. Quia vt dicit PhuÌs. v. EthicoruÌ. Iê° naturale eÅ¿t quod apud omnes homines eaÌdeÌ heÌt potentiam, quare de ea aÌplius diÅ¿ceptare noÌ expeditur. Sed quales Å¿uÌt Angliae coÌÅ¿uetudines Å¿lâer similiter et Å¿tatuta eÅ¿t amodo êÅ¿crutaÌduÌ
et primo coÌÅ¿uetudinuÌ illaruÌ viÅ¿itab â¢
mê° qualitates.

div.head: Â¶The cuÅ¿tomes of Englande are of moÅ¿t auncient aÌ tiquitie, practiÅ¿ed and receaued of v. Å¿euerall nations from one to an other by Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿ion. Cap. 17

div.p:
THe roialme of England was firÅ¿t inhabited of ye BritoÌs. Next after theÌ ye Romains had ye rule of ye lande. And theÌ again ye BritoÌs poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ed it. After whoÌ the Saxons inuaded it, who chauÌging ye name therof did for Britain call it England. After theÌ for a certain tyme the Danes had the dominioÌ of the Roialme, & theÌ SaxoÌs again. But laÅ¿t of al the Normans Å¿ubdued it, whoÅ¿e diÅ¿cent continuethe in ye gouernmeÌt of ye kingdom at this preÅ¿ent.
And in al ye times of theÅ¿e Å¿eueral nations & of theire kinges this roialme was Å¿till ruled withe the Å¿elfe Å¿ame cuÅ¿tomes that it is nowe gouerned witheall. Whiche if theye had not beene right good, Å¿ome of thoÅ¿e kynges moued eyther with IuÅ¿tice or with reaÅ¿on, or affection would haue chauÌged them, or els altogether aboliÅ¿hed theÌ: and Å¿pecially the RomaiÌs who did iudge all the reÅ¿t of the world by their own lawes. LikewiÅ¿e woulde other of the foreÅ¿aide kinges haue done whiche bye the Å¿worde onelye poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ing the royalme of Englande myghte by the lyke power and auctoritye haue extinguiÅ¿Å¿hed the lawes thereof.
And touchynge the antyquitie of the Å¿ame neither are the Romaine Ciuile lawes by Å¿o longe contynuaunce of auÌcient times confirmed nor yet the lawes of the venetians, whiche aboue al other are reported to be of moÅ¿t antiquity: forÅ¿omuch as their Ilande in the beginninge of the Britones was not then inhabited, as Roome then alÅ¿o vnbuilded: neyther the lawes of any patnime nation of the world are of Å¿o olde and auncyent yeares. Wherefore the contrarye is not to be Å¿ayde nor thoughte, but that the EnglyÅ¿he cuÅ¿tomes are verye good, yea of all other the verye beÅ¿t.

REgnuÌ Angliae primo per Britones iÌhabitatum eÅ¿t, deinde per Romanos regulatum iteruÌ
que per Britones, ac deiÌde ê Saxones poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿uÌ, qui nomen eius ex BritaÌnia in Angliam mutaueruÌt: ex tuÌc per Danos ideÌ regnuÌ paruÌ ê dnÌatuÌ eÅ¿t, et iteruÌ ê Saxones, Å¿ed finaliter per Normannos quorum propago regnum illud optinet in preÅ¿enti,
Et in omnibus nationuÌ harum et regum earuÌ teÌporibus, regnuÌ illud eiÅ¿deÌ quibus iaÌ regitur conÅ¿uetudinibus, continue regulatuÌ eÅ¿t. Quae Å¿i optimae noÌ extitiÅ¿Å¿ent, aliqui reguÌ illoruÌ iuÅ¿titia, ratione, vel affectione concitati, eas mutaÅ¿Å¿ent aut oÌnino deleuiÅ¿Å¿eÌt, et maxiÌme Romani: qui legibê° Å¿uis quaÅ¿i totuÌ orbis reliquum iudicabant. Similiter et alij reguÌ predictorum, qui, Å¿olum gladio regnuÌ Angliae poÅ¿Å¿iderunt, quo et poteÌ tia Å¿imili ipÅ¿i leges eius exinaniÅ¿Å¿e valuerunt.
Ne
que vero tantorum temporuÌ curriculis, leges Ciuiles in quaÌ tum Romanorum inueteratae Å¿unt, neque venetoruÌ leges quae Å¿uper alias antiquitate diuulgantur quoruÌ tum inÅ¿ula in initio Britonum inhabitata non fuit, Å¿icut nec Roma coÌ dita, nec vllorum mundi regnorum deicolarum leges tanto aeuo inolitae Å¿unt, quare non bonas, immo non optimas eÅ¿Å¿e anglorum conÅ¿uetudines, Å¿icut non dicere, ita nec Å¿uÅ¿picari fas eÅ¿t.

div.head: Â¶Here he Å¿heweth with what grauitie Å¿tatuts are made in Englande. Cap. 18.

div.p:
NOw whether the Å¿tatuts of England bee good or not, that onely remainethe to be diÅ¿cuÅ¿Å¿ed. For they procede not onely from the princes pleaÅ¿ure as do the lawes of thoÅ¿e kingdomes that are ruled onelye by regal gouernement, where Å¿ometymes ye Å¿tatuts do Å¿o procure the Å¿ingular commoditie of the maker, that theye redounde to the hinderaunce and dammage of his Å¿ubiectes. Sometymes allÅ¿o by the neglygence, and ouerÅ¿ight of Å¿uch priÌces, & their Å¿leighte regard, reÅ¿pecting onelye their own coÌmodities thei are Å¿o vnaduiÅ¿edly made,
that they are more woorthy to haue the name of diÅ¿orders, then of well ordered lawes. But Å¿tatutes cannot thus paÅ¿Å¿e in Englande, forÅ¿omuch as they are made not onlye by the Princes pleaÅ¿ure, but alÅ¿o by the aÅ¿Å¿eÌt of the whole royalme: Å¿o that of neceÅ¿Å¿itie they muÅ¿t procure the wealth of the people, and in noe wiÅ¿e tende to theire hynderaunce. And it cannot otherwiÅ¿e bee thoughte, but that they are repleniÅ¿hed with muche wytte and wyÅ¿edome, Å¿eeynge they are ordayned not by the deuyÅ¿e of one man alone, or of a hundrethe wiÅ¿e counÅ¿ellers onelye, but of mo then three hundreth choÅ¿en menne,
much agreeinge with the number of the auncient Å¿enatoures of Roome: as they that know the faÅ¿hion of the Parliament of Englande, and the order and maner of callyng the Å¿ame together are hable more diÅ¿tinctly to declare. And if it fortune theÅ¿e Å¿tatutes beeinge deuyÅ¿ed with Å¿uche greate Å¿olemnitie and witte, not to fal out Å¿o effectuallye as the intent of the makers dyd wyÅ¿he, they may be quicklye refourmed, but not wythout the aÅ¿Å¿ent of the commens and Å¿tates of the realme, by whoÅ¿e autoritie they were firÅ¿t deuyÅ¿ed. Thus moÅ¿te woorthy Prince you do plainlye vnderÅ¿tande all the kyndes of the lawes of Englande.

And touching theire qualities, as whether they be good or not, you Å¿halbee able to meaÅ¿ure that aÅ¿wel by your owne witte, as by comparinge them with other lawes. And when ye Å¿hall finde none in the whole worlde of lyke excellency, you muÅ¿t of force grant them to bee not onely good, but alÅ¿o on youre behalfe moÅ¿t to bee embraced.

STatuta tunc Anglorum, bona Å¿int nec ne Å¿olum reÅ¿tat explorandum. Non enim emanant illa a principis Å¿olum voluÌtate vt leges in regnis quae tantum regaliter gubernaÌtur, vbi quaÌ do
que Å¿tatuta ita coÌ Å¿titueÌtis êcuraÌt coÌ moduÌ Å¿ingulare, qdâ in eiê° Å¿ubditoruÌ ipÌa reduÌdaÌt diÅ¿peÌdiuÌ et iacturam QuaÌdo
que etiaÌ iÌ aduertentia principuÌ huiuÅ¿modi, et Å¿ibi conÅ¿ulentium inertia, ipÅ¿a tam inconÅ¿ultÃ¨ eduÌtur
quod corruptelarum nomina potius quam legum, illa merentur. Sed non Å¿ic Angliae Å¿tatuta oriri poÅ¿Å¿unt, dum nedum priÌ cipis voluÌtate, Å¿ed et totius regni aÅ¿Å¿enÅ¿u ipÅ¿a conduÌ tur, quo populi le Å¿uram illa efficere nequeunt, vel noÌ eorum comodum procurare. Prudentia etiam & Å¿apientia, neceÅ¿Å¿ario ipÅ¿a eÅ¿Å¿e referta putandum eÅ¿t, duÌ non vnius, aut ceÌ tum Å¿olum conÅ¿ultorum virorum prudentia, Å¿ed pluÅ¿quam trecentorum electorum hominum
quali numero oliÌ Å¿enatus Romano rum regebatur, ipÅ¿a edita Å¿uÌt, vt hij qui parliamenti Angliae formaÌ, coÌ uocationis quo
que eius ordinem, & modum noueruÌt hec diÅ¿tinctius referre noruÌt. Et Å¿i Å¿tatuta hec, tanta Å¿oleÌnitate & prudentia edita, efficaciae tantae quantae coÌditoruÌ cupiebat intentio, non eÅ¿Å¿e coÌtingant: coÌcito reformari ipÅ¿a poÅ¿Å¿unt, et noÌ Å¿ine coÌ munitatis & proceruÌ regni illius aÅ¿Å¿eÌÅ¿u; quali ipÅ¿a primitus emanarunt. pateÌt igitur iaÌ tibi princeps, leguÌ angloruÌ Å¿pecies oeÌs,
earum quo
que qualitates, vt Å¿i bonae ipÅ¿ae Å¿int, metiri tupoteris prudentia tua, comparatione etiam aliarum legum, & cum nullam tantae preÅ¿tantiae in orbe reperies, eas nedum bonas, Å¿ed tibi optabiliÅ¿Å¿imas fore neceÅ¿Å¿ario confiteberis.

div.head: Â¶Heare he deuyÅ¿eth a meane howe to knowe the diuerÅ¿itie betwene the Ciuile lawes and the lawes of England. Chap. 19.

div.p:
ONe only doubt wherwt your mind is troubled, remaineth now behiÌde vndiÅ¿cuÅ¿Å¿ed. And yt is this. Whether as yt ciuile lawz, Å¿o likwiÅ¿e ye lawz of
Englande bee fruytfull and effectuall, theÅ¿e for the royalme of England as the other for the Empiere, and whether they may worthely bee iudged fytte and meete. CompariÅ¿ons, moÅ¿t noble prince (as I remember I harde you ones Å¿aye) are compted odious. Wherefore I am lothe to meddle wt them. But whether they bee bothe of lyke worthines, or that the one deÅ¿eruethe an higher commendation then the other heareof you may gather a pythier argument out of thoÅ¿e pointes, wherein theire Å¿entences do differ then by my declaracion. For wher both the lawez doo agree, the prayÅ¿e of them ys equall.

But in caÅ¿es where they diÅ¿agree, the worthyer lawe is moÅ¿te prayÅ¿e-woorthye. Wherefore wee will nowe propound Å¿ome Å¿uch caÅ¿es, to the intent you maye indifferentlye ponder and weye whether of theÅ¿e doothe moÅ¿te iuÅ¿tlye and better define the Å¿ame. And firÅ¿t wee will putte furthe exaumples of caÅ¿es of much weight.

SOlum iam vnuÌ de his quibus agitatur animus tu us reÅ¿tat explanaÌ duÌ, vz an vt Ciuiles, ita et ang. leges
frugi Å¿int et efficaces, iÅ¿ti Angliae regno, vt illae imperio, etiam et accomode iudicari me reantur. Comparationes vero priÌ ceps, vt te aliquan do dixiÅ¿Å¿e recolo odioÅ¿ae reputantur, quo eas aggredi non delector, tu an equalis Å¿int ambae leges meriti, vnaue altera celÅ¿ius preconium mereatur, non ex meo iuditio, Å¿ed ex his in quibus earum differunt Å¿ententiae, efficatius carpere poteris argumentum. Nam vbi coÌ ueniunt Leges ambae, aequalis laudis ipÅ¿ae Å¿unt,
Å¿ed in caÅ¿ibus vbi ipÅ¿ae diÅ¿Å¿entiunt, preÅ¿tantioris legis preconia digna penÅ¿atione refulgent. Quare caÅ¿us huiuÅ¿modi aliquos iam in medium proferemus vt quae legum illarum eos iuÅ¿tius meliuÅ¿
que diffiniat, equa lance valeas ponderare, et primo ex caÅ¿ibê° maximi poÌderis exeÌpla preponamus.

div.head: Â¶The firÅ¿t caÅ¿e wherin the Ciuile lawes, and the lawes of England do differ. Ca. 20

div.p:
IF they that haue a matter of coÌtrouerÅ¿ie depending before a Iuge coÌe to ye coÌteÅ¿tation of the Å¿uite vpon the matter of ye deed which ye lawyers of England call ye iÅ¿Å¿u of ye plea:
the truth of Å¿uch an iÅ¿Å¿ue by the ciuile lawes muÅ¿t be tryed by the depoÅ¿ition of witneÅ¿Å¿es, wherein .ii. allowable witneÅ¿Å¿es are Å¿ufficieÌt. But by ye lawes of England the truthe of the matter cannot appier euident to the Iuge wtout ye othes of xii. men neighbours to the place where Å¿uch a dede is Å¿uppoÅ¿ed to be done. Nowe therefore the queÅ¿tioÌ is whether of theÅ¿e two, Å¿o dyuers procedinges ought to be eÅ¿teemed more reaÅ¿onable & effectual for the opening of the trueth, which thus is Å¿ought for. For the law yt can more certeinly & better Å¿hewe the truthe, is in this behalfe of more excellency than ye other yt is of leÅ¿Å¿e efficacy & force. wherfore in the Å¿earche of this matter thus we proceede.

SIcoram Iudice coÌtendeÌtes, ad litis êueniant conteÅ¿tationeÌ Å¿uê materia facti, quaÌ legis Angliae periti exituÌ plâiti appellâ. Exitus hmÌoi veritas
ê leges Ciuiles teÅ¿tiuÌ depoÅ¿itioneÌ êbari debet, iÌ qua duo teÅ¿tes idonei Å¿ufficiunt, Sed per leges Angliae, veritas illa noÌ niÅ¿i .xij. hominuÌ de vicineto vbi factuÌ huiuÅ¿modi Å¿uponitur Å¿acrameÌto, Iudici conÅ¿tari poterit. Queritur igitur, quis horuÌ duoruÌ êceÅ¿Å¿uuÌ taÌ diuerÅ¿oruÌ rationabilior cenÅ¿eri debeat & efficatior, ad veritateÌ quae Å¿ic queriturreuelaÌdaÌ. Quia lex qÌ eaÌ certiê° meliuÅ¿
que oÅ¿teÌdere poteÅ¿t, preÅ¿tantior in hoc eÅ¿t lege altera quae noÌ taÌtae efficatiae eÅ¿t et virtutis, quare in huius rei indagine Å¿ic êcedimus.

div.head: Â¶Here are Å¿et â¢ urth the inconueniences proceding of the law, which no otherwiÅ¿e then by witneÅ¿Å¿es admitteth trials. Cap. 21.

div.p: BY the Ciuile lawes ye party which in ye iÅ¿Å¿ue holdethe the affirmatiue muÅ¿t briÌg furth witneÅ¿Å¿ez which he himÅ¿elfe at hys own pleaÅ¿ure Å¿hall name But the negatiue cannot be proued directli, though indirectly it may: For the hability of him is thought to be very Å¿mal & weake, and his witte much leÅ¿Å¿e, which among al the men that he knoweth is not able to fynde ii. Å¿o voide of conÅ¿cience & trueth, which for dreade, loue or profit will not bee readye to gaineÅ¿aye all truthe.
Suche then maye he produce for witneÅ¿Å¿es on hys Å¿yde.

And if the other partye would obiect any thinge againÅ¿t them, or their Å¿aienges, it chanceth not euer yt they & their condicions & doinges are knoweÌ to ye contrarie partye: Å¿o yt by reaÅ¿on of theire foule lifes & vicious behauiour Å¿uch witneÅ¿Å¿es might bee reprooued. And while their Å¿aienges coÌteine the affirmatiue, it Å¿halbe very harde to reproue them by circuÌÅ¿tances or any other indirect meanz. who then Å¿halbe hable to liue in Å¿uertie of his goodes or of himÅ¿elfe vnder Å¿uche a law, ye miniÅ¿treth Å¿uch aid to euery buÅ¿y body yt luÅ¿teth to trouble another? And what ii. wicked men are Å¿o vnwarie & vncircuÌ Å¿pect, which touching the deede wherof they Å¿halbe examined in iudgement,
will not beefore they are called furth for witneÅ¿Å¿es Å¿ecreatly imagine and deuiÅ¿e a fourme & faÅ¿Å¿ioÌ therof, & frame thereunto all circumÅ¿tances euen Å¿uche as muÅ¿t needes haue ben Å¿o, if ye thing had ben true in dede? For ye children of this world (Å¿aith ye lorde) are wiÅ¿er then ye children of light. So ye moÅ¿t wicked IeÅ¿abel brought furth ii. witneÅ¿Å¿es of ye children of Beliall in iudgement agaiÌÅ¿t Nabot, wherby he loÅ¿t his life, & king Achab her huÅ¿bande obtayned the poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ion of ye vyneyarde. So the moÅ¿t chaÅ¿te matrone SuÅ¿aÌna Å¿hould haue dyed for aduoutrye by the wytnes of twoe olde dotardes being iudges, if the lorde hadde not meruelouÅ¿lye deliuered
her by a wonderfull feate of prudence, which of nature the yong child hadde not being yet vnder age. And though ye Å¿ame child by theire altering & doubling in their depoÅ¿itions did coÌuict them to be falÅ¿e wretches, yet whoe (Å¿aue only the lord) could haue knowen that in their Å¿aienges they woulde thus haue diÅ¿agreed? Seeinge there was no lawe ye did moue theÌ to haue in remeÌ brance what kind of tree it was, wherunder ye fact was Å¿uppoÅ¿ed to be done. For the witneÅ¿Å¿es of euerye wicked deede are not thought to conÅ¿ider al circuÌÅ¿taunces apperteining to ye Å¿ame, beiÌg Å¿uch as do nothiÌg help to ye aggrauatioÌ & detectioÌ of ye faulte.
But while thoÅ¿e wycked iudges willinglye Å¿wearing did alter touching ye kindes of the trees, theire owne wordes proued theÌ to be falÅ¿e verlets. Wherfore thei worthely Å¿uffred the Å¿ame puniÅ¿hemeÌt theÌ Å¿elues. You alÅ¿o moÅ¿t gratious priÌce do know how yt lately maiÅ¿ter I. Fring after yt he had continued three yeares in the order of priÅ¿tehoode was compelled by the depoÅ¿ition of twoe wicked perÅ¿ones whiche witneÅ¿Å¿ed that he had before he was made prieÅ¿te betrouthed hymÅ¿elfe to a certeine yonge woman, to forÅ¿ake the holye order of prieÅ¿tehoode, and to marrye the Å¿ame womanne. Wythe whome when hee hadde lyued fourtene yeares,
and hadde beegotten .viiâª children of her, at ye laÅ¿te beeinge conuicted of treaÅ¿on conÅ¿pired againÅ¿te your highnes, hee confeÅ¿Å¿ed before all the people euen at the very point of deathe that thoÅ¿e witneÅ¿Å¿es were hiered, and that theire depoÅ¿itions were falÅ¿e. And thus manye tymes are iudgemeÌtz peruerted by the meane of falÅ¿e witneÅ¿Å¿es, yea & that vnder the verye beÅ¿t Iudges as vnto you it is not vnhearde, nor to the worlde vnknowen, while this wickednes (the more is the pitie) is often committed.

PEr leges ciuiles pars, quae in litis conteÅ¿tatione affirmatiuaÌ dicit, teÅ¿tes êducere debet, quos ipÅ¿emet ad libituÌ Å¿uuÌ nominabit. Negatiua auteÌ êbari noÌ poteÅ¿t, vz directÃ¨, licet poÅ¿Å¿it ê obliquuÌ. Exilis quippe creditâ eÅ¿Å¿e poteÌtiae minoris quo
que induÅ¿triae, qui de omnibus quos noÅ¿cit hoiÌbê°, duos repire nequit ita coÌÅ¿cieÌ tia & veritate vacuos, vt timore, amore, vel comodâ oiÌ velint coÌtraire veritâ. Hos poteÅ¿t tuÌc ipÅ¿e iÌ teÅ¿timÌ ê ducere iÌ cauÅ¿a Å¿ua
et ãâã contra eos pars altera dicere velit, vel coÌtra eorum dicta, noÌ Å¿eÌê coÌtinget, eos eoruÌ quo
que mores aut facta, apud coÌtradicere volenteÌ agnoÅ¿ci, vt ex eoruÌ feditate et viciis teÅ¿tes illi poÅ¿Å¿iÌt reêbari. Et duÌ eoruÌ dicta affirmatiuaÌ coÌtineaÌt, noÌ facile poteruÌt illa, ê circuÌÅ¿taÌtias aut obliqua alia im êbari. Quis tuÌc poterit Å¿uoruÌ aut Å¿ui ipÅ¿iê°, Å¿ub lege tali viuere Å¿ecurus, duÌ cuilibet Å¿ibi inimicari voleÌti lex tale preÅ¿tat Å¿ubÅ¿idiuÌ? noÌ antequaÌ in teÅ¿tes êducaÌtur, occulte fingaÌt imagineÌ et figuram, coÌ ponaÌt quo
que eideÌ omnes circumÅ¿taÌ tias, quales Å¿ibi affuiÅ¿Å¿ent, Å¿i illud in veritate coÌÅ¿titiÅ¿Å¿et PrudeÌtiores naÌ
que vt dicit dominus Å¿unt filij huius muÌ di, quam filij lucis Sic IeÅ¿abel Å¿celera tiÅ¿Å¿ima, teÅ¿tes duos filios belial, coÌtra Nabot in iuditio produxit, quÃ´ ipÅ¿e vitam perdidit, et Achab rex eius vineam poÅ¿Å¿idebat. Sic duorum Å¿enuÌ etiam Iudicum teÅ¿timonio, mortua fuiÅ¿Å¿et pro adulte riovxor caÅ¿tiÅ¿Å¿ima SuÅ¿anna, Å¿i non
eaÌ miraculoÅ¿e liberaÅ¿Å¿et dnÌs inexcogitabili prudeÌtia, quam a natura noÌ habuit puer iunior noÌduÌ etate êuectus. Et Å¿i ipÅ¿os depoÅ¿itionÌ Å¿ua varia coÌuicerat puer ille eÅ¿Å¿e falÅ¿arios, quis niÅ¿i Å¿oluÌ dnÌs nouiÅ¿Å¿e poterat eos in dictis Å¿uis taliter variaturos? duÌ non de arboris natura Å¿ub qua imputatuÌ facinus fie bat, lex aliqua eos artabat reminiÅ¿ci. Quia teÅ¿tes Å¿celeris cuiuÅ¿
que , coÌÅ¿iderare noÌ putaÌtâ oiÌa vmbracula & cetera vicina illi facto, qÌ ad aggrauati oneÌ vel detectionÌ criminis illius minime operantur,
Sed duÌ de arboruÌ Å¿peciebê°, iudices illi nequaÌ vltro deponeÌtes variabaÌtâª eorum dicta ipÅ¿os veritatis fuiÅ¿Å¿e preuaricatores demoÌ Å¿trabaÌt, quÃ´ et talionis penaÌ merito incurreruÌt. NoÅ¿ti et tu princeps diuine qualiteriam tarde, magiÅ¿ter IohaÌnes Fringe, qui poÅ¿tquaÌ annis tribê° Å¿acerdotali fuÌctus eÅ¿t officio, duobus iniquoruÌ depoÅ¿itione, qui euÌ aÌtea iuueÌculaÌ quaÌ daÌ affidaÅ¿Å¿e teÅ¿tati Å¿uÌt, Å¿acruÌ preÅ¿biteratê° ordineÌ reliÌqÌre coÌpulÅ¿ê° eÅ¿t, et matrimoniuÌ cuÌ femina illa coÌÅ¿umare. CuÌ qua, poÅ¿tquaÌ annis .xiiij. moratê°
Å¿obolem Å¿eptimaÌ Å¿uÅ¿citauerat, demum de crimine laeÅ¿e maieÅ¿tatis in tuam celÅ¿itudineÌ coniurato conuictus, Å¿ubornatos fuiÅ¿Å¿e teÅ¿tes illos, et falÅ¿um dixiÅ¿Å¿e teÅ¿timonium, in mortis Å¿uae articulo coram omni populo faÅ¿Å¿us eÅ¿t. Qualiter et Å¿epe peruerti iudicia, falÅ¿orum teÅ¿tium medio, etiam Å¿ub optimis iudicibus, noÌ eÅ¿t tibi inauditum nec incognitum mundo, dum Å¿celus illud (prohdolor) creberime committatur.

div.head: Â¶Of the crueltie of rackinges. Cap. 22

div.p: THerefore the law of Fraunce in offences criminall whereupoÌ deth dependeth is not conteÌt to conuict the party accuÅ¿ed by witneÅ¿Å¿es, leaÅ¿t by the teÅ¿timony of falÅ¿e perÅ¿ons innocent blood Å¿hould be condeÌned. But that lawe chooÅ¿eth rather to tormeÌt Å¿uch offeÌders wt racking, vntill they theÌÅ¿elues confeÅ¿Å¿e their owne fault, rather then by ye depoÅ¿ition of witneÅ¿Å¿es, which mani tymes through wicked affeccions, & Å¿ometimes by ye Å¿ubornation of euil meÌ, are moued to êiurie. VpoÌ this & Å¿uche like cautels & reÅ¿pectes offeÌdours & Å¿uÅ¿pect êÅ¿ons are in that royalme wt Å¿o many kynds of rackynges tourmeÌted that my penne abhorreth to put theÌ in writting.

For Å¿ome are Å¿tretched our vpon a horÅ¿e in Å¿uche wiÅ¿e that theire Å¿ynowes breake, and theyre veines gouÅ¿heout with Å¿treames of bloude. Agayne other Å¿ome haue dyuers greate weightez hanged at their feete: whereby their limmes and ioyntes are diÅ¿Å¿olued and vnlooÅ¿ed.

Some alÅ¿o haue theire mouthes Å¿o long gagged open, till Å¿uch abundance of water bee powered in that theire holly Å¿welleth lyke a hill or a tonne, to the intent that then the bellye being perÅ¿ed with Å¿ome boring inÅ¿trument, the water may yÅ¿Å¿ue and Å¿poute out thereat and at the mouth Å¿treame wiÅ¿e, not much vnlike a whale
which when he hath Å¿upped vppe and Å¿wallowed downe a great quantitye of Å¿ea water, with herringes and other Å¿mall fiÅ¿hez, guÅ¿heth out ye Å¿ame water againe as high as the toppe of anye Pyneapple tree. My penne is both weary & aÅ¿hamed to rehearÅ¿e the outragiouÅ¿nes of torments deuiÅ¿ed iÌ this behalf. For the number of them is Å¿o greate, that it can Å¿cant well bee noted in a whole Å¿kinne of parchement. More ouer the Ciuile lawes for want of witneÅ¿Å¿es doe fetche out the truthe by Å¿uche rackinges. And Å¿o doe dyuers other Countries too. But whoe is Å¿o harde harted, whiche beynge once releaÅ¿ed out of Å¿o cruell a Racke,
thoughe he bee innocent and fautles, woulde not yet rather accuÅ¿e himÅ¿elfe of all kindes of offences, then agayne to commytt himÅ¿elfe to the intollerable crueltie of the tourment ones proued: and hadde not rather dye at ones (Å¿eeinge deathe ys the ende of all miÅ¿eries) then Å¿o often to be kylled, and to Å¿uÅ¿taine Å¿o manye hellyÅ¿he furies, paynfuller then death it Å¿elfe?

And didde not you moÅ¿te worthye prince knowe a certeine offendour which in Å¿uche tourmentes accuÅ¿ed a woorÅ¿hipfull, yea a ryghte good and faythfull knighte of treaÅ¿on, wherein, as hee Å¿aide they twoe hadde coÌ Å¿pired together,
which treaÅ¿on he himÅ¿elf beynge releaÅ¿ed from the racke, afterward attempted and accoÌpliÅ¿hed, therby to acquite himÅ¿elf froÌ comynge to the torture agayne. But at the laÅ¿t by meane of thoÅ¿e tourmeÌts beinge Å¿o meamed in his bodie, that therby he was brought in deÅ¿paire of his lyfe and therupon receauynge his howÅ¿ell, he theÌ Å¿wore by ye Å¿ame bodie of the lord, &, by the deathe whiche he beleeued that he Å¿hould furthwith dye, that the Å¿aid knight was innocent and gilties in all thinges whereof he had accuÅ¿ed hiÌ, howbeit the paines wheriÌ he was at the tyme of that his accuÅ¿acion he Å¿aid were Å¿o extreame, that rather theÌ
he woulde feele the Å¿ame agaiÌe, he would no Å¿ticke to accuÅ¿e the Å¿aid knight agayne, yea & his owne father to. This he Å¿aid beynge then at ye verie poiÌt of deathe, whiche he beleued he could not then eÅ¿cape. No nor he eÅ¿caped not the deathe whiche he then feared. But afterward beynge hanged, at the tyme of his deathe he cleared the Å¿aid knight of all crimes wherof before he had defamed hiÌ. Thus (o pitifull caÅ¿e) do many other wretcheis not for ye truethes Å¿ake, but forced thereunto by the extremitie of tourmentes, And what certentie then can ariÅ¿e of the confeÅ¿Å¿ions of miÅ¿erable tourmeÌted perÅ¿ons. But if Å¿ome innoceÌt bodie hauynge his mynd fixed
vpon eternall Å¿aluation, woulde in Å¿uch a Babylonicall fornace with the iii. childreÌ bleÅ¿Å¿e & magnifie the lorde, and not lye to the damnation of his owne Å¿oule, in ye ye iudge pronounceth him vngiltie, doth not that iudge by the Å¿elfe Å¿ame iudgement iudge himÅ¿elf giltie of all the crueltie & paiÌes wherewith he hathe tourmented the innocent. O howe cruel is Å¿uch a law whiche in that it can not condempne the Å¿yelie innocent, condempneth the iudge. Suerly Å¿uche a cuÅ¿tom is not to be accompted a lawe, but rather the hieghe waye to the deuill O iudge, in what Å¿chole haÅ¿t thou learned to be preÅ¿ent, while the offendour is tourmented?
For the execution of iudgements vpoÌ offeÌdours ought to be doÌe by meÌ of baÅ¿e degre: ye doers wherof doo purchaÅ¿e to themÅ¿elfes preÅ¿ent infamie by the deede doynge, in Å¿omuch that euer after they are diÅ¿habled from the pÌ ferment of a iudge. Neither dothe the lorde god execute his iudgementes pronounced ageynÅ¿t the dampned by angells, but by deuylls. Yea and in Purgatorie the Å¿oules there remayniÌge, though they be predeÅ¿tinate too glorie, yett are they not tourmented of good angells, but of euyll. ThoÅ¿e alÅ¿o are euyll and wycked men by whome the lorde in this worlde doth miniÅ¿ter to wretched Å¿inners
deÅ¿erued puniÅ¿hemÌt For when god Å¿aid iÌ the xxii. chapter of the third booke of Kynges: Who Å¿hall deceaue Achab. it was an euill Å¿pirite that aunÅ¿wered: I will be a lying Å¿pirite in ye mouth of all his prophetes. For it becomed not a good Å¿pirite to take vpon him the executioÌ of Å¿uche thinges thoughe this iudgement proceeded from the lorde that Achab Å¿houlde be deceued by a lye. But the iudge peraduenture wyll Å¿aye: I withe myne own handes did nothinge in theÅ¿e tourmentes But what differth it whether one be a doer wt his ownÌ handes, or ells be preÅ¿ent at the doynge, and the
thinge that is done to exaÅ¿perate hit by his commaundement. It is onely the maiÅ¿ter of the Å¿hippe that bringeth it to ye haueÌ, though by his coÌmauÌ dement an other bee the Å¿tireÅ¿man I beleue that the wouÌde wherewith ye mynde of the iudge thus tourmentinge any man is plaged, wyll neuer be healed ageyne Å¿pecially while he remembreth the extremitie of ye paines Å¿uÅ¿teyned by the poore wretche iÌ thoÅ¿e miÅ¿erable tourments

NOn igitur coÌ tenta eÅ¿t lex Francie, in criminalibus vbi mor â¢ imminet, reuÌ teÅ¿tibus coÌuincere, ne falÅ¿idicorum teÅ¿timonio Å¿anguis in nocens condeÌnotur. Sed mauult lex illa reos tales torturis cruciari, quouÅ¿
que ipÅ¿i eoruÌ reatum confiteantur, quaÌ teÅ¿tiuÌ depoÅ¿itione, qui Å¿epe paÅ¿Å¿ionibus iÌiquis, & quando
que Å¿ubornatione maloruÌ ad êiuria Å¿timulaÌtâ. Quali cautione & aÅ¿tutia, criminoÅ¿i etiaÌ & de criminibê° Å¿uÅ¿pectitot torturaruÌ iÌ regno illo generibê° affliguntur, quod faÅ¿tidet calamê° ea literis deÅ¿ignare.
Quidam vero in equuleis extenduntur, quÃ´ eorum rumpuntur nerui, et venae in Å¿anguinis fluenta prorumpuÌt. Quorundam vero, diuerÅ¿orum ponderum pendulis diÅ¿Å¿oluuntur compagines et iuncturae, et quorundam gaggantur ora, vÅ¿que dum ê illa, tot aquarum infundantur fluenta, vt ipÅ¿orum venter montis tumeÅ¿cat more, quo tunc venter ille foÅ¿Å¿orio vel Å¿imili percuÅ¿Å¿us inÅ¿trumento, per os aquam illaÌ euomet ad inÅ¿tar Balenae
que cum halecibê° et aliis piÅ¿ciculis mare abÅ¿orbuit, aquam deÅ¿pumat, ad altitudinem arboris pini. Piget (proh pudor) iam penna exqueÅ¿itorum ad hec cruciatuuÌ enarrare immania. Wherfore concernynge lordeÅ¿hippes and other poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ions rueled by the ciuile lawe and in all accions fallynge vnder the Å¿ame lawe the actions of the plaintifes for wante of witneÅ¿Å¿es many tymes are choked, Å¿o that Å¿kant the halfe parte of them atteyneth to the deÅ¿iered ende. What maner of
lawe then is this whiche to them ye Å¿uÅ¿teyne wroÌg thus faileth in yeeldinge IuÅ¿tice? I doubt whether it deÅ¿erue too bee called a iuÅ¿te lawe, becauÅ¿e in the Å¿ame lawe it is wryten, that IuÅ¿tice rendreth too euerye maÌ that which is his owne. But this cannot Å¿uch a lawe doo.

div.head: Here hee declareth how counties are deuided, and Å¿hieri â¢ ffs choÅ¿en.

div.p:
Now that we haue opened after what maner the Ciuile lawes do enfourme a iudge of the truthe of a matter brought into iudgement, it is conÅ¿equent to declare by what meanes the lawes of Englande doo boult out the trueth of Å¿uche a matter. For the
orders of bothe the lawez beynge layde together, the qualities of theÌ bothe wyll more playnely appere: forÅ¿omuche as the philoÅ¿opher Å¿ayeth that contraries placed one by an other wyll Å¿hewe theÌ Å¿elfes more euidently. But herein after the maner of oratours in Å¿teade of a proheme, it Å¿hall not bee amyÅ¿Å¿e that we open certen thinges before, the knowlege whereof Å¿hall geue light too thinges whiche heareafter Å¿hall come in talke wherefore thus we doo proceede. The royalme of Englande is deuided into counties, as the royalme of Fraunce is into Baylywyks, Å¿o that in Englande ther is no place
that is not with in the bodie of Å¿ome countie. CouÌ ties alÅ¿o are deuided into huÌdreds which Å¿oÌe wher are called wapentages. And hundredes are deuided into villages vnder which appellation are coÌ teyned borowes and Cities. For the boundes of villages are not conteyned within the circuit of walles, buyldynges, or Å¿treetes, but within the compaÅ¿Å¿e of fildes, greate territories, certein hamlettes, and many other, as of wat
er s, woodes & waÅ¿te grouÌdes, whiche it is not needefull nowe to Å¿et furthe by their names: becauÅ¿e that in England there is Å¿kante any place, which is not conteined within the coÌ paÅ¿Å¿e
of villageis, though certeyn priuileged places within villageis are Å¿uppoÅ¿ed to be no parcell of ye Å¿ame villages, More ouer in euerie couÌtie ther is one certeyn officer called the kynges Å¿hierief, which amonge other duties belongynge to his office, putteth in execucion all the commaundementes, and iudgements of the kynges courte, that are to be executed within his countie His office endureth but for one yeare, Å¿o that after the expiratioÌ of that yeare, he may not miniÅ¿ter in that office. Neither Å¿hall he within ii. yeares next enÅ¿ueynge be admited to ye
office agayne. This officer is thus choÅ¿en. Euery yeare the morrowe after All Å¿oullen daye all the kynges counÅ¿ellers meet together in the kynges exchequer, aÅ¿wel ye lordes Å¿pirituall and temporall as all other IuÅ¿tices, all the barones of the exchequer, the maiÅ¿ter of the rolles, and certeyn other officers, where all theÅ¿e with one commen aÅ¿Å¿ent doo name of euerie countie iii. knightes or eÅ¿quyers, whome amonge other of the Å¿ame countie they take to bee of good diÅ¿poÅ¿itioÌ and fame, and beÅ¿t diÅ¿poÅ¿ed to the office of the Å¿hiereif of that couÌ tie. Of the whiche iii. the kynge chooÅ¿eth one,
whome by his letters patents he appointeth Å¿herief of the countie that he is choÅ¿en of for the yeare then folowinge. But he before hee receaue his patent Å¿hall Å¿were vpoÌ ye holye ghoÅ¿pell amonge other articles, that he Å¿hall well and faithfully and indifferently exerciÅ¿e and doo his office all that yeare, and that he Å¿hall receaue or take nothyng of any other man then the Kynge, by colour or meane of his office.
TheÅ¿e thynges beynge thus nowe preÅ¿uppoÅ¿ed, lett vs proceede too the Å¿earche of thoÅ¿e thinges, that we Å¿eke for.

Villarum etenim metae, non muris, edificiis, aut Å¿tratis terminan tur, Å¿ed agroruÌ ambitubus, territoriis magnis, hamiletis quibuÅ¿daÌ, et multis aliis, Å¿icut aquaruÌ, boÅ¿coruÌ, et vaÅ¿toruÌ terminis, quae iam non expedit nominibus deÅ¿ignare, qÌa vix in anglia eÅ¿t locus aliquis,

div.head: Howe Iurers muÅ¿t be choÅ¿en and Å¿worne

div.p:
AS ofte as Å¿uters in the courtes of the kynge of Englande are come to ye iÅ¿Å¿ue of their plea vpon ye mater of the facte, furthwith the IuÅ¿tices by vertue of the kynges wrytte directed vnto the Å¿hirief of the countie, wherein ye deede is Å¿uppoÅ¿ed to be done, wyll him to cauÅ¿e to come before the Å¿ame IuÅ¿ticeis at a certein day by them limitted xii good and lawfull men neighbours to the place where the facte is Å¿uppoÅ¿ed to be done: the Å¿ame to be Å¿uch as be of no kynne to either of the pleaders, to the ende that by ther oths it maye certeynly be knoweÌ, whether ye deede wer done as the one partie affirmeth,
or ells as the other partye denyeth. Vppon the daye aforeÅ¿ayde the Å¿hieref Å¿hall retourne the Å¿aid wrytte before the Å¿ame IuÅ¿tices, together with the pannell of their names, which he hereunto hath Å¿ommoned. WheÌ they are come either partie may refuÅ¿e them, allegyng that the Å¿hierief hathe made that pannell fauorably for the other partye of perÅ¿ones not in different. Whiche exception if it be founde treue by the othe of ii men of the Å¿ame pannell choÅ¿en thereunto by the IuÅ¿tyceis, that pannell Å¿hall immediatly be quaÅ¿Å¿ed And then ye IuÅ¿tices Å¿hall
wryte to the coroners of the Å¿ame couÌtie that they Å¿hall make a newe painell. Whiche when thei haue doÌe if it be likewiÅ¿e fouÌde fautie, it Å¿hall alÅ¿o be quaÅ¿Å¿ed. And then the IuÅ¿tices Å¿hall elect and chooÅ¿e ii of the clerkes of the Å¿ame courte, or other of the Å¿ame couÌtie, which in the preÅ¿eÌce of the court vpon their othes Å¿hall make an indifferent panell, whiche by neither of the parties Å¿halbe challenged. Howbeit when the men Å¿o impanelled are come into the courte, either of the parties may make exceptions againÅ¿t the perÅ¿oÌe of anye of theÌ, as he may alÅ¿o do in all caÅ¿es & at all times wheÌ any maÌ by any meanez
impanelled Å¿hall appeare to be Å¿worne in the courte vpon the truthe of Å¿uch an iÅ¿Å¿ue: Å¿aiyng that the perÅ¿on impannelled is coÅ¿ein or allyed to ye other party or by anye kind of amity Å¿o knytte vnto him, that he is not indifferent to declare the truethe betwene them. And of theÅ¿e exceptions there are Å¿o manye kyndes and Å¿ortes, that theye can not bee in fewe woords rehearÅ¿ed. Wherof if anye one bee founde true, thenne Å¿hall not hee bee Å¿worne agaynÅ¿t whoÌ the exception is purpoÅ¿ed, but his name Å¿hallbe cancelled in the pannell. So allÅ¿o Å¿halbee done of all the names of the perÅ¿ons impannelled, vntill .xii. of theÌ Å¿o indiffereÌt be Å¿worn,
that neither party can haue againÅ¿t them any mater of exception or challenge. AlÅ¿o of theÅ¿e .xii.iiii. at the leaÅ¿t Å¿halbe of the huÌ dred where the village Å¿taÌ deth wherin the fact wher uppon the Å¿utte rieÅ¿ethe is Å¿uppoÅ¿ed to bee done. And euerie Å¿uche Iurer Å¿hall haue landes or reuenues for terme of lyfe at ye leaÅ¿t to the yearly value of xl. sÌ. And this order is obÅ¿erued & kept in al accions & cauÅ¿es criminall reall, and perÅ¿onall, Å¿auynge where the dammages or debt in accioÌs êÅ¿onal excedeth not the Å¿uÌme of .xl. markes of EngliÅ¿he moneye For thenne it is not requiÅ¿ite that Iurers in Å¿uch accyons Å¿hall bee hable to dyÅ¿pende Å¿omuche.

Yet they Å¿hall haue lande or rentes to a competente value after the diÅ¿cretion of the IuÅ¿tices. OtherwyÅ¿e theye Å¿hall not bee Å¿worne, leaÅ¿te for neede and pouertie Å¿uch Iurers myghte eaÅ¿elye bee corrupte and Å¿uborned.

And if by Å¿uche exceptions Å¿o manye Iurers names bee cancelled in the pannel that there remayneth not a Å¿ufficient number to make thereof a Iurie, theÌ ye Å¿herifes by ye kinges write Å¿halbe coÌmauÌ ded to adioin mo Iur â¢ rs. Which thing may ofte be don, Å¿o yt for lack of Iurers ye inquiÅ¿itioÌ of ye truth vpoÌ Å¿uch a plea Å¿hal not â¢ emaiÌ And this is ye fourm how Iurers and Å¿uche inquiÅ¿itours of truth ought to be choÅ¿eÌ in the kings courte.
and lykewiÅ¿e to bee Å¿worne. Wherefore how they muÅ¿te bee charged and infourmed of ye vtteryng of ye Å¿ame trueth, this nowe reÅ¿teth to be diÅ¿cuÅ¿Å¿ed.

div.head: Â¶Howe Iurers oughte to be enfourmed by euidences and witneÅ¿Å¿es. Cap. 26.

div.p:
Twelue good & lawefull meÌ beiÌg at ye laÅ¿t Å¿worne in fourme aforÅ¿aid, hauing beÅ¿ides their moueables, Å¿ufficieÌt poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ioÌs as afore is declared, wherby they may be hable to maiÌ taiÌ their own Å¿tates, & being to neither partye Å¿uÅ¿pected or hated, but neighbours to theÌ both, theÌ Å¿halbe red before theÌ in EngliÅ¿h by ye court al ye recorde & proceÅ¿Å¿e of the plea dependynge beetwene the
parties, with a plaine declaracion of the yÅ¿Å¿ue of ye plea, touchinge the trueth whereof thoÅ¿e Å¿worne meÌ Å¿hall certifie the courte. Whyche thynges beinge done eyther party by himÅ¿elfe or his couÌÅ¿ellours in the preÅ¿ence of the courte Å¿hal vtter and open to the Å¿aide Å¿worne men all and Å¿inguler maters and euidences whereby he thynkethe he may beÅ¿t informe them of the truethe of the yÅ¿Å¿ue Å¿o impleaded. And then maye eyther partie bring before the Å¿ame IuÅ¿tices and Å¿worne menne al and Å¿inguler Å¿uche witneÅ¿Å¿es on his beehalfe as hee will produce. Who by the IuÅ¿tices beeinge charged vpon the holye goÅ¿pell of godde, Å¿hal teÅ¿tifie
al thinges proouynge the truthe of the fact, whereupon the parties coÌtend And if neede Å¿o require, thoÅ¿e witneÅ¿Å¿es Å¿halbe Å¿euered and deuided til they haue depoÅ¿ed all that they wyll, Å¿o that the Å¿ayinge of one Å¿hall not mooue or prouoke an other to teÅ¿tyfye the lyke. The premiÅ¿Å¿es beeynge done, then after that thoÅ¿e Iurers haue had talke at theire pleaÅ¿ure vppon the truethe of that yÅ¿Å¿ue wythe aÅ¿muche deliberation as themÅ¿elfs Å¿hall require, in the keepynge of the miniÅ¿ters of the courte wythin a place to them for the Å¿ame purpoÅ¿e aÅ¿Å¿igned, to the intente that noe manne in the meane tyme may corrupte them, theye Å¿hall
retourne into the courte, and certyfie the IuÅ¿tices vppon the decitie of the yÅ¿Å¿ue Å¿o ioyned in the preÅ¿ence of bothe the partyes (if theye willbe there) and Å¿pecially of the plainetyfe The reporte of whiche Iurers by the lawes of Englande is called a verdycte: by the whyche woorde is mente, a true reporte, or a reporte of the truethe. And thenne accordyng to the qualitie of that veredicte the IuÅ¿tices Å¿hall frame and fourme their iudgemente. NotwitheÅ¿tandynge yf the other partye, agaynÅ¿te whom the verdycte is geeuen complayne that hee is thereby vniuÅ¿tly greeued, then the Å¿ame partye maye Å¿ue a writte of attyncte
agaynÅ¿t thoÅ¿e Iuries, and againÅ¿t the partie yt hathe preuayled. By force of whiche write if it Å¿halbee found by the othe of .xxiiij. men in fourme aforeÅ¿aide retourned elect and Å¿worne, whiche Å¿halbee men of muche greater lyuynges then the firÅ¿t Iurers were that the Å¿ame firÅ¿t Iurers haue made a falÅ¿e othe, then the bodies of ye Å¿ame fyrÅ¿te Iurers Å¿halbee committed to the kynges priÅ¿one, theire goodes Å¿hallbee confiÅ¿cate, and al their poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ions Å¿halbee Å¿eaÅ¿ed into the kinges handes. theire howÅ¿es alÅ¿o & buildynges Å¿halbee raÅ¿ed and throwne downe, there woodes felled, and theire medowe grouÌdes plowed And alÅ¿o ye Å¿ame f â¢ rÅ¿t Iurers
Å¿hal for euer after be noted for infamed perÅ¿oÌs, and Å¿hal in no place be receaued to teÅ¿tifie the truth And the partie whiche in the former plea had the ouerthrowe, Å¿halbe reÅ¿tored to all thynges whyche by occaÅ¿ion thereof he hathe loÅ¿t. Who theÌ, though he regarde not his Å¿oules healthe, yet for feare of Å¿o greate puniÅ¿hmente, and for Å¿hame of Å¿o greate infamye woulde not vppon his othe declare the trueth And if one man parauenture haue Å¿o litle reÅ¿pecte to hys honoure or eÅ¿timation, yet Å¿ome of Å¿o manye Iurers wyll not neglecte theyre owne good fame, nor wyl not thoroughe theyre owne defaulte Å¿uffre themÅ¿elfes
thus to be Å¿poyled of their goodes and poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ions. Is not this order now for the boultynge oute of the truethe better and more effectuall, then the proceÅ¿Å¿e which the Ciuile lawes do procure? Here no cauÅ¿e nor no mans ryghte quailethe throughe death, or for wante of witneÅ¿Å¿es Here are not brought f â¢ rthe vnknowen witneÅ¿Å¿es, hiered perÅ¿ons, pore men, vagaboundes, vnconÅ¿tant people or Å¿uche whoÅ¿e conditions and naughtynes is vnknowen. TheÅ¿e witneÅ¿Å¿es are neygheboures hable to lyue of theyre owne, of good name and fame of honeÅ¿te reporte, not brought into the court by the partye, but by a
worÅ¿hipfull and indifferent officer choÅ¿en, and Å¿o compelled to come before the iudge. TheÅ¿e knowe all that the witneÅ¿Å¿es are hable to depoÅ¿e, â¢ id theye knowe allÅ¿o the conÅ¿tancye and vnconÅ¿tauncye of the witneÅ¿Å¿es, and what reporte goethe vppon theÌ. And what wyll ye haue more. Doubtles there is nothynge that maye dyÅ¿cloÅ¿e the truethe of anye doubt fallynge in contention, whiche can in anye wyÅ¿e be hydde from Å¿uche Iurers, Å¿o that it be poÅ¿Å¿ible for the Å¿ame to come to mans knowledge.

Et Å¿i neceÅ¿Å¿itas exegerit, diuidentur teÅ¿tes huiuÅ¿modi, donec ipÅ¿i depoÅ¿uerint quicquid velint, ita qdâ dictum vnius, noÌ docebit aut concitabit eoruÌ aliuÌ ad conÅ¿imiliter teÅ¿tificanduÌ. reuenient illi in curiaÌ, et certificabuÌt iuÅ¿titiarios Å¿uê veritate exitus Å¿ic iuncti, in preÅ¿entia partium (Å¿i intereÅ¿Å¿e velint) et maxime peteÌtis. QuoruÌ iuratoruÌ dictuÌ, per leges Angliae veredictuÌ nuÌcupatur, et tunc Å¿ecuÌduÌ hmÌodi veredicti qualitatem iuÅ¿titiarij reddeÌt et formabuÌt iudicÌ Å¿uuÌ. Tamen Å¿i pars altera coÌtra quaÌ veredictuÌ hmÌodi prolatuÌ eÅ¿t, conqueratur Å¿e ê illud iniuÅ¿te eÅ¿Å¿e grauatuÌ, êfequi tunc poteÅ¿t pars illa verÅ¿us iuratores illos, et verÅ¿ê° parteÌ qÌ optinuit breue de attineta.
Virtute cuius, Å¿i coÌpertuÌ fuerit per Å¿acramentuÌ viginti quatuor hominuÌ, in forma pÌno
â¢ ata retornatoruÌ, electorum, et iura â¢ orum, qui multo maiora habebunt patrimonia quam iuratores primi, quod ijdem primi iuratores falÅ¿um fecerunt Å¿acrameÌ tuÌ, corpora eorundem primoruÌ iuratoruÌ priÅ¿onae regis coÌmittentur bona eoruÌ coÌfiÅ¿cabuÌtur, ac oeÌs poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿iones eorundem in manus regis capieÌtur. domus quo

extunc infames erunt, nec alicubi recipientur in teÅ¿timonium veritatis, et pars qÌ Å¿uccubuit in priori placito, reÅ¿tituetur ad omnia que ipÌe per didit occaÅ¿ione eiê° Quis tunc (etÅ¿i immemor Å¿aluti â¢ animae Å¿uae fuerit,) non formidine tantae penae, et verecundia tantae infamiae, veritateÌ noÌ diceret, Å¿ic iuratus et Å¿i vnê° forÅ¿an taÌ tus Å¿ui honoris êdigus eÅ¿Å¿e noÌ peêcerit aliqui tamen iuratoruÌ taÌtorum famaÌ Å¿uaÌ noÌ necligeÌt, ne

propria culpa Å¿ua. NoÌne iam hic ordo reuelaÌdi veritateÌ, potior et efficacior eÅ¿t, quaÌ eÅ¿t proceÅ¿Å¿us qualeÌ pariunt ciuiles leges? Non hic periunt cauÅ¿ae aut ius alicuius per morteÌ aut ob defectuÌ teÅ¿tium, noÌ hic producuntur teÅ¿tes ignoti, conducticij, pauperes, vagi, inconÅ¿taÌtes, aut quo rum conditiones vel maliciae ignoraÌ tur. Vicini Å¿unt teÅ¿tes iÅ¿ti, de propriis viuere potentes famae integrae, et opinionis illeÅ¿ae, non per partem incuriam ducti, Å¿ed ê officiariuÌ nobilem
et indiffereÌteÌ electi, et coram iudice venire compulÅ¿i. IÅ¿ti omnia Å¿ciunt qÌ teÅ¿tes deponere noruÌt et iÅ¿ti teÅ¿tium productorum agnoÅ¿cuÌt conÅ¿tantias, incoÌÅ¿taÌtiaÅ¿

div.head: Â¶Here he Å¿hewethe howe cauÅ¿es criminal are determined in Englande. Cap. 27.

div.p: BVt it is alÅ¿o neceÅ¿Å¿ary to diÅ¿cuÅ¿Å¿e how in matters criminal the laws of Englande do fetche oute the truthe that perfectlye vnderÅ¿tandinge the fourme of bothe the lawes, wee maye the more certainelye perceaue & know whether of them bothe doth more effectually diÅ¿couer the hydde truthe.

Yf anye manne accuÅ¿ed of felonye or treaÅ¿on in Englande doe at his arreignemente beefore the Iudges deny the offence, furthwithe the Å¿herife of the countie where ye deede was done Å¿hal cauÅ¿e to come before the Å¿ame iudges xxiiij. good and lawefull men dwellinge nighe toe ye village where the facte was done, Å¿uche men as
to the party accuÅ¿ed be no thing allyed: and Å¿uche as euery of theÌ hathe. C.s. of land and reuenues, to certifie the iudges vpon the truthe of the crime. Whiche at theire appearaunce the partie accuÅ¿ed maye challenge in lyke Å¿orte as in actions reall maye bee done, as afore is deÅ¿cribed. And moreouer the Å¿ame partye in fauoure of hys lyfe maye challenge fiue and thirtie menne Å¿uche as hee moÅ¿te fearethe: whyche vppon his challenge Å¿halbee cancelled in the pannel, or Å¿halbee noted wyth Å¿uch markes, that theye Å¿hall not paÅ¿Å¿e vppon hym: thoughe hee bee not hable to Å¿hewe anye cauÅ¿e of his exception and challenge.
Whoe thenne can vniuÅ¿t lye dye in Englande for anye criminall offence, Å¿eynge hee maye haue Å¿o manye helpes for the fauoure of his life, and that none maye condempne him but his neighboures, good and lawfull menne agaynÅ¿te whom hee hathe no mater of exception. In deede I woulde rather wyÅ¿he twentye euill dooers to eÅ¿cape deathe thoroughe pitie, thenne one manne to bee vniuÅ¿tlye c â¢ ndempned. And yet it is not to bee Å¿uÅ¿pected, that anye off â¢ ndoure can vnder this fourme eÅ¿cape the puniÅ¿hement of his offence, foraÅ¿muche as his lyfe and conuerÅ¿ation Å¿halbee afterwarde a terroure to them that haue thus cleared hym of the crime.
In this kynde of proceedynge there is noe crueltye or extremitie vÅ¿ed. Neither can the innocent and vnguiltye perÅ¿one be hurt in his bodye or lymmes. Wherefore hee Å¿hall not Å¿tand in feare of the Å¿clauÌ der of hys enemies, beecauÅ¿e hee Å¿hall not be racked or tormen â¢ ed at their wyll and pleaÅ¿ure.

Thus vnder this lawe a manne maye paÅ¿Å¿e his life wythe quietnes and Å¿afetie. Iudge yow therefore moÅ¿te noble prince whether of theÅ¿e lawes ye had rather choÅ¿e, if you Å¿hould liue a priuate life.

SEd quomodo iÌ criminalibus leges Angliae Å¿crutaÌ tur veritatem etiaÌ
â¢ imare per neceÅ¿Å¿arium eÅ¿t, vt et iÌ eis plenariÃ¨ agnita aÌ barum legum forma, quae earum efficacius latentem reuelat veritatem certius agnoÅ¿camus. Si reus quiÅ¿pi am de felonia aut proditione in Anglia rettatus crimen Å¿uum coram iudicibus dedicat mox vicecomes comitatus vbi facinê° illud commiÅ¿Å¿um eÅ¿t, venire faciet coram eiÅ¿dem iudicibus, viginti quatuor probos et legales hoeÌs de viceneto villae vbi illud factuÌ eÌ, qÌ retato
illi nulla affinitate attingunt, et quoruÌ quilibet ceÌ tuÌ Å¿olidatê° heÌat terrae et redditê°, ad certificaÌduÌ Iudices illos Å¿uê criminÌ illiê° veritate. Quibê° coÌ pareÌtibê°, rettatê° ille eos caluÌpniare poteÅ¿t eadeÌ forma qua iÌ actionibê° realibus fieri debere Å¿uêiê° diÅ¿cribitâ. Et iÌÅ¿up reê° ipÌe iÌ fauoreÌ vitae Å¿uae caluÌpniare poteÅ¿t triginta quiÌ
que hoiÌes, quos ipÌe maxime formidat, qÌ ad eiê° caluÌpniaÌ caÌcellabuÌtâ iÌ panello, aut Å¿ignÌ talibê° notabuÌtâ qdâ (vt verbê­ legê­ vtar) illi Å¿uê euÌ noÌ traÌÅ¿ibuÌt licet ipÌe nullaÌ cauÅ¿aÌ aÅ¿Å¿ignare Å¿ciat exceptionis Å¿eu
caluÌpniae Å¿uae. Quis tuÌc mori poÅ¿Å¿et in iquÃ¨ in Anglia pro crimine? cuÌ tot iuuamina habere ille poterit ob fauoreÌ vitae Å¿uae? et noÌ niÅ¿i vicini eius, êbi et fideles homines, verÅ¿us quos ipÅ¿e nullaÌ heÌt materiam exceptionis euÌ condeÌnare poteruÌt? mallem reuera vigiÌti facino roÅ¿os mortem pietate euadere, quaÌ iuÅ¿tuÌ vnuÌ iniuÅ¿te condempari. Nec tameÌ reuÌ quempiaÌ Å¿ub hac forma, reatus Å¿ui penam euadere poÅ¿Å¿e Å¿uÅ¿picaÌ dum eÅ¿t, dum eius vita et mores timori de â¢ ceps eruÌt eis qui euÌ Å¿ic purgarunt a crimine.
In hoc equideÌ proceÅ¿Å¿u nihil eÅ¿t crudele, nihil inhumanuÌ, nec ledi poterit innocens iÌ corpore aut membris Å¿uis quare nec formidabit ille caluÌpniam inimicorum eius quia non torquebitâ iÅ¿te ad arbitrium ipÅ¿orum. Sub hac igitur lege viuere quietum et Å¿ecurum eÅ¿t. Iudica ergo, princeps optime, qÌ legum harum tibi electiÅ¿Å¿ima foret, Å¿i tu priuatam Å¿pirares vitam.

div.head: Â¶The prince graunteth the lawes of Englande to be more commodious for the Å¿ubiectes, then the Ciuile lawes in the caÅ¿e nowe diÅ¿puted. Cap. 28.

div.p: WHereunto the prince aunÅ¿wered and Å¿ayde. I Å¿ee no harde or Å¿traunge mater, good ChauÌcelour that Å¿houlde make mee doubtefull or daungerous in the election and choyÅ¿e of the thynge that yee aÅ¿ke. For whoe woulde not rather chooÅ¿e to lyue vnder that lawe, wherevnder hee myghte lyue in Å¿ecuritye, then vnder that lawe, whych woulde Å¿ette hym naked and Å¿uccourleÅ¿Å¿e agaynÅ¿te the crueltye of hys enemyes. Verelye no manne can bee Å¿aufe in body or gooddes, whom his aduerÅ¿arye maye conuince in euerye cauÅ¿e withe twoo vnknowen wytneÅ¿Å¿es of his owne chooÅ¿ynge & bryngynge fourthe.

And thoughe a manne be not compelled by theire Å¿ayenges to dye, yet is he lyttell relieued that hath eÅ¿caped deathe, beeynge Å¿hronke in all his Å¿ynnews and lymmes, & caÅ¿t intoo a perpetuall impotencye of his bodye. And truelye into Å¿uche daunger maye the crafte of a Å¿pytefull perÅ¿on bringe anye manne that lyuethe vnder the lawe, whyche herewhile you Å¿pake of. But Å¿uche miÅ¿chiefe and inconuenience cannot be wroughte by witneÅ¿Å¿es that make theire depoÅ¿itions in the preÅ¿ence of twelue credyble menne neyghbours to the deede that is preÅ¿entlye in queÅ¿tion, and to the circumÅ¿taunces of the Å¿ame:
which alÅ¿o know the maners and condicions of ye Å¿ame witneÅ¿Å¿es, Å¿pecially if they bee nigh dwellers and knowe alÅ¿o whether they bee menne worthye to bee credited or no. And further all thoÅ¿e xii. caÌnot bee ignoraunt in thoÅ¿e thinges that were doone by & among theire neighbours. For I know more certeinelye the thinges that are doone heare in Barro where I am now remayninge, then thoÅ¿e thinges that are done in England. Neither doe I thynke that thinges can be kepte from the knowledge of a good & honeÅ¿t man being done nighe to his houÅ¿e, and almoÅ¿t vnder his noÅ¿e, bee they neuer Å¿o Å¿ecretlye doone.
But yet I maruail much why the foreÅ¿aide lawe of Englande, whiche is Å¿o good and commodious, is not commen to all the whole worlde.

CVi princeps. ArduuÌ aÌbigu uÌue CaÌcellarie, noÌ conÅ¿picio, qdâ moroÅ¿um me tutubaÌ teÌue redderet in electione rei quaÌ interrogas. NaÌ quis noÌ Å¿ub lege quaÅ¿ecuram ducere poÅ¿Å¿et vitaÌ viuere potius eligeret, quaÌ Å¿ub lege tali, Å¿ub qua inermem indefenÅ¿um
que Å¿e Å¿eÌê redderet Å¿euiciae omniuÌ inimicoruÌ eius? Vere tutus quiÅ¿quaÌ eÅ¿Å¿e noÌ poterit in corêe aut in bonis, queÌ inimicus eius (in omni cauÅ¿a) conuincere poterit teÅ¿tibê° duobus etiam ignotis, per ipÅ¿ummet electis et êductis.
Et licet quis mortem per dicta eorum Å¿ubire noÌ cogatur, parum tamen releuatur ipÅ¿e qui mortem euaÅ¿it, coÌtractione neruorum & meÌ brorum Å¿uorum, at
que corporis eius languore êpetuo. Tali reuera diÅ¿crimini impellere poteÅ¿t inimici aÅ¿tutia oeÌm homineÌ qui Å¿ub lege degit, quaÌ tu iam duduÌ explicaÅ¿ti. Sed tale maluÌ operari nequeruÌt teÅ¿tes qui depoÅ¿itiones Å¿uas faciunt, in preÅ¿entia duo decim fide dignoruÌ vicinorâ facto de quo agitâ & circuÌÅ¿tantiis eius,
qui et noÅ¿cunt eorundem teÅ¿tium mores, maxime Å¿i vicini ipÅ¿i fuerint, noÅ¿cunt etiam et Å¿i ipÅ¿i Å¿int credulirate digni. Omnes etiam duo decim â¢ ales latere omnino non poterit, quicquid actum eÅ¿t per, aut inter vicinos eorum.

NoÅ¿co namque ego certius quae iam aguntur hic in Barro vbi Å¿um modo conuerÅ¿atus, quam quae iÌ Anglia fiuÌt. Nec effugere poÅ¿Å¿e pu
â¢ o noticiam probi viri ea quae aguÌ tur, licet quo daÌmÌo occultÃ¨, prope domicilium eius.
Sed tuÌ cur predicta lex Angliae, quae tam frugi et optabilis eÅ¿t, noÌ eÅ¿t toti mundo communis, vehementer admiror.

div.head: Â¶VVhy inqueÅ¿tes are not made by iuries of .xii. men in other roialmes aÅ¿wel as in Englande. Cap. 29

div.p: YOur highnes came very yonge out of EnglaÌd (quod the chauncellour,) Å¿o that the diÅ¿poÅ¿icion and qualitie of that lande is vnknowen vnto you.

Whiche if ye know, and Å¿houlde compare therewith the commodities and qualities of other countreis, you would nothinge maruaile at theÅ¿e thinges, whyche nowe do trouble youre mynde.
In deede Englande is Å¿o fertile and fruitfull, that comparinge quantitie to quantitie, it Å¿urmounteth all other landes in fruitfulnes. Yea it bringeth furthe fruit of it Å¿elf Å¿kant prouoked by mans induÅ¿trie and laboure.

For there the landes the fieldes, the groues and the woodes doe Å¿o abundauntlye Å¿pringe, that the Å¿ame vntilled do commonlye yelde to theire owners more profit then tylled, thoughe elles they be moÅ¿t fruitfull of corne and graine. There alÅ¿o are fildes of paÅ¿ture incloÅ¿ed with hedges and d â¢ tches, with trees planted and growynge vppon the Å¿ame, whiche are a defence to theire heards of Å¿heepe and cattell,
aÅ¿well agaynÅ¿t Å¿tormes, as alÅ¿o againÅ¿te the heate of the Å¿onne. And the paÅ¿tures are commonly watered, Å¿o that cattell Å¿hutte and cloÅ¿ed therein haue no neede of keping neither by daye, nor by nighte. For there bee noe wolfes, nor beares, nor Lyons. Wherefore theire Å¿heepe lye night by night in the fieldes vnkepte within their foldes, wherwith theire lande is manured. By ye meane wherof the menne of that countrey are Å¿kante troubled with anye painefull labour. Wherefore they lyue more Å¿piritually, as dyd the auncient fathers whiche dyd rather chooÅ¿e to keepe and feede cattell theÌ to diÅ¿turbe ye quietnes
of the mynde wyth the care of huÅ¿bandrye. And heereof it commeth that menne of this countreye are more apt and fitte to diÅ¿cerne in doubtfull cauÅ¿es of greate examinatioÌ and tryall, then are men whollye geeuen to moylyng in the grounde: in whome that rurall exerciÅ¿e ingendreth rudenes of witte and mynd. More ouer the Å¿ame countrey is Å¿o filled and replenyÅ¿hed with landed menne, that therein Å¿o Å¿mall a thorpe can not be founde wherein dwellethe not a knight, an eÅ¿quier, or Å¿uch a houÅ¿holder as is there commonlye called a fraÌklayne, enryched with greate poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ions: And alÅ¿o other freeholders,
and manye yomen hable for their liuelods to make a Iurie in fourme aforemencioned. For there bee in that lande dyuers yomenne whiche are able to diÅ¿pende by the yeare aboue a hundreth poundes Wherefore the Iuries afore declared are there verye ofte made, Å¿pecially in greate matters of knightes, eÅ¿quiers, and others whoÅ¿e poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ions in the whole amounteth yerely aboue the Å¿umme of fyue hundreth markes.

Wherefore it cannot bee thought that Å¿uch menne can bee Å¿uborned, or that they wyll bee periured, not onelye for that they haue beefore theire eyes the feare of God, but alÅ¿o, for that theye
haue a carefull regarde too the preÅ¿eruation of theire honoures, and to the eÅ¿chueyng of reproch, and dammage thereuppon enÅ¿uynge, and alÅ¿o that theire heires bee not impeched through theire infamye. After thys maner, O myghtye Prince are none other royalmes of the worlde dyÅ¿poÅ¿ed and inhabyted.

For thoughe there bee in them menne of greate power, of greate ryches, and poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ions, yet they dwell not one nyghe to an another as Å¿uch greate menne dooe in England. Neyther Å¿o manye inherytoures and poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿oures of lande are elÅ¿ewhere as in Englande.
For in a whole towne of an other Countrey it is harde to fynde one man whyche for his lyuelode is hable to bee receaued into a Iurye. For there, excepte it bee in Cities and walled townes, verye fewe there bee, beÅ¿ide noble menne that haue anye poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ions of landes or other immouables.
The noble menne alÅ¿o haue there Å¿mall Å¿tore of paÅ¿ture. And to labour in vyneyardes, or to putte theire handes to ye plough that is vnfitte for theire eÅ¿tate and degree.

And yet in vineyardes and eareable grounde conÅ¿iÅ¿teth the Å¿ubÅ¿taunce of theire poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ions, Å¿auynge onelye a fewe fyeldes nexte adioyninge
to greate ryuers, and Å¿auynge alÅ¿o certein woodz the paÅ¿tures whereof are commen to their tenants and neighboures.

Howe then can a Iurie bee made in Å¿uche countreis of xii. Å¿ubÅ¿taunciall menne nighe adioyninge to the place of anye deede broughte in iudgement, Å¿eeinge they can not bee called neighboures that dwell Å¿o farre a Å¿under. Truely xii. Å¿worne men theare muÅ¿t needes bee farre diÅ¿taunt from the place of the deede, when the defendaunt in thoÅ¿e Countreys hathe challenged xxxv. menne of the nexte dwellers wythout Å¿hewynge anye cauÅ¿e whye. Wherefore in thoÅ¿e landes a Iurye
muÅ¿t bee made either of Å¿u â¢ he as dwell farre of from the place of the deed that is in controuerÅ¿ie, and therefore cannot attaine to the knowledge of the truthe thereof, or els it muÅ¿t bee made of poore menne that bee not aÅ¿hamed of infamie, neither doe feare the loÅ¿Å¿e of theire goodes which they haue not.
They alÅ¿o blinded wyth ruÅ¿ticall and brute rudenes are not hable to beholde the cleare bryghtneÅ¿Å¿e of the trueth.
Marueyle not therefore, mo â¢ woorthye Prynce, yf the lawe whereby the truethe is Å¿ifted out in Englande bee not frequented and vÅ¿ed in other nations.
For they are not hable to make Å¿ufficient and lyke Iuries as bee made in Englande.

et armenta, ipÅ¿ae

que valecti diuerÅ¿i in regione illa, qui pluÅ¿ quaÌ Å¿excenta Å¿cuta ê annum expendere poÅ¿Å¿unt, quÃ´ iuratae Å¿uêius deÅ¿criptae, Å¿epiÅ¿Å¿ime iÌ regione illa fiunt: preÅ¿ertim in ingentibus cauÅ¿is, de militibus, armigeris, et aliis quoruÌ poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿iones in vniuerÅ¿o excedunt duo milia Å¿cutoruÌ per annum, Quare cogitari nequit tales Å¿ubornarÃ¬ poÅ¿Å¿e, vel êiurari velle, neduÌ ob timorâ dei, Å¿ed & ob
honorem Å¿uuÌ conÅ¿eruandum, et vituperium damnuÌ quoque inde conÅ¿equutiuum euitaÌ dum, etiam ne eorum heredes ipÅ¿orum ledantur infamia. Taliter, fili regis, diÅ¿poÅ¿ita inhabitataque non Å¿unt aliqua alia mundi regna.

Nam licet in eis Å¿int viri magnae potentiae, magnorum opum et poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ionum, non tamen eorum vnus prope moratur ad alterum, vt in Anglia tanti morantur viri, nec tanta vt ibi hereditatorum eÅ¿t copia et poÅ¿Å¿ â¢â¢ eÌtiuÌ terras:
vix enim in villata vna regionum aliaruÌ reperiri poterit vir vnus, patrimonio Å¿ufficiens, vt in iuratis ipÅ¿e ponatur. NaÌ raro ibideÌ, aliqui preter nobiles reperiuntur poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ores agroruÌ, alioruÌ ue immobiliuÌ, extra ciuitates & muratas villas. Nobiles quo
que ibidem paÅ¿turaruÌ copiam noÌ habeÌt, & vineas colere, aut aratro manê° apponere, Å¿tatui eoruÌ non coÌuenit, tnÌ in vineis et terris arabilibê° coÌÅ¿iÅ¿tit Å¿ubÅ¿tantia poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ionuÌ eoruÌ, exceptis Å¿olum pratis quibuÅ¿dam, adiacentibus

Quomodo tuÌc in regionibus talibus iurata fieri poterit ex duodecim probis hominibus de vicineto vbi factum aliquod in iudicio deducitur cuÌ vicini dici non poterunt qui tanta diÅ¿tantia diÅ¿iun guntur? Vere remotos multum a facto duodecim iuratos ibideÌ eÅ¿Å¿e oportebit, poÅ¿tquaÌ reus in regionibus illis triginta quin

de multum remotis a facto de quo contenditur, qui veritatem facti non agnoÅ¿cunt, in regnis illis oportebit facere iuratam, aut de pauperibus, quibus non eÅ¿t verecundia infamiae, nec timor iacturae bonorum Å¿uorum, cum ipÅ¿a non Å¿int ipÅ¿i etiam ruÅ¿ticitatis ruditate obcecati, veritatis claritatem nequeunt intueri.

Non igitur mireris princeps Å¿ilex qua in Anglia veritas inquiritur, alias non êuagetâ nationes,

div.head: Â¶Heere the prince commendeth the lawes of Englande of theire proceeding by Iuries. Cap. 30

div.p: THough we haue Å¿aid, (ê the prince, that coÌ pariÅ¿ons are odious, yet the Ciuile lawe in the compariÅ¿on by you made hath cleared it Å¿elfe from all blame. For thoughe you haue prooued ye lawe of Englande to bee of more excellencye then it, yet it deÅ¿erueth not therby to bee odious, forÅ¿o much as you haue blamed neither it nor the makers thereof.

But haue Å¿hewed ye couÌ trey wher it ruleth to be the only cauÅ¿e why it doth not in matters of doubte trye out the truth wyth Å¿o commendable a kynde of proceedinge, as the lawe of Englande dothe. But as touchinge that ye law of Englande in the caÅ¿e by you nowe diÅ¿cuÅ¿Å¿ed is more fitte and meete for that roialme then the Ciuile lawe, hereof we may not doubte. Wherefore wee are not deÅ¿irous to chaunge it for the Ciuile lawe. Howbeit this preeminence of the lawe of England proceedeth not of the fault of the other. For it is onelye the fertilitie of Englande that hath cauÅ¿ed it to bee Å¿uche as it is.

TVnc princeps Comparationes odioÅ¿as eÅ¿Å¿e licet dixerimus, lex tamen Ciuilis in comparatione per te facta omni Å¿e purgauit a crimine: quia licet ei Legem Angliae tu p â¢ etuleris, odium inde ipÅ¿a non meretur, dum neque eam, ne
que coÌditores eius increpaÅ¿ti.
Å¿ed Å¿oluÌ patriam vbi illa regit cauÅ¿aÌ eÅ¿Å¿e demoÌÅ¿traÅ¿ti quod non tam optabili proceÅ¿Å¿u vt lex Angliae, ipÅ¿a in dubiis elicit veritatem. Legem vero Angliae in caÅ¿u iam per te diÅ¿putato, accomodatiorem eÅ¿Å¿e regno illi quam eÅ¿t lex ciuilis, ambigere non Å¿inimur, quo eam pro ciuili coÌ mutare non appetimus, Å¿ed tamen hec legis Angliae preeminentia, ab alterius crimine non euenit, Å¿olum enim eam Angliae fertilitas Å¿ic cauÅ¿auit.

div.head: Â¶The Prince doubteth whether this proceeding by a Iurye be repugnaunt to godds lawe or not. Chap. 31.

div.p: BVt thoughe wee bee greatly delited in the fourme which the lawes of England vÅ¿e in Å¿ifting out the truthe in matters of contention, yet whether the Å¿ame lawe bee contrarie to holye Å¿cripture or not, that is to vs Å¿omewhat doubtfull.

For our Lorde Å¿aiethe to the PharaÅ¿ies in the vii. Chapiter of Saint Iohnz GhoÅ¿pell: In your lawe it is written that the teÅ¿timonye of two menne is true. And the lorde confirming the Å¿ame Å¿aithe.
I am one that beare witneÅ¿Å¿e of my Å¿elfe, and the father that Å¿ent mee beareth wytnes of me.
Nowe Å¿ir the PharaÅ¿ies were Iewes, Å¿o that it was all one to Å¿aye. It is written in your lawe and it is written in MoyÅ¿es lawe, whyche God gaue to the children of IÅ¿raell by MoyÅ¿es.

Wherefore to gayneÅ¿aie thys lawe is too denye gods lawe. Whereby it folowethe that if the law of England Å¿warue from thys lawe, it Å¿waruethe alÅ¿o from Godds lawe, whyche in no wiÅ¿e maye bee contraryed.

It ys wrytten alÅ¿o in ye eyghteenthe Chapiter of Saint Mathues goÅ¿pell:
Where the lord Å¿peaking of brotherlye admonitioÌ, amonge other thinges Å¿ayethe thus: But if thy brother here Å¿hee not then take yet wyth thee one or twooe, that in the mouthe of twoe or three witneÅ¿Å¿es euerye matter maye bee Å¿tabliÅ¿hed.

If the Lorde haue appointed euerye matter to be Å¿tablyÅ¿hed in ye mouth of twoe or three witneÅ¿Å¿es, then it is in vaine for to Å¿eeke for the verdict of manye menne in maters of doubt. For no manne is able to laye any other or better foundation then the Lorde hath layde.

TheÅ¿e are the doubtes good Chauncelloure whyche touchynge the
procedynge of the law of Englande in the tryall of maters do Å¿oÌewhat trouble me. Wherefore what auÌÅ¿wer maye here vnto be made I would gladly learne of you

SEd licet non in fimÃ¨ Canceltarie, nos delectet forma, qua leges Angliae in contentionibus reuelant veritatem, tamen an modus ille Å¿acrae repugnet Å¿cripturae vel non, paululum agitamur. Ait namque dominus phariÅ¿eis. Ioh. viii. In lege veÅ¿tra Å¿criptum eÅ¿t, quia duorum hominum teÅ¿timonium verum eÅ¿t, et huic applaudeÌs dominus inquit,
ego Å¿um qui teÅ¿timonium perhibeo de me ipÅ¿o, et teÅ¿timonium perhibet de me qui miÅ¿it me pater.
PhariÅ¿ei quippe iudei erant, vnde idem erat dicere in Lege veÅ¿tra Å¿criptum eÅ¿t, et in Lege MoÅ¿ay â¢â¢ (quae a domino ê MoyÅ¿en filiis IÅ¿raell prolata fuit) Å¿criptum eÅ¿t.

Quare huic legi coÌtraire, legi eÌ diuinÌ refragari, quÃ´ Å¿equitâ, qdâ lex Angliae Å¿i ab hac lege diÅ¿cedat, a lege diuina, cui reluctari noÌ licet, ipÅ¿a diÅ¿cedÃ­t. Scribitur etiam Math .xviij.
Quod dominus (loquens de correctione fraterna) inter alia Å¿ic ait. Si autem non te audierit frater tuus, adhibe tecum adhuc vnum aut duos, vt in ore duorum vel trium, Å¿tet omne verbum. Si in ore duorum vel trium dominus omne verbum Å¿tatuerit, fruÅ¿tra plurimum hominum queritur in dubiis veredictum. Nemo enim poteÅ¿t melius aut aliud fundamentum ponere, quam poÅ¿uit dominus.

Hec Å¿unt Cancellarie quae me de
legis angliae proceÅ¿Å¿u in probationibus aliquantulum conturbant. Quare qÌd his reÅ¿pondendum eÅ¿t a te doceri depoÅ¿co

div.head: Here is Å¿hewed that the procedinge by a Iurie is not repugnaunt to the lawe of god. Cap. 32.

div.p:
THe lawes of EnglaÌd, quod the CauÌcellour are nothiÌge at all repugnaunt to theÅ¿e thynges that trouble you, moÅ¿t worthie prince, thoughe they in maters of doubte do Å¿omewhat otherwyÅ¿e boult out ye trouthe. The lawe of the generall couÌ cell, wheriÌ it is prouided that Cardinalles Å¿hall not be coÌuicted of crimiÌal
offenÅ¿es otherwiÅ¿e then by the depoÅ¿ition of xii witneÅ¿Å¿es, is it any hynderaunce to the teÅ¿timonie of ii. men Yf? the teÅ¿timonie of ii men be true, of more force muÅ¿t the teÅ¿timonie of xii men be iudged true, acordynge to a rule of the law that Å¿ayethe: The more euer conteyneth in it that whiche is leÅ¿Å¿e. The iÌholder was promiÅ¿ed to be rewarded with an ouerplus, if he beÅ¿towed vpon the cure of the wounded maÌ more then the ii. penÅ¿e which he receaued. A man that laboreth to proue that he was abÅ¿ent at the tyme of the offenÅ¿e wherewith he is charged, Å¿hal it not be nedefull for him to
brynge furthe mo then ii or iii, witneÅ¿Å¿es, when his aduerÅ¿arie hathe proued, or is readie to proue the Å¿ame by ii. or iii. wytneÅ¿Å¿es. And Å¿o he that trauaylethe to conuince witneÅ¿Å¿es of periurie, muÅ¿t of neceÅ¿Å¿ite bringe furthe many mo then they were Å¿o that the teÅ¿timonie of ii. or iii. men Å¿hall not euer be iudged true. But that lawe muÅ¿t thus be vnderÅ¿tanded, that by a leÅ¿Å¿er number of witneÅ¿Å¿es then ii. the truthe in matters doubtfull ought not to be Å¿earched for, as appeareth by Bernard aÅ¿Å¿ignynge dyuers caÅ¿es wherin by the lawes mo then iii. wytneÅ¿Å¿es muÅ¿t needes be produced. As in Å¿ome of them v, and in
and in Å¿ome vii. Nor yett the lawes of Englande be not againÅ¿t it, but that the truethe may be proued by ii. witneÅ¿Å¿es, wheÌ it can no otherwyÅ¿e be tried For if thinges be done vppoÌ the Å¿ea without the bodye of any countye of that royalme, which afterward be brought in plea before the lord admirall, the Å¿ame thynges by the decrees of ye lawes of england muÅ¿t be proued by wytneÅ¿Å¿es. In lyke maner it hathe bene accuÅ¿tomed to be done before the CoÌÅ¿table & MarÅ¿hall of England touchynge a facte that was done in an other royalme, Å¿o that the heariÌge thereof appertaiÌeth
to the ConÅ¿tables courte. Moreouer in the courtes of certein liberties in EnglaÌd where matters proceede by lawe merchaunt contractes or bargaynes made amoÌge merchauÌtz in an other royalme are proued by witneÅ¿Å¿es.

And this coÌmeth to paÅ¿Å¿e becauÅ¿e that in theÅ¿e caÅ¿es there be no neighbours founde by whoÅ¿e othes Iuries of xii men may be made, as in contractes and other caÅ¿es arieÅ¿ynge within the royalme of Englande is accuÅ¿tomed to be doÌe LikewyÅ¿e if a deede wherin witneÅ¿Å¿es are named be brought into the kynges courte, then proceÅ¿Å¿e Å¿halbe made agaynÅ¿t thoÅ¿e witneÅ¿Å¿es: and they together withe xii. Iurers
Å¿hall by their othes recogniÅ¿e whether the Å¿ame be his deede or no whoÅ¿e it is Å¿uppoÅ¿ed to be. Wherefore the lawe of EnglaÌd reproueth not that lawe whiche by wytneÅ¿Å¿es tryeth out the trueth, Å¿pecially wheÌ neceÅ¿Å¿itie Å¿o requirethe. For Å¿o do ye lawes of Englande too, not onely in the caÅ¿es now mencioned, but alÅ¿o in certein other caÅ¿es, wherof here to make reherÅ¿all it Å¿hall not be material. Howbeit this lawe neuer determineth a coÌtrouerÅ¿ie by witneÅ¿Å¿es onely that maie be determined by a Iurie of xii. men: forÅ¿omuche as this waye is muche more aualeable and effectuall for the triall of the trueth
then is the fourme of any other lawes of the world and further from the dauÌ ger of corruption and Å¿ubornation. Nor this fourmÌ of proceedinge caÌ not in any cauÅ¿e faille for wante of witneÅ¿Å¿es: nor the teÅ¿timonies of witneÅ¿Å¿es, (if anye be) can not chooÅ¿e but come to their due ende and effect Neither caÌ Å¿uche xii. men be forÅ¿worne, but that for their offeÌÅ¿e they muÅ¿t Å¿uffer moÅ¿t Å¿harpe puniÅ¿hement, and neuertheleÅ¿Å¿e the partie by their depoÅ¿itions greeued Å¿hall obteie due remedie And theÅ¿e thiÌges Å¿hall not be doÌe by ye will & Å¿aiÌges of Å¿traunge or vnknowne
men but by the othes of good, of worÅ¿hipfull, and of credible meÌ neighbours to the parties, in whome the Å¿ame parties haue no cauÅ¿e of challenge or miÅ¿truÅ¿t touchiÌg their verdit. O howe horryble and deteÅ¿table dauÌ gers happen mani times throughe the fourme of proceedinge by wytneÅ¿Å¿es. Yf a maÌ make a priuie contract of matrimonie, & afterward before wytneÅ¿Å¿es do betrouthe or aÅ¿Å¿ure himÅ¿elf to another woman, Å¿hall he not in the contentious courte be coÌpelled to marye her, & alÅ¿o after that in ye penitenciall courte be iudged to lye with the firÅ¿t, if he be duely required, and to do penauÌce as ofte as by
his owne mocioÌ and procurement he liethe with the Å¿econde, thoughe in bothe courtes the iudge be one and the Å¿elfe Å¿ame man. In this caÅ¿e, as it is wryten in Iob, are not ye Å¿ynewes of Leuyathan perplexed and intricat. div.p:
I Å¿ee playnely, quod the prince, that in the caÅ¿e wherin you haue now trauayled they haue the preeminence aboue all other lawes of the world Yet we haue heard that Å¿ome of my progenitours kynges of EnglaÌd haue not bee pleÅ¿ed with their owne lawes, and haue therefore gone about to

div.p:
You woulde nothiÌge marueyll here at, quod the Chauncellour, if you did deepely conÅ¿yder withe your Å¿elfe ye cauÅ¿e of this inteÌt. In Å¿omuche that at ye tie of his coronation he is bound by an othe to the obÅ¿eruaunce and keepiÌg of his owne lawe, which thinge Å¿oÌe kynges of England not well brooking as thinkynge that thereby they Å¿hould not freely gouerne their Å¿ubiects as other kiÌges do, whoÅ¿e ruele is onely regall, gouernynge their people by the Ciuile lawe, and chiefely by that foreÅ¿aid maxime of the Å¿ame lawe whereby they at their pleaÅ¿ure chaunge lawes
make newe lawes, execute puniÅ¿hmentes, burden their Å¿ubiectes withe chargeis: and alÅ¿o when they luÅ¿t, do determine controuerÅ¿ies of Å¿ueters, as pleaÅ¿eth them. Wherfore theÅ¿e your progenitours went about to caÅ¿t of the yoke politique, that â¢ hey alÅ¿o might lykewiÅ¿e â¢ uele or rather rage ouer â¢ he people their Å¿ubiectes â¢ n regall wyÅ¿e onely: not â¢ onÅ¿yderynge that the power of bothe kynges is â¢ quall, as in the foreÅ¿aid â¢ reatiÅ¿e of the lawe of the â¢ awe of nature is declared: and that to ruele the people by gouernement politique is no yoke, but libertie, and greate Å¿ecuritie not onely to the Å¿ubiectes, but alÅ¿o to ye kinge
kynge himÅ¿elf: & further no Å¿mall lyghtenynge or eaÅ¿ement of his charge. And that this may appere more euident vnto you, ponder and weighe the experience of bothe regimentes And begynne with the kiÌge of FrauÌce, peruÅ¿iÌge after what Å¿orte he ruelethe his Å¿ubiectes by regall gouernement alone. And then coÌe to ye effect of the ioynte gouernaunce regall and politique, examinynge by experience howe and after what maner the kynge of England gouernethe his Å¿ubiectes.
