div.head: The inconueniences that happen in the royalme â¢ f FrauÌce throughe regall gouernement alone. Cap. 35.

div.p:
CAll to remeÌbrauÌce, moÅ¿t worthye prince after what Å¿orte you Å¿aw ye wealthie villages and townes (as touchynge â¢â¢ ore of corne) in the royalme of Fraunce, while you were there a Å¿o iourner, peÅ¿tered with the kynges men at armes & their horÅ¿es, Å¿o that Å¿kant in any of ye great townes there you could gett any lodgynge. Wheare of ye inhabiters you learned yt thoÅ¿e men, thoughe they continue in one village a monethe or ii, do not nor will paye any thynge at all either for their owne charges, or for the charges of their horÅ¿es. But, which is worÅ¿e, yâ¢y coÌpelled ye iÌhabitz of ye vilages
and town dwellers whether they caÌe, to prouide of their owne proper coÅ¿tes out of the villages adioyninge wyne & fleÅ¿h for them, and other thiÌgs yt thei needed at dearer prices then they might haue bought the Å¿ame at home. And if any refuÅ¿ed thus to do, they were anoÌ by plaine Å¿tafford lawe forced to do it. And when they had Å¿pent all the victualies, fewell, and horÅ¿e meat in one towne, then thoÅ¿e men went to an other towne waÅ¿tynge the Å¿ame in lyke maner, not payeyng one pennye for any neceÅ¿Å¿aries either for themÅ¿elfs, or ells for their coÌcubines and harlottes, whereof they euer carryed
caried aboute withe them great abundaunce, nor for hoÅ¿eÌ or Å¿hewes, and other lyke euen to the leaÅ¿t poiÌt or lace, but they compelled the towneÅ¿men, wheare theye carried to beare all theire expenÅ¿es. And thus were al the villages and vnwalled townes of that lande vÅ¿ed, Å¿o that there is not the leaÅ¿t village there free from this miÅ¿erable calamitie, but that it is once or twyÅ¿e euery yeare beggered by this kynde of pilling. Furthermore the kyng Å¿uffereth no man to eate Å¿alte within his kingdome, excepte he buy it of the kinge at Å¿uche price as pleaÅ¿eth him to aÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿e.

And if any pore man had rather eate his meate freÅ¿he, then to buy Å¿alt Å¿o exceÅ¿Å¿iuely deare, hee is imiÌmediatly
coÌpelled to buy Å¿o much of ye kinges Å¿alte at the kings price as Å¿hall Å¿uffice Å¿o many perÅ¿ones as he keepeth in his houÅ¿e. Moreouer all the inhabyters of that royalme geeue yearelye to the kynge the fowerthe parte of all the wynes yt theire grouÌdes bearethe: and euerye vintener the fowerth penney of the price of the wine that hee Å¿ellethe. And beeÅ¿ides all this euery village and borroughe payethe yearelye to the kyng great Å¿ummes of moneye aÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ed vppon them for the wages of men at armes, Å¿o that the charges of the kings army, which is euer verye great, is mainteyned by the poore people of ye villages, boroughes, & towns of ye roialme.
And yet moreouer euerye village findethe continuallye twoo CroÅ¿Å¿ebowes at the leaÅ¿te, and Å¿ome mo wythe all furnyture and habyliments requiÅ¿ite for the kynges Å¿eruyce in hys warres as ofte as it pleaÅ¿ethe hym to muÅ¿ter them whyche hee dothe verye ofte. And theÅ¿e thynges not conÅ¿idered, other exceedynge greate talleges are yearelye aÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ed vppon euerye vyllage of the Å¿ame royalme to the kynges vÅ¿e, whereof theye are no yeare releaÅ¿ed. The people beeinge wyth theÅ¿e and diuers other calamities plagued and oppreÅ¿Å¿ed, do liue in greate myÅ¿ery, driÌkiÌg water daily. Neyther do ye inferiour Å¿ort taÅ¿t any other licor Å¿auiÌg only at Å¿oleÌpne feaÅ¿ts
Theire Å¿hamewes are made of hempe, muche lyke to Å¿acke clothe. Woollen clothe theye weare none, excepte it bee verye courÅ¿e, and that onelye in theire coates vnder theire Å¿ayde vpper garmentes. Neyther vÅ¿e they anye hoÅ¿en, butte from the knee vpwarde: the reÅ¿idue of theire legges go naked. Theire women go barefoote Å¿auing on holye dayes. Neyther menne nor women eate anye fleÅ¿he there, but onelye larde of bacon, wythe a Å¿mall quantity whereof they fatten theire potage and brothes. As for roÅ¿ted or Å¿odden meate of fleÅ¿he they taÅ¿t none, except it be of ye inwards Å¿ometimes & heads of beaÅ¿tes ye be killed for geÌtlemeÌ & merchaÌtz
But the menne at armes they deuour and conÅ¿ume al their pullein Å¿o, ye theye haue Å¿kant the egges left to eate for Å¿peciall deintiez And if theye fortune at anye time to growe Å¿omewhat wealthie in Å¿ubÅ¿taÌ ce, Å¿o that any of them be compted ryche, hee is by & by charged to the kinges Å¿ubÅ¿idie more deepely theÌ any of his neighboures, Å¿o that within Å¿hort time he is made equall in pouertie with the reÅ¿t of his beggerlye neighboures. And this as I Å¿uppoÅ¿e, is the Å¿tate of the common and raÅ¿call people of that nation. But gentlemen and nobles are not Å¿o oppreÅ¿Å¿ed, and ouercharched wyth exaccions. Butte yf anye of them chauÌ ce
to bee accuÅ¿ed of anye cryme, thoughe it be by hys enemies, hee is not euer wonte to bee cyted or called beefore an ordynarye iudge. But manye tymes it hathe beene Å¿eene that hee hathe in that beehalfe been talked wythe in the kynges chamber, or elÅ¿where in Å¿ome priuate place, and Å¿ometymes onelye bye a pourÅ¿euaunte or meÅ¿Å¿enger. And immedyatlye as Å¿oone as the princes conÅ¿cience hathe throughe the reporte of others, iudged him guiltie, he is witheout anye faÅ¿Å¿ion of iudgement put in a Å¿acke and in the night Å¿eaÅ¿on by the MarÅ¿hals Å¿eruaÌts hurled iÌto a riuer, & Å¿o drowned.
After which Å¿ort you haue harde of manye mo put to deathe, then that haue bene by ordinary proceÅ¿Å¿e of the lawe condempned.

Howe be it the princes pleÅ¿ure, as Å¿aye the Ciuile lawes, hathe the force of a lawe. AlÅ¿o whyle yowe weare abydynge in FrauÌ ce, and nighe to the Å¿ame kyngedome, you heard of other greate enormityes lyke vnto theÅ¿e, and Å¿ome much worÅ¿e then theÅ¿e deteÅ¿table & damnable done no otherwiÅ¿e but vnder ye colour of that lawe: whiche here to rehearÅ¿e woulde continue oure talke too longe a time. Now therefore let vs Å¿e what ye effect of the lawe politique and regal, which Å¿ome of your progenitours would haue chaunged into this Ciuile
hathe wrought in the royalme of Englande: that yowe beeynge inÅ¿tructed wythe the experience of bothe lawes, may the better by theire effectes iudge whether of theÌ ye oughte rather to chooÅ¿e. Seeynge the philoÅ¿opher, as afore is rehearÅ¿ed, dothe Å¿aye, ye contraries layde together do more êfectly appeare.

div.head: Â¶The commodities that proceede of the iointe gouernement politique and regall in the royalme of Englande. Cap. 36,

div.p:
WIthein the roialme of England no man Å¿oiourneth in an other maÌs houÅ¿e wtout ye loue & ye leaue of ye good maÌ of ye Å¿ame houÅ¿e: Å¿auiÌg in coÌmen ynnes, wher before his deêture thence he Å¿hal fullye
Å¿attÅ¿fie & paye for all his charges there. Neyther Å¿hal he eÅ¿cape vnpuniÅ¿hed whoÅ¿oeuer he bee that taketh another mans goods wytheoute the good wyll of the owner therof. Neyther is it vnlawefull for anye manne in that royalme to prouide and Å¿tore hymÅ¿elfe of Å¿alte and other marchaundyÅ¿es or wares at his owne wyl and pleaÅ¿ure of any man that Å¿elleth ye Å¿ame. Howbe it the kinge, thoughe ye owners woulde Å¿aye nay maye by his officers take neceÅ¿Å¿aries for his houÅ¿e at a reaÅ¿onable price to be aÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ed by the diÅ¿crecions of the conÅ¿tables of the towns. Neuertheles he is bounde by his lawes to paye therefore eyther preÅ¿entlye in hande, or elles
at a daye to bee limitted and Å¿ette by the higher officers of his houÅ¿e. For by his lawes he maye take awaye none of his Å¿ubiectes goodes, witheoute due Å¿atiÅ¿faction for the Å¿ame. Neyther dothe the kinge there eyther by him Å¿elfe or by his Å¿eruauntes and officers leuie vppon his Å¿ubiectes tallages, Å¿ubÅ¿idies, or anye other burdeins, or alter theire lawes, or make newe laws without the expreÅ¿Å¿e conÅ¿ente and agreemente of his whole royalme in his parliamente. Wherefore euerye inhabiter of that royalme vÅ¿eth & enioyeth at his pleaÅ¿ure all the fruites that his land or cattall bearethe, withe all the profites & commodytyes,
whiche by his owne trauayle, or by the labour of others he gaineth by land or by water: not hindered by the iniurie or wronge deteinement of anye man but that hee Å¿halbee allowed a reaÅ¿onable recompence. And hereby it commethe to paÅ¿Å¿e that the men of that lande are ryche, hauynge abundaunce of golde and Å¿iluer and other thinges neceÅ¿Å¿arie for the mayntenaunce of mans lyfe Theye drynke no water, oneles it bee Å¿o that Å¿oome for deuotion, and vppon a zeale of penaunce do abÅ¿teyne from other drinkes. They eate plentyfullye of all kyndes of fleÅ¿he and fyÅ¿he. They weare fine wollen cloth in al their apparell.
Theye haue allÅ¿o abundaunce of bed coueryngs in their houÅ¿es, and of all other wollen Å¿tuffe. They haue greate Å¿tore of all huÅ¿tlements and implements of houÅ¿hold. They are plentifullye furniÅ¿hed withe all inÅ¿trumentes of huÅ¿bandry, & al other thinges that are requiÅ¿ite to the accompliÅ¿hement of a quiet and wealthie lyfe accordyng to their eÅ¿tates & degrees. Neither are they Å¿ued in ye law, but onelye beefore ordinarye iudges, wherebye the lawes of the lande theye are iuÅ¿tlye intreated. Neyther are theye arreÅ¿ted or impleaded for theire moueables or poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ioÌs, or arreigned of ani offeÌce criminal be it neuÌ Å¿o great & outragious
but after the lawes of the lande, and before the iudges aforeÅ¿aide. And thys are the fruites whiche gouernement politique and regall conioyned doothe beare and brynge fourthe Whereof nowe appeare euidentlye vnto yowe the experiences of the effectes of the lawe, whiche Å¿ome of your progenitoures trauayled to aboliÅ¿he. Before allÅ¿o yowe Å¿awe plainlye the effects of the other lawe, whyche theye with Å¿uche earneÅ¿te endeuoure laboured to aduaunce and place in Å¿teade of this lawe. So that by the fruites of them bothe you maye knowe what theye are And did not ambition, ryotte, and wanton luÅ¿te,
whiche youre Å¿aid progenitoures eÅ¿teemed aboue the wealthe of the realme moue them to this alteracion? ConÅ¿ider therefore moÅ¿te worthie prince, and that earneÅ¿tlye this that foloweth.

IN regno Angliae nullus perhendinat in alterius domo inuito domino, Å¿i non in hoÅ¿piciis publicis, vbi tunc pro omnibus quae ibidem expeÌdit ipÌe plenariÃª

que bona alterius capit, Å¿ine voluntate proprietarij eoruÌ deÌ, ne

oÌiÌbus: qÌ induÅ¿tria êria vel aliena ipÌe terra mari
que lucratur, ad libituÌ êpriuÌ vtitur nulliê° pÌpeditus iÌiuria vel rapina, quin ad minê° iÌde debitas coÌÅ¿eqÌ tur emeÌdas: vnde inhabitaÌtes terraÌ illaÌ locupletes Å¿unt, abuÌdaÌtes auro, et argeÌto, etcuÌctis neceÅ¿Å¿arijs vitae. AquaÌ ipÌi noÌ bibuÌt, niÅ¿i qÌ ob deuotioÌis et peniteÌciae zeluÌ aliquaÌ do ab alijs potubê° Å¿e abÅ¿tineÌt. Omni genere carniuÌ et piÅ¿ciuÌ ipÌi in copia veÅ¿cuÌtur, qÌbus patria illa noÌ modicÃ¨ eÅ¿t referta, pannis de lanis bonis ipÅ¿i induuÌtur in oiÌbus operimentis Å¿uis,
etiam abundaÌt in lectiÅ¿terniis et quo libet Å¿uppellectili cui lana congruit in oiÌbus domibus Å¿uis, nec non opulenti ipÅ¿i Å¿unt in oÌ nibus huÅ¿tilimentis domus neceÅ¿Å¿ariis culturae, et oÌnibus qÌ ad quietam, et felicem vitaÌ exiguntur, Å¿ecunduÌ Å¿tatus Å¿uos. Nec in placitum ipÅ¿i ducuntur niÅ¿i coram iudicibus ordinariis, vbi illi per leges terrae iuÅ¿te tractantur. Nec allocuti Å¿iue implacitati Å¿unt de mobilibus aut poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ionibus Å¿uis, vel arrettati de crimine aliquo qualit
er cuÌ
que magno et enormi,
niÅ¿i Å¿ecundum leges terrae illius, et coram iudicibus antedictis. Et hij Å¿unt fructus quos parit regimeÌ politicum et regale, ex quibus tibi iam apparent experienciae effectus legis, quam quidam progenitorum tuorum abicere conati Å¿unt. Superius quoque tibi apparent effectus legis alterius, quam tanto zelo loco legis iÅ¿tius, ipÅ¿i niÅ¿i Å¿unt inducere, vt ex fructubus earum tu agnoÅ¿cas eas, et nonne ambicio, luxus, et libido, quos

div.head: A compariÅ¿on of the worthines of bothe the regiments Cap. 37.

div.p:
SAiÌt Thomas in his boke whiche he wrote to ye kiÌg of Cyprê° of ye regimeÌt of princes, Å¿aieth yt ye king is geeueÌ for ye kingdome, & not the kingedome for the king. Whereupon it foloweth that al kingelye power muÅ¿te bee applyed to the wealthe of his kyngdome. Whiche thynge in effecte conÅ¿iÅ¿tethe in the defeÌce therof froÌ forreyne
inuaÅ¿ions, and in the maiÌ tenaunce of his Å¿ubiectes, and their goodes from the iniuries and extortions of the inhabitauntes of the Å¿ame. Wherfore that kiÌg whiche is not hable to perfourme theÅ¿e things, muÅ¿t of neceÅ¿Å¿itie be iudged impotent and weake. But if he bee Å¿o ouercome of hys owne affections and luÅ¿tz or Å¿o oppreÅ¿Å¿ed wythe pouertie, that hee canne not wytheholde hys handes from the pyllynge of hys Å¿ubiectes, whereby hymÅ¿elfe impoueriÅ¿heth them and Å¿ufferethe them not to lyue, and to bee Å¿uÅ¿teyned vppon theire owne Å¿ubÅ¿taunces, howe muche more weake or feble is he iÌ this reÅ¿pect to be iudged,
then if hee weare not hable to defend them agaiÌÅ¿t the iniuries of others. Truelye Å¿uche a kynge maye well bee called not onelye feeble, but eeuen verye feblenes it Å¿elfe: nor is not to bee iudged free, beeinge tyed with Å¿o manye bandes of feeblenes. On the other Å¿yde that kynge is free and of myghte, that is hable to defende his Å¿ubiectes aÅ¿well agaynÅ¿te Å¿traungers as agaynÅ¿te his owne people: and alÅ¿o theire gooddes and poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ions not onelye from the violente and vnlawefull inuaÅ¿ionz of theire owne countreymenne and neighbours, butte allÅ¿o from his own oppreÅ¿Å¿ion and extortion,
though Å¿uch wilful luÅ¿ts and neceÅ¿Å¿ities doe moue him to the contrarie. For who can be more mighty or more free then he that is hable to conquere and Å¿ubdue not onely others but alÅ¿o himÅ¿elfe?

Whiche thinge a kynge whoÅ¿e gouernaunce is politike can doo and euer dothe. Thus moÅ¿t woorthy prince it appearethe vnto you by the effecte of experience, that your progenitours, whyche were thus mynded to renounce theire politique gouernement, coulde not thereby not onely not obtaine the might and power, whiche they wiÅ¿hed: that is to Å¿aye, increaÅ¿e therof, but rather they Å¿houlde haue endaungered and greatlye haÅ¿arded the wealthe
aÅ¿well of themÅ¿elues, as alÅ¿o of theire kingdome. NotwithÅ¿tandinge theÅ¿e thinges nowe practiÅ¿ed, which as touchiÌg theffect of experience do Å¿eeme to blemiÅ¿he the power of a king ruling all alone regally, neuer proceeded of the default of their law, but of ye careleÅ¿Å¿e demeanour, and negligent louÅ¿enes of Å¿uche a ruler.

Wherefore that dignitie is not heareby in power imbaÅ¿ed vnder the dignitie of a politique gouernour, whiche bothe in my foreÅ¿aid treatiÅ¿e of the nature of the law of nature I haue plainlye proued to bee in power equall.

But the premiÅ¿Å¿es dooe moÅ¿te euidentlye declare it to be a matter of much more difficultie for a king
whoÅ¿e rule is onely regal to exerciÅ¿e his power, and that bothe hee and hys people Å¿tande in muche leÅ¿Å¿e Å¿ecuritie. And therefore it were not to bee wiÅ¿hed of a wiÅ¿e kynge to chaunge a politike regiment intoo that gouernement whiche is onelye regall. And accordinge to thys the foreÅ¿aide Sainte Thomas wiÅ¿hethe that all the kingdomes of the worlde were ruled by politike gouernaunce.

SAnctê° Thomas in libro queÌ Regi Cipri de regimine priÌcipuÌ Å¿cripÅ¿it dicit: qdâ rex datur êpter regnuÌ, etnoÌ regnuÌ êpter regeÌ quoÌ oÌnis poteÅ¿tas regia referri debet ad bonuÌ regni Å¿ui, quod effectiuÃ¨ coÌ Å¿iÅ¿tit in defencione eiuÅ¿dem ab exteroruÌ incurÅ¿ibê°,
et in tuicione regnicolarum, et bonorum Å¿uorum ab indigenarum iniurijs et rapinis. Quare rex quihec peragere nequit, impotens eÅ¿t neceÅ¿Å¿ario iudicandus. Sed Å¿i ipÅ¿e paÅ¿Å¿ionibus proprijs aut penuria ita oppreÅ¿Å¿us eÅ¿t, quod manus Å¿uas cohibere nequit a depilatione Å¿ubditorum Å¿uoruÌ quÃ´ ipÅ¿emet eos depauperat, nec viuere Å¿init et Å¿uÅ¿tentari proprijs Å¿ubÅ¿tantijs Å¿uis: quanto tunc impotencior ille iudicaÌdus eÅ¿t,
quam Å¿i eos defendere ipÅ¿e non Å¿ufficerent erga aliorum iniurias? Reuera rex talis nedum impotens, Å¿ed et ipÅ¿a impotentia dicendus eÅ¿t, et non liber iudicari poteÅ¿t tantis iÌpotentiae nexubus vinculatus. E regione rex liber et potens eÅ¿t, qui incolas Å¿uos erga exteros et indigenas, eoruÌ quo que bona et facultates nedum erga vicinorum et conciuium rapinas defendere Å¿ufficit, Å¿ed erga proprium oppreÅ¿Å¿ionem, et rapinam
licet Å¿ibi paÅ¿Å¿iones neceÅ¿Å¿itateÅ¿
que huiuÅ¿modi reluctentur. Quis enim potentior liberiorue eÅ¿Å¿e poteÅ¿t, quam qui non, Å¿olum alios, Å¿ed et Å¿e ipÅ¿uÌ Å¿ufficit debellare? quod poteÅ¿t et Å¿eÌ per facit rex politicÃª regens populum Å¿uum, quare experientiae effectu tibi conÅ¿tat priÌ ceps, progenitores tuos qui Å¿ic politicum regimen abicere Å¿atagerunt, non Å¿olum in hoc non potuiÅ¿Å¿e nanciÅ¿ci potentiaÌ quaÌ optabant, videlicet ampliorem, Å¿ed et Å¿ui bonum, Å¿imiliter et bonum Regni Å¿ui,
per hoc ipÅ¿i diÅ¿crimini expoÅ¿uiÅ¿Å¿ent et êiculo graÌdiori Tamen hec quae iaÌ de experienciae effectu practicata, potentiaÌ regis regaliter tantuÌ preÅ¿identis exprobrare videntur, noÌ ex legis Å¿uae defectu êceÅ¿Å¿eruÌt, Å¿ed ex incuria negligeÌtia
que taliter principaÌtis, quare ipÅ¿a dignitateÌ illaÌ potentia noÌ minuuÌt, a dignitate regis politicÃ¨ regulaÌtâ quos paris eÅ¿Å¿e potentiae in predicto tractatu de natura legis naturae luculenter oÅ¿tendi. Sed poteÌ ciaÌ regis regaliter tantuÌ principantis difficilioris eÅ¿Å¿e ex
cercij, ac minoris Å¿ecuritatis Å¿ibi & populo Å¿uo, illa clariÅ¿Å¿imÃ¨ iam demonÅ¿trant, quÃ´ optabile non foret regi prudenti, regimen politicuÌ pro tantÃ»m regali commutare.
vnde et Å¿anctus Thomas Å¿upradictus, optare cenÅ¿etur, vt omniuÌ muÌ di regna politice regerentur.

div.head: Â¶The Prince breaketh the Chauncellour of his tale. Cha. 38

div.p:
BEare with mee I beÅ¿eche you good Chancellour quod the Prince,
in that with my queÅ¿tioÌs I haue draweÌ you Å¿o farr from youre purpoÅ¿e. For the thynges whiche by this occaÅ¿ion you haue diÅ¿cuÅ¿Å¿ed are to me righte profitable, thoughe they haue Å¿oomewhate Å¿taied you, and pulled you back from the ende of your intent. Whereunto I pray you now make haÅ¿te: and firÅ¿t as you promiÅ¿ed, and as you haue begonne, open vnto mee Å¿ome other caÅ¿es wherin the Å¿entences of the lawes of Englande and of the Ciuile lawes do diÅ¿agree.

TVnc priÌceps Parce obÅ¿ecro Cancellarie,
quod te ad tantam a propoÅ¿ito tuo digreÅ¿Å¿ionem compuli queÅ¿tionibus meis, michi nanque perutilia Å¿unt quae hac occaÅ¿ionÌ exaraÅ¿ti, licet te parumper retardauerint a meta intentionis tuae, ad quam vt tu iaÌ celerius properes flagito, et primo vt aliquos alios caÅ¿us, in quibus legum Angliae et Ciuilium diÅ¿crepant Å¿entenciae, vt promiÅ¿iÅ¿ti et cepiÅ¿ti, mihi enarres.

div.head: Â¶The Å¿econde caÅ¿e, wherin the Ciuile lawes, and the lawes of England diÅ¿agree in theire iudgementes. Chap. 39.

div.p:
ACcording to your requeÅ¿t moÅ¿t noble priÌce (quod ye Chancellour) I will open vntoo you certeine other caÅ¿es wherein the Å¿aide lawes diÅ¿agree. Howbeit whether of the Å¿ame lawes in their iugements excelleth ye other, yt will I leaue to your own determination. The Ciuile law doth legittimate the childe borne beefore matrimonie aÅ¿well as yt which is borne after: and geueth vntoo it Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿ion in ye parents inheritance. But to the childe borne out of matrimonye the lawe of Englande alloweth no Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿ion, affirmynge it to bee naturall onelye and not lawfull. The CiuiliaÌs in this caÅ¿e auaunce theire law-alleginge
that by meane thereof the Å¿acrament or Å¿tate of matrimonie comminge in place, extinguiÅ¿hethe the former Å¿inne, whereby eles the Å¿owles of twoe perÅ¿ones Å¿houlde haue periÅ¿hed. And it is to bee preÅ¿umed, Å¿ay they that they were at theyre firÅ¿t copulation bothe Å¿o mynded as the Å¿acrameÌt enÅ¿uynge afterward declareth. The churche alÅ¿o accepteth Å¿uche chyldren for legittimate. TheÅ¿e I trowe are the iii. Å¿trongeÅ¿t reaÅ¿ons, whereby they maintaine and defende theyre law. Which are thus aunÅ¿wered by the lawyers of England. FirÅ¿te they Å¿aye that the Å¿inne of the firÅ¿te carnal accion in ye caÅ¿e propounded is not purged by the
matrimonie enÅ¿uynge, thoughe by the woorthynes thereof the Å¿ynners puniÅ¿hement is Å¿omwhat abated. They Å¿aye alÅ¿o that they whiche thus do Å¿inne are Å¿omuche ye leÅ¿Å¿e repentaunt therefore, in aÅ¿muche as they perceaue the lawes to fauour and beare with Å¿uche traÌÅ¿greÅ¿Å¿ours. And vppon thys conÅ¿ideration they are made the redyer to committe the Å¿inne: thereby breakinge the commaundement bothe of god and of the churche. Wherefore this lawe dooth not onelye participate wt the offeÌce of Å¿inners, but alÅ¿o Å¿warueth froÌ the nature of a good lawe. ForaÅ¿much as a law is a holye Å¿tabliÅ¿hement, coÌmaÌding thynges honeÅ¿t, and forbiddynge the contrarye.
Whiche this lawe dothe not, but rather allureth ye myndes of Å¿ynners to diÅ¿honeÅ¿tye. Neither can it bee anye defence to thys lawe, that the churche accepteth Å¿uche children for legittimate. For that louynge mother diÅ¿penÅ¿eth in many thinges, whiche Å¿hee licenceth to be doone And it was by waye of diÅ¿penÅ¿acion that the ApoÅ¿tle Å¿et virgins at libertie, whereunto he would not counÅ¿el them, rather wyÅ¿hinge all to continue virgines like himÅ¿elfe. And god forbyd that Å¿o greate a mother Å¿houlde in thys caÅ¿e wythdrawe her tender loue from her chyldren, whiche by the inticement of this lawe dooe manye times fall into Å¿inne.

And by the matrimonye enÅ¿uynge the church is infourmed that the partyes Å¿o marrieng are penitent & Å¿ory for the offence paÅ¿Å¿ed, and are willinge in time to come through matrimonie to lyue contineÌt. But the law of EnglaÌde in this caÅ¿e woorketh a much contrarie effecte.

For it prouokethe not to Å¿inne, nor cheriÅ¿hethe or mainteineth Å¿inners, but putteth them in feare, & to keepe them from Å¿inne threatneth puniÅ¿hement. For the wantonneÅ¿Å¿e of the fleÅ¿he hath no neede of allurement, but rather of diÅ¿couragement: becauÅ¿e the luÅ¿tes of the fleÅ¿he are wanton, and almoÅ¿te vntamable. And foraÅ¿much as it is impoÅ¿Å¿ible for maÌ to liue euer in hymÅ¿elfe,
he naturallye coueteth to lyue euer in his like, beecauÅ¿e euery liuing thing, deÅ¿yreth to be lyke ye firÅ¿t and chiefe cauÅ¿e, which is perpetuall & euerlaÅ¿ting. And hereof it commethe that man hath more delyte and pleaÅ¿ur â¢ in the Å¿ence of feeling, whereby his kind is preÅ¿erued, thaÌ in the Å¿ence of taÅ¿t, which preÅ¿erueth onely the particuler man. Wherefore Noe executinge vengeance vpoÌ his Å¿onne which vncouered his priuities, dyd curÅ¿e his nephewe the offendors childe, that thereby the offendoure might bee more grieued then with his owne miÅ¿happe. Wherefore ye law that puniÅ¿heth the offendours iÅ¿Å¿ue doth more penallye prohibite Å¿inne.
then that whiche plageth but the offendour alone. Whereby it may eaÅ¿elye bee conÅ¿idered with what zeale the lawe of EnglaÌd abhorreth vnlawfull coniuÌctions, whiche doth not onelye iudge the childe Å¿o gotten to be illegittimate but alÅ¿o prohibiteth it to Å¿uccede in the parents inheritaÌce. Is not this lawe then chaÅ¿t and pure? And dooth it not more forceably and more earneÅ¿tlye Å¿uppreÅ¿Å¿e Å¿inne, then the foreÅ¿aide Ciuile lawe, whiche winketh at the Å¿inne of lecherie, and leueth it vnpuniÅ¿hed?

CAncellarius. QuoÅ¿daÌ caÅ¿us alios in quibus diÅ¿Å¿entiunt leges predictae, vt petis princeps, detegere conabor. Prolem ante matrimoniuÌ natam, ita vt poÅ¿t legittimuÌ, lex ciuilis, et Å¿uccedere facit in hereditate pareÌtuÌ Å¿ed proleÌ quaÌ matrimoniuÌ noÌ parit Å¿uccedere noÌ Å¿mit lex angloruÌ, naturaleÌ taÌtuÌ eaÌ eÅ¿Å¿e & noÌ legittimaÌ proclamans. quia incitameÌtum eaÌ eÅ¿Å¿e dicuÌt, quo matrimonij Å¿acrameÌto ceÅ¿Å¿et peccatuÌ, ê qdâ alias duo rum animae interirent, preÅ¿umenduÌ quo
que eÅ¿Å¿e dicuÌt, tales fuiÅ¿Å¿e coÌtrahen tiuÌ animos in primo eoruÌ coÌcubitu quales eÅ¿Å¿e demoÌ Å¿trat Å¿ubÅ¿equeÌs Å¿acramentuÌ. EccleÅ¿ia etiaÌ fetus hmÌÃ´i habet pro legittimis: hec ni fallor tria fulcimeÌta Å¿uÌt maiora, quibus ipÅ¿i appodiaÌt defeÌ dunt
que legeÌ Å¿uam. Ad quae Å¿ic reÅ¿poÌ dent leges Angliae periti. primo dicuÌt quod peccatum primi concubitus in caÅ¿u propoÅ¿ito
non purgatur per Å¿ubÅ¿equens matrimoniuÌ, licet eius merito deliÌqueÌtiuÌ quodamodo minuatur pena. DicuÌt etiaÌ quod peccati illius conÅ¿cii, tanto minus inde peniteÌt, quo leges traÌgreÅ¿Å¿oribus illis fauere coÌÅ¿iderant. quali etiaÌ coÌÅ¿ideratione, procliuiores ipÅ¿i redduntur ad coÌmitteÌduÌ peccatuÌ, per quod neduÌ dei Å¿ed & eccleÅ¿iae precepta necliguÌt. Vnde lex illa neduÌ delinquentiuÌ êticipat culpaÌ, Å¿ed et legis bonÌ naturaÌ ipÅ¿a declinat. cuÌ lex Å¿it Å¿aÌctio Å¿aÌcta iubens honeÅ¿ta & êphibeÌs coÌtrarâ,
qualia ipÅ¿a non prohibet, Å¿ed potiê° ad inhoneÅ¿ta animos labentium inuitat. Nec vallari poteÅ¿t lex iÅ¿ta per hoc, quod eccleÅ¿ia fetus huiuÅ¿modi pro legittimis habet. Pia nan
que mater illa, in quaÌplurimis diÌÅ¿peÌÅ¿at, quae fieri ipÅ¿a noÌ coÌcedit, diÅ¿penÅ¿atiua enim laxauit apoÅ¿tolus virginitatis frena, qdâ coÌÅ¿ulere noluit, cuÌ oeÌs ipÅ¿e voluerit vt Å¿e virgines permanÅ¿iÅ¿Å¿e Et abÅ¿it vt mater tanta a filiis Å¿uis in caÅ¿u iÅ¿to pietatem Å¿uaÌ cohiberet, duÌ Å¿epe ipÅ¿i etiaÌ legis huiê° ciuilis fomeÌto coÌcitati, inciduÌt in peccatum.
peccatum. Et per matrimoniuÌ Å¿ubÅ¿equens docetur eccleÅ¿ia, contraheÌtes penitere de preterito, et de futuro per matrimonium Å¿e velle cohibere. Sed longe alium in hoc caÅ¿u lex angliae effectum operatur, dum ipÅ¿a non concitat ad peccatum, neque peccaÌtes fouet, Å¿ed terret eos, et ne peccent minatur penas, carnis etenim illecebrae fomento noÌ egent, egeÌt vero frenis, quia irritamenta carnis laÅ¿ciua & quaÅ¿i infatigabilia Å¿uÌt. Et homo quuÌ indiuiduo êpetuari nequit, êpetuari

Vnde fit quod plus delectatur homo in Å¿enÅ¿u tactus, quo Å¿eruatur Å¿pecies eius, quam in Å¿enÅ¿u guÅ¿tus, quo conÅ¿eruatur iÌdiuiduuÌ Quare Noe vlciÅ¿cens in filium qui eius pudenda reuelauit, nepoti Å¿uo, filio delinqueÌ tis maledixit, vt inde plus cruciaretur reus quaÌ êprio poÅ¿Å¿it incomodo, quare lex quae vindicat in ê geniem delinqueÌ tis, penalius prohibet peccatum,

div.head: Â¶Speciall cauÅ¿es why baÅ¿e borne children are not legittimate in England by matrimony enÅ¿uing. Chap. 40.

div.p: MOre ouer the Ciuile lawes Å¿ay yt your natural or baÅ¿tard Å¿onne is ye Å¿oÌne of ye people. Wherof a certein metriciaÌ writeth in this wiÅ¿e.
div.q: To whom the people father is, to hiÌ is father none & all. To whom the people father is, wel fatherles we may him call.
div.p:
And while Å¿uche a chylde had no father at ye tyme of his birthe, Å¿urelye nature knoweth not howe he could afterward come by a father. For if one woman Å¿houlde beare two children of twoe fornicatours, and the one of them Å¿houlde afterward marrye her: Whether of theÅ¿e twooe children Å¿houlde by this marriage bee legittimat? OppinioÌ may Å¿omewhat êÅ¿wade,
but reaÅ¿on cannot fynde: Å¿eeing the time was once when bothe thoÅ¿e chyldren beeinge iudged the children of the people, did not knowe theire fathers It were therefore vnreaÅ¿onable that a child afterwarde borne in the Å¿ame wedlocke, whoÅ¿e generation cannot be vnknoweÌ Å¿houlde be diÅ¿herited, and that a childe whiche knoweth no father Å¿hould be heire to the father & mother of the other, Å¿pecially in ye roialme of England where the eldeÅ¿t Å¿onne only enioieth the fathers inheritance. And an indifferent iudge would think it no leÅ¿Å¿e vnreaÅ¿onable, that a baÅ¿e borne childe Å¿houlde bee equally matched with a lawful begotten childe in ye inheritaÌce
whiche by the Ciuile lawes can bee deuyded but onelye among male children. For Å¿aint AuguÅ¿tine in the xvi. booke de Ciuitate dei wrytethe thus. Abraham gaue all his Å¿ubÅ¿tance to his Å¿onne IÅ¿aac: and to the Å¿onnes of his concubines he gaue gyftes. Whereuppon Å¿emeth to bee ment, that to baÅ¿tarde children there is noe inheritaunce due, but onelye a neceÅ¿Å¿ary lyuinge. Thus Å¿aieth hee And vnder the name of a baÅ¿tard child Å¿aint AuÅ¿teÌ vnderÅ¿taÌdeth all vnlawful yÅ¿Å¿ues: & Å¿o doth holye Å¿cripture alÅ¿o iÌ diuers places, callinge none by the name of a baÅ¿tard. Lo, Saint AuÅ¿ten thinkethe no Å¿mall difference to be, & Å¿o thinketh AbrahaÌ to,
betwene the Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿ion of a baÅ¿tarde, and of a Å¿onne lawfullye begotten. Yea holye Å¿cripture reprehendeth all vnlawful childreÌ vnder this metaphore, Å¿ayeng BaÅ¿tarde Å¿lippes Å¿hall take no deepe roote nor lay any faÅ¿t foundation, in the iiii. chapiter of the booke of wiÅ¿edome. The churche alÅ¿o reproueth the Å¿ame in that it admitteth them not to holye orders. And if it Å¿o bee that the churche doe dyÅ¿penÅ¿e withe Å¿uche a one, yet it permitteth not him to haue anye dignitye or preeminence in ye church Wherefore it is conuenyent that mannes lawe in the benefite of Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿ioÌ Å¿houlde cutte theÌ Å¿horte,
whome the Churche iudgeth vnworthy to bee receaued into holye orders, and reiecteth from all prelacie: yea whome holye Å¿cripture iudgeth, as touchinge their birthe, much inferiour to them that be lawfullye begotten. We reade that Gedeon the puiÅ¿Å¿aunt begate lxx. Å¿onnes in wedlocke, and but one onelye out of wedlocke. Yet thys miÅ¿begotten chylde wyckedlye Å¿lewe all thoÅ¿e lawfullye beegotten children one onelye excepted. Iudges .ix. Whereby it ys perceaued that there was more wyckedneÅ¿Å¿e in one baÅ¿tarde chylde, then in .lxix. lawfull Å¿onnes. For it is a commen Å¿ayenge:
If a baÅ¿tard bee good, yt coÌmeth to him by chauÌce, that is to wytte, by Å¿peciall grace, but if he be euil that commeth to him by nature. For it is thought that the baÅ¿e child draweth a certeyn corruption and Å¿tayne from ye Å¿ynne of his parentes, without his owne fault, as all we haue receaued of ye Å¿ynne of oure firÅ¿t pareÌts much infection, thoughe not Å¿omuche. Howebeit the blemiÅ¿he which baÅ¿tardes by their generation do receaue muche differeth froÌ that werein lawfull children are borne. For their conception is wrought by the mutuall Å¿ynnefull luÅ¿t of both pareÌts, which in the laufull & chaÅ¿t copulations of marryed couples taketh no place. The
Å¿ynne of Å¿uche fornicatours is committed by ye mutuall conÅ¿ent of them bothe. Wherefore it is likened to the firÅ¿t Å¿ynne, & cleaueth more cruelly to the chylde, then the Å¿ynne of Å¿uche as do otherwiÅ¿e offende alone: Å¿o that the chylde Å¿o begotten deÅ¿erueth to be called the child of Å¿ynne, rather then the chylde of Å¿ynners. wherefore the boke of wyÅ¿edoÌ makynge a difference betweene theÅ¿e ii. genÌatioÌs of ye laufull genÌatioÌ it Å¿ayethe thus. O howe faire is a chaÅ¿te generacioÌ wt vertue. The memoriall thereof is immortall: for it is knowen with god & with men. But the other is not knowen with men
Å¿o that the children there of borne are called ye children of the people. Of whiche baÅ¿e generation the Å¿ame booke thus Å¿peaketh: All the chyldreÌ that are borne of wycked pareÌtz are witneÅ¿Å¿es of wyckednes agaiÌÅ¿t their pareÌtz when they be aÅ¿ked. For beiÌge demauÌded of their parentz, they open theyr Å¿ynne, euen as the wycked Å¿onne of Noe vncouered his fathers priuities. It is therefore beleued touchiÌge the bliÌde borne of whom the pharaÅ¿iez in the ix chapter of Saint Iohns ghoÅ¿pell Å¿aid: Thou art altogether borne in Å¿iÌne: yt he was a baÅ¿tarde, who wholly is borne of Å¿ynne. And where it folowethe:
doeÅ¿t not thou teache vs. It Å¿eemeth that thereby maye be vnderÅ¿tanded, yt a baÅ¿tard hathe no lyke naturall diÅ¿poÅ¿ition to knowlege and learnyng as a lawfull chylde hath. Wherefore that lawe maketh no good diuiÅ¿ion whiche in the fathers inheritance makethe equal baÅ¿tard children and laufull childreÌ, whoÌ ye church in gods inheritaunce maketh vnequall. Betwene whom alÅ¿o Å¿cripture putteth a differeÌce in fourme aboue mentioned: & whoÌ nature in her gyftes Å¿euereth, markynge the naturall or baÅ¿tard chyldren as it were with a certein priue mark iÌ their Å¿oules Whether therefore of ye ii. lawes EngliÅ¿he or ciuile do you now imbrace
moÅ¿t noble prince, & iudge to haue the preeminence in this caÅ¿e.

hereditatem quae iure Ciuili inter maÅ¿culos diuidenda eÅ¿t. Nam Å¿aÌctus AuguÅ¿tinus xvi. li. de Ciui. dei Å¿ic Å¿cribit. Abraham oeÌm cenÅ¿um Å¿uuÌ dedit IÅ¿aac filio Å¿uo, filiis auteÌ coÌ cubinarum dedit dationes, ex quo videtur innui qdâ Å¿puriis non debetur hereditas, Å¿ed victus neceÅ¿Å¿itas. hec ille. Sub noiÌe vero Å¿purii denotat AuguÅ¿tinus omnem fetum illegittimuÌ, qualiter et Å¿epiê° facit Å¿criptura Å¿acra quae nemineÌ vocat baÅ¿tar duÌ. quos eccleÅ¿ia indignos iudicat Å¿acro ordinÌ, et quos ipÅ¿a repellit ab oiÌ prelatia, ipÅ¿os etiaÌ quos Å¿criptura Å¿acra in natalibê° minoratos iudicat a legittime procreatis. div.head: The prince alloweth the lawe whiche doth not legittimat chyldren borne bifore matrimonie. Cap. 41.

div.p:
Surely euen to that law do I geeue the preferment, quod the prince, which is of more force to abandoÌ Å¿ynne out of the royalme, and to auaunce vertue. ThoÅ¿e alÅ¿o in the benefites of mans lawe do I Å¿uppoÅ¿e abiect and baÅ¿e, whom the lawe of god conÅ¿ydereth vnworthye, and whoÌ the church in her benefits reiecteth and nature alÅ¿o iudgeth more prone vnto Å¿ynne. I thiÌke you do not iudge amyÅ¿Å¿e, quod the ChauÌcellour. wherefore I wyl reherÅ¿e yet other caÅ¿es,
wherein the Å¿aid lawes diÅ¿agree.

div.head: The third caÅ¿e wherein the lawes aforeÅ¿aide diÅ¿agree. Cap. 42.

div.p:
The Ciuile lawes decre that the yÅ¿Å¿ue euer foloweth the woÌbe, that is to Å¿aye, the mother. As for example, yf a boÌd woman be marryed to a freman, theyr iÅ¿Å¿ue Å¿halbe bond. And contrarywiÅ¿e if a bonde man marrie a free woman, he begetteth none but free children But the lawe of EnglaÌd neuer iudgeth the iÅ¿Å¿u to folowe the mothers condicion, but alwaye the fathers. So that a free man begetteth free children aÅ¿well of a bonde woman as of a free woman: and a boÌde maÌ in wedlock caÌ beget noÌe other but boÌd
childreÌ. Whether of theÅ¿e lawes is better thynke you in theier Å¿entences. It is a cruell lawe which without offeÌce Å¿ubdueth the free mans chylde to boÌdage. And no leÅ¿Å¿e crueltie is to be thought in ye lawe, whiche without anye deÅ¿erte oppreÅ¿Å¿eth the free womaÌs chylde with boÌdage. Yet the CiuiliaÌs Å¿aye that ye Ciuile lawes in theÅ¿e their iudgemeÌts do excell. For an euil tree Å¿aye they can not brynge furthe good fruites, nor a good tree beare euyll fruites. And by the coÌÅ¿eÌt of all lawes it is agreed that euery plante yeldeth to the nature of ye grouÌde wherein it is planted the chylde alÅ¿o hath muche more certeiÌ & Å¿ure knowlege of ye mother theÌ of ye
father, Whereunto the lawyers of Englande auÌ Å¿wer on this wyÅ¿e: That a child laufully begotten hathe no more certein and Å¿ure knowlege of ye mother then of the father For bothe theÅ¿e laws thê° diÅ¿agreeynge, agree yet in this poynte, that he is the father, whoÌ wedlock declareth. And is it not then more conuenient yt the condicion of the childe Å¿hould haue relation rather to the fathers condicion, then to the mothers. Seynge that Adam Å¿peakiÌge of marryed couples, Å¿aydeâª They Å¿halbe ii. in one fleÅ¿he. which our lord expoundynge in the ghoÅ¿pell Å¿ayethe: Nowe are they not ii. but one fleÅ¿he And forÅ¿omuch as ye malâ as more worthi coÌteineth the
female, then the whole fleÅ¿h Å¿o vnited muÅ¿t haue relation to the male as to the worthyer. wherefore the lorde called Adam & Eue not by the name of Eue, but becauÅ¿e they were bothe one fleÅ¿he, he called them bothe in the name of Adam the man, as it apeareth in ye fifthe chapter of geneÅ¿is. The Ciuile lawes alÅ¿o holde that women do euer gliÅ¿ter with the Å¿hyenynge beames of their huÅ¿baÌds Wherefore in the title begynnynge withe theÅ¿e wordes: Qui Å¿e proÅ¿eÅ¿Å¿ione excuÅ¿ant, in ye nynth boke L. fi. the text Å¿ayeth thus. we auaunce women wt the honoure of their huÅ¿bandes, and with the kiÌ red of their huÅ¿baÌdes we worÅ¿hippe theÌ: in ye court
we decree matters to paÅ¿Å¿e in the name of their huÅ¿bandes, & into ye houÅ¿e and Å¿urname of their huÅ¿bandes do we tranÅ¿late them. But if afterward a woman marrye with a man of baÅ¿er degree, theÌ leÅ¿eth Å¿he her former dignitie, and foloweth the coÌ dicioÌ of her latter huÅ¿baÌd And forÅ¿omuche as all children, Å¿pecially male children bear the fathers name, & not the mothers, whereof then Å¿houlde it coÌe, that ye Å¿onne by reaÅ¿oÌ of the mother Å¿hould leÅ¿e the honour, or chaunge the condicioÌ of the father whoÅ¿e naÌe neuertheleÅ¿Å¿e he Å¿hall Å¿tyll keepe. Specially Å¿eeynge the mother herÅ¿elf receaueth of the Å¿ame father honour, worÅ¿hippe, & dignitie. which honour, worÅ¿hippe, and
dignitie of the huÅ¿bande caÌ neuer be diÅ¿teined or iÌpeached through ye fault of the wyfe. Truely that lawe may well bee demed cruell, which with out any cauÅ¿e coÌmittethe to bondage the free maÌs Å¿onne, and which diÅ¿heritinge the innocent Å¿onne of the iÌnocent free father adiudgeth his laÌde to an vnworthie Å¿traunger: whiche alÅ¿o withe ye baÅ¿e Å¿tate of boÌdage in ye Å¿oÌne defaceth the name of the free father. Cruell alÅ¿o of neceÅ¿Å¿ite muÅ¿t that lawe be compted, which augmenteth thraldom, and diminiÅ¿heth libertie or freedom. For libertie is ye thinge that maÌs nature euer coueteth. For by maÌ & for Å¿ynne did bondage firÅ¿t enter. But freedome is graffed in mans
nature of god. whereof if men be depriued, he is euer diÅ¿ierous to recouer ye Å¿ame agayne, lyke as all other thinges do that are Å¿poiled of their naturall libertie. wherefore wycked and cruell is he to be deemed that fauoureth not libertie. which thiÌges the lawes of England duely conÅ¿ydering, do in all reÅ¿pectes Å¿hew fauour to libertie. And thoughe the Å¿ame lawes iudge hiÌ thrall, whom a boundeman iÌ wedlock begetteth of a free womaÌ, yet here by caÌ not theÅ¿e lawes be reputed Å¿euere and cruel For a woman which by mariage hath Å¿ubmitted herÅ¿elf to a boundeman, is made one fleÅ¿he withe him. wherefore, as ye forÅ¿aid lawes determine, Å¿he
foloweth the Å¿tate of his conditioÌ, and of her owne free wyll hathe made her Å¿elfe a bonde womaÌ, not forced thereto by the law muche lyke to Å¿uch as in kynges courtes become bondemen, or Å¿ell theÌÅ¿elfs into bondage without any compulÅ¿ioÌ at all. And howe then can the lawe determine that childe to be free, whom Å¿uche a mother hathe thus borne. For the huÅ¿band can neuer be in Å¿o much Å¿ubiection to his wyfe, thoughe Å¿he be a right greate ladye, as this womaÌ is Å¿ubiect to the bondeman, whom Å¿he hathe made her lorde: inÅ¿omuche as ye lorde Å¿ayeth to al wifes Thou Å¿halt be vnder the power of thy huÅ¿bonde, & he Å¿hall haue dominion ouer thee. And what is it
that theÅ¿e Ciuilians Å¿aye of the fruite of a good or euyll tree. Is not euerye wyfe of a fre or thral condition accordynge to yâ¢ Å¿tate of her huÅ¿baÌd And in whoÅ¿e ground hathe yt huÅ¿bande planted, while his wyfe is one fleÅ¿he wt him. Not in his owne? And what theÌ if he haue graffed a Å¿lyppe of a Å¿wete nature iÌ a Å¿tock of a Å¿ower tree: So yt ye tre be his owne, Å¿hall not the fruites, thoughe they euÌ Å¿auer of the Å¿tocke, be his owne fruites? So the childe which the wyfe bareth is the huÅ¿bandes iÅ¿Å¿ue, whether the wyfe be free or thrall. Howbeit ye lawes of England decree that if a bonde woman without the coÌÅ¿eÌt of
her lorde bee maryed to a free man, though they can not be deuorced, beecauÅ¿e the ghoÅ¿pell Å¿aieth, whom god hathe conioyned let not man Å¿eperate, yet Å¿hal her lorde recouer agaynÅ¿t the Å¿ame free man all the dammages that hee hathe Å¿uÅ¿teyned by reaÅ¿on of the loÅ¿Å¿e of his vaÅ¿Å¿all or bond woman. This nowe as I Å¿uppoÅ¿e is the Å¿omme and fourm of the law of Englande in the caÅ¿e nowe declared, What therefore is your opinion moÅ¿t excelleÌt prince in the Å¿ame caÅ¿e?
And whether of theÅ¿e two lawes doe you eÅ¿teeme to be of more worthineÅ¿Å¿e & excellencye.

creare poteÅ¿t Å¿eruê°, Que putas leguÌ haruÌ melior eÌ in Å¿eÌteÌtiis Å¿uis? crudelis eÌ lex, qÌ liberi proleÌ Å¿ine culpa Å¿ubdit Å¿eruituti. Ad hec legis Angliae coÌÅ¿ulti dicuÌt: qd, êtê° ex legittimo thoro noÌ certiê° noÅ¿cit matrem quaÌ genitoreÌ Å¿uuÌ NaÌ am bae leges qÌ iam contendunt, vniformiter dicuÌt qd ipÅ¿e eÅ¿t pater, quem nuptiae demoÌÅ¿traÌt. Nunquid tunc magis eÅ¿t coÌ ueniens, vt filii coÌ ditio ad patris potiê° quaÌ ad matris conditionem referatur, cum de coÌ iugatis dixerat AdaÌ? erunt ipÅ¿i duo in carne vna. qd dominê° exponeÌs in euangelio ait: Iam non Å¿uÌt duo Å¿ed vna caro, et cum maÅ¿culinum concipiat femininum,
ad maÅ¿culinuÌ qd dignius eÅ¿t referri debet tota caro Å¿ic facta vna Quare Adam et Euam vocauit dominus, non EuaÌ, Å¿ed quia caro vna ipÅ¿i erant, ambos eos vocauit ipÅ¿e nomine viri, vide licet, Adam: vt patet GeneÅ¿is quinto capitâ. IpÅ¿ae quo
que ciuiles leges dicunt: qd mulieres Å¿emper coruÅ¿caÌt, radiis maritorum Å¿uorum. Vnde. C qui profeÅ¿Å¿ione Å¿e excuÅ¿ant. libro no no .l. fi. textê° Å¿ic loquitur: Mulieres honore maritorum erigimus, et genere nobilitamê°, et foruÌ ex eorum

Vnde tuÌc êuenirâ poterit, qd filiê° ratione matris amitteret honoreÌ, coÌdicionemue patris Å¿ui mutaret, cuius tameÌ nomeÌ ipÌe retinebit, pÌÅ¿ertiÌ duÌ honorâ patris eiuÅ¿deÌ ac conditione reÅ¿plendeat mat

Crudelis neÌpe ceÌ Å¿eretur lex que Å¿ine cauÅ¿a filiuÌ liberi Å¿eruituti coÌmittit, et terraÌ ê qua liber ille iÌnoceÌs a crimine innoceÌtis filii Å¿ui titulo, non Å¿udanti tradet extraneo poÅ¿Å¿ideÌdaÌ, ac patris nomeÌ etiaÌ filii Å¿eruitutis nota coÌmaculat. Crudelis etiaÌ neceÅ¿Å¿ario iudicabitur lex qÌ Å¿eruituteÌ augmentat, et minuit libertateÌ, Nam pro ea natura Å¿emper implorat humana. Quia ab hoÌine et ê vicio iÌtroductâ eÌ Å¿eruitus. Sed libertas

Et licet iura illa iudicent eum Å¿eruuÌ, queÌ Å¿eruus in coniugio ex libera procreauit, non per hoc iura illa rigida, crudeliaue Å¿entire poterunt. Å¿upraÅ¿criptae, eius coÌÅ¿eqÌtur coÌditionem, et êprio arbitrio Å¿e fecit ancillaÌ, Å¿ed potiê° Å¿eruaÌ, nullatenus a lege coacta, qualiter et faciunt qÌ Å¿e Å¿eruos reddunt in curiis reguÌ, vel in Å¿eruituteÌ Å¿e veÌ dunt nullatenus ad hoc compulÅ¿i Quomodo tunc liberuÌ Å¿aÌcire poÅ¿Å¿uÌt leges filium illum, quem mater talis, taliter eÅ¿t enixa? nuÌquaÌ eniÌ Å¿ic Å¿ubiectus eÌ vir vxori, licet maxima domina ipÅ¿a fuerit, vt Å¿ubiecta eÅ¿t libera hec Å¿eruo, queÌ ipÅ¿a fecit dominum eius, dicente domino vxori omni. Eris Å¿ub
poteÅ¿tate viri, et ipÅ¿e dominabitur tuiÌ. Et quid eÅ¿t qd dicunt legiÅ¿toe illi, de fructu arboris boÌae vel maloe. noÌ ne coÌditionis liberoe vel Å¿eruilis eÅ¿t vxor omnis, qualis eÅ¿t maritus eiê°? et in cuiê° Å¿olo plaÌ tauit maritê°, dum vxor eius eÅ¿t Å¿ibi caro vna? Nonne in êprio? quid Å¿i Å¿urculuÌ dulcis naturae inÅ¿eruerit ipÅ¿e Å¿tipiti arboris acerbae: DuÌmodo arbor illa eius eÅ¿t. noÌne fructê° (licet ex Å¿tipite redoleÌt) Å¿eÌê Å¿int fructê° eiê° Sic ex muliere genita êles, mariti eÌ progenies, fuerit mater libera vel aÌ cilla. natiuae a libero iÌ matrimonÌ Å¿uÌptae ipÌo iÌcoÌÅ¿ulto cum eam repudiare nequeat dicente euaÌgelio: quos deus coniunxit, homo noÌ Å¿eperet: re cuperabit verÅ¿us liberum illum, omne damnum quod ipÅ¿e Å¿uÅ¿tinuit ratione deperditi Å¿eruicij, et amiÅ¿Å¿oe ancillae Å¿uae. div.p:
REaÅ¿oÌ Å¿uffereth vs not to doubte, quod ye priÌce but that in this caÅ¿e the lawe of Englande Å¿urmounteth the Romaine lawe. And that lawe is to me more alloweable, which vnto children Å¿heweth fauour rather then rigour. For I remeÌber a rule of the lawe that Å¿ayeth. It is behouable that cruell hate be repreÅ¿Å¿ed, and fauour auauÌced. And good reaÅ¿oÌ, quod ye ChauÌ cellour. Yyet wyl I expÌÅ¿Å¿e vnto you an other caÅ¿e wherein thes lawes are repugnaunt. And Å¿hortly after I wyll make an ende, leaÅ¿t it be tedioê° to you to be troubled wt Å¿o manie diÅ¿agreiÌgs & leaÅ¿t you happeÌ to be weried

PRinceps. Anglorum legeÌ iÌ hoc caÅ¿u, Roma noruÌ lege preÅ¿tare dubitarâ nos racio non permittit. Et optior mihi Å¿eÌ per eÅ¿t lex, quae fauoreÌ, potiê° quam rigoreÌ, êtibus ad miniÅ¿trat. Recolo nam

div.head: Â¶The fowerth caÅ¿e wherein the Å¿aide lawes vary Cap. 44.

div.p:
THe Ciuile lawes commit the tuition of orphanes to the next of their bloud, whether the kinred grow on the fathers Å¿yde or on the mothers Å¿yde, that is to Å¿aye, to euerye man accordynge to the degree and order, wherein his tourne is nexte to Å¿ucceede the pupille in his inhertiauÌce. And the reaÅ¿on of this lawe is that: that no man will beehaue him Å¿elfe more tenderly or more fauourably in the carefull education of the infaunte, thenne hee that is nexte of hys bloude.
Neuertheles the lawes of England touching the cuÅ¿todie of orphanes do determine muche otherwiÅ¿e For there if an inheritauÌ ce beeinge holden in Å¿orage deÅ¿cend to an orphane from anye of the kynred of his fathers Å¿ide, the Å¿ame orphane Å¿hall not be vnder the keeping of any of that kynred, but he Å¿hal be gouerned by his coÅ¿ins or kyneÅ¿folke of his mothers Å¿ide. And if the inheritaunce come to him froÌ anye kineÅ¿man of his mothers Å¿ide, then the pupill with his inheritauÌce Å¿hall bee in the cuÅ¿todie till hee come to lawefull age of hym that is nexte of hys kynne of hys fathers Å¿ide and not of anye kyneÅ¿man of the mothers Å¿yde.
For our lawes Å¿aye, that to commit ye tuition of an iÌfaÌt to him yt Å¿hal next Å¿uccede him, ys lyke as if one Å¿houlde beetake a lambe vnto a woulfe to bee deuoured. Butte if the inheritaunce bee not holden in Å¿ocage, but by knightes feruyce, thenne by the lawes of the Å¿ame lande the childe wythe his inheritaunce Å¿hall bee in the keepinge of none of hys kynred of neyther Å¿yde, but in the cuÅ¿todie of the lorde of the fee vntill hee come to ye age of one and twenty years. And think you that anye man can or will better inÅ¿tructe and trayne vp the childe in feates of armes, whyche bye reaÅ¿on of his tenure he is bouÌd to yeelde to ye lord of his fee, then ye lord hiÌÅ¿elfe,
to whom Å¿uche Å¿eruice is by him due? Whyche is alÅ¿o to bee iudged of more power, and honoure thenne the friendes and kyneÅ¿folkes of his tenant. For hee to the intente hee maye in tyme to come bee the better Å¿erued of hys tenaunte wyll vÅ¿e the more diligence towarde hym. And it is to bee preÅ¿umed that he is more experte and Å¿kylfull to trade him in this thynges, then his other friends rude peraduenture and vnpractiÅ¿ed in martiall feats Å¿peciallye yf his patrimonie bee but Å¿mall. And what can be more profitable for the chylde, whiche by reaÅ¿on of hys tenure Å¿hall in the Å¿eruice of hys lorde endaunger his life,
and all that hee hathe in the actes of chiualrye, theÌ in his nonage to be broughte vppe in the diÅ¿cipline and practiÅ¿e of the Å¿ame, Å¿eeynge that in his rype age hee Å¿hall not bee hable to auoyde the aduenture thereof? And to Å¿aye the truethe it Å¿hall bee no Å¿mall commoditie for the royalme, yt the inhabiters of the Å¿ame be well expert in the knowledge of armes. For as Å¿aieth the philoÅ¿opher, euerye man dothe the thynge boldelye, wherin he aÅ¿Å¿ureth hiÌÅ¿elfe to be Å¿kylfull. And do you not theÌ moÅ¿t noble prince allowe this lawe and coÌ mende it aboue the other now deÅ¿cribed.

LEges Ciuiles impuberum tuÌ telas, proximis de eoruÌ Å¿anguine coÌ mittunt, agnati fuerint Å¿eu cognati, vnicuique videlicet Å¿ecundum gradum et ordinem quo in hereditate pupilli Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿urus eÅ¿t. Et racio legis huius eÅ¿t quia nullus teneriÃ»s fauorabilibÃ»Å¿ue infantem alere Å¿ataget, quam proximus de Å¿anguine eius.
Tamen longe aliter de impuberuÌ cuÅ¿todia Å¿tatuunt leges Angliae. NaÌ ibidem, Å¿i hereditas quae tenetur in Socagio, deÅ¿cendat impuberi ab aliquo agnatoruÌ Å¿uorum, non-erit impubes ille Å¿ub cuÅ¿todia alicuius agnatorum eius. Et Å¿i ex parte cognatoruÌ hereditas Å¿ibi deÅ¿cenderit, pupillus ille cuÌ hereditate Å¿ua ê proximum agnatuÌ et noÌ cognatum eius cuÅ¿todietâ. QuouÅ¿
que ipÌe fuerit adultus.

NaÌ leges illae dicuÌt qdâ coÌmittere tutelaÌ iÌfaÌtis illi qÌ eÅ¿t eiÌ proximÃ¨ Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿urê°, eÅ¿t quaÅ¿i agnuÌ coÌmittere lupo ad deuoraÌduÌ. Sed Å¿i hereditas illa non in Å¿ocagio, Å¿ed teneatur ê Å¿eruiciuÌ militaâ, tuÌc ê leges terrae illiê°, iÌfaÌs ipÅ¿e et hereditas eiê°, noÌ ê agnatos ne
que cognatos, Å¿ed per dnÌm feodi illiê° cuÅ¿todieÌ tur, quouÅ¿
que ipÌe fuerit etatis vigiÌti et vnius aÌnoruÌ. Quis putas infanteÌ taleÌ in actibus bellicis quos facere ratioÌe tenurae Å¿uae ipÅ¿e aÅ¿tringitur dnÌo feodi Å¿ui, meliê° inÅ¿truere poterit, aut velit quam dnÌs ille,
eui ab eo Å¿eruicium tale debetur? et qui maioris potentiae et honoris eÅ¿timatur. qÌ Å¿unt alij amici et êpinqÌ tenentis Å¿ui? IpÅ¿e naÌ
que , vt Å¿ibi ab eodeÌ tenente melius Å¿eruiatur, diligentem curam adhibebit, et melius in his euÌ erudire expertus eÅ¿Å¿e cenÅ¿etur, quam reliqui amici iuuenis, rudes forÅ¿aÌ et armoruÌ inexperti, maxime Å¿i noÌ magnuÌ fuerit patrimoniuÌ eius. Et quid vtilius eÅ¿t infanti qui vitam et omnia Å¿ua periculis bellicis exponet in Å¿eruicio domini Å¿ui ratioÌe tenurae Å¿uae,
quam in militia actubuÅ¿que bellicis imbui, dumminor eÅ¿t, cum actus huiuÅ¿modi ipÅ¿e in etate matura declinare non poterit. Et reuera non minime erit regno accomodum, vt incolae eius in armis Å¿int experti. Nam vt dicit Philo. audacter quilibet facit, qdâ Å¿e Å¿cire ipÅ¿e non defidit. Nunquid tunc legem hanc tu approbas fili regis, et collaudas Å¿uper legem alteram iam deÅ¿criptam.

div.head: Â¶Here the prince commeÌdeth the education of noble mens children beinge orphanes. Cap. 45.

div.p:
YEs good Chauncelour, quod ye priÌce, this lawe I do allowe much more theÌ the other. For in the firÅ¿te parte of it whiche you noted, it prouideth much more waryly for the securitie and Å¿aufegarde of the pupill, then the Ciuile lawe dothe. Howbeit in the Å¿econde parte of the Å¿ame I do take more delyte. For thereof it comethe to paÅ¿Å¿e that in Englande noble mens chyldren canne not eaÅ¿elye degenerate, butte rather paÅ¿Å¿e and Å¿urmouÌt theire aunceÅ¿tours in vertue, in courage, and in honeÅ¿t condicions, forÅ¿omuche as theye are broughte vp & inÅ¿tructed in an higher & an honorabler court,
thenne in the houÅ¿es of theire parentes, thoughe theire parents weare paraduenture broughte vppe in the lyke places. For theire parents houÅ¿e was neuer yet lyke the lordes houÅ¿e, whome aÅ¿well the parentes, as allÅ¿o the children Å¿erued. The princes allÅ¿o of the royalme beeynge ruled bye thys lawe, and lykewyÅ¿e other lordes holdynge theyre lande immedyatlye of the kynge, canne not lightlye fall to wantonnes and vnÅ¿eemelynes, Å¿eeynge that in theire childehoode, whyle theye bee orphanes they are broughte vppe in the kynges houÅ¿e. Wherefore I muÅ¿te needes highelye prayÅ¿e & coÌmeÌ
â¢â¢ ye ryches,
and high porte of the kinges court, in that it is the chiefeÅ¿t Å¿chole within the royalme for the nobilitye of the lande. It is alÅ¿o the Å¿cholehouÅ¿e of manhoode, of vertue, and of good maners, wherby the royalm is honored and flouriÅ¿heth and is preÅ¿erued againÅ¿te inuaÅ¿ions: Å¿o yt it is dreaded bothe of friendes and foes. And to bee plain this greate commoditie coulde not haue happened to the royalme, yf noble mens children beeinge orphans and pupilles hadde beene nouriÅ¿hed and brought vp by the poore friendes of their parentes. Neyther canne this bee preiudicial or hurtefull to the wealthe of the royalme, that the children of burgeÅ¿es,
and of other freeholders, whiche holde theire tenementes in Å¿ocage, and are not thereby bound to warfare, are brought vp in the houÅ¿es of their like friendes, as to him yt Å¿hall thoroughly weigh the mater it may euidently appeare.

PRinceps. Immo Cancellarie legem hanc, pluÅ¿quaÌ alteram, ego laudo. Nam in eius parte prima, quam tu notaÅ¿ti, cautÃ¨ magis quam ciuilis ipÅ¿a prouidet Å¿ecuritati pupilli. Sed tamen in eius parte Å¿ecunda, multo magis ego delector. Nam ab ea eÅ¿t quod in Anglia, nobilium progenies de facili degenerari nonpoteÅ¿t, Å¿ed probitate potius, Å¿trenuitate, et morum honeÅ¿tate anteceÅ¿Å¿ores Å¿uos ipÅ¿a tranÅ¿cendet, dum in altiori, nobiliorique curia,
quaÌ in domo parentum illa Å¿it imbuta, licet indomo conÅ¿imili forÅ¿an parentes eius educati erant: Quia conÅ¿imilis adhuc non erat, domus parentum illorum domui dominorum, quibus ipÌi parentes et ipÅ¿i infaÌ te â¢ Å¿eruierunt.

Principes quoque regni Å¿ub hac lege regulati, Å¿imiliter et domini alii a rege iÌmediate teneÌ tes, non poÅ¿Å¿uÌt deleui in laÅ¿ciuiam ruditat en â¢ ie l â¢ bi, cum in pueritiadum orphani fuerint ipÅ¿i, in domo regia nutriuntur. Quare non iÌnmo
domus regiae opulentiaÌ magnitudineÌ
que collaudo, duÌ in ea ginpnaÅ¿iuÌ Å¿upremuÌ, Å¿it nobilitatê­ regnÌ Scholaquo que Å¿trenuitatis, êbitatis et moruÌ quibus regnum honoratur, et florebit, ac contra irruentes Å¿ecuratur, etiaÌ formido ipÅ¿a erit inimicis et amicis regni. Hoc reuera bonuÌ accidiÅ¿Å¿e noÌ potuiÅ¿Å¿et regno illi, Å¿i nobilium filij, orphani et pupilli, per pauperes amicos parentum Å¿uorum nutrirentur. Nec regni bono officere poteÅ¿t, licet burgeÌ tium filij et alioruÌ libere tenentium
qÌ in Å¿ocagio teneÌt tenemeÌta Å¿ua, quo ipÌi ad militiaÌ non aÅ¿tringuÌtur, in domo conÅ¿imiliuÌ amicoruÌ Å¿uoruÌ educantur vt êÅ¿picuÃ¨ conÅ¿ideraÌti lucidÃ¨ apparere poteÅ¿t.

div.head: Â¶Yet he rehearÅ¿eth other caÅ¿e â¢ wherein the forÅ¿aid lawes differ. Cap. 46

div.p:
THere bee yette diuers other caÅ¿es, quod the Chaunceloure, wherin the lawes aforeÅ¿ayde do varye. As in that the Ciuile lawes do iudge open thefte to bee Å¿atiÅ¿fied by the recompence of fower folde, & priuye thefte by the recompence of double. Butte the lawes of
Englande Å¿uffer neither of thoÅ¿e offences to be more fauorablye puniÅ¿hed then wyth the offendours deathe, Å¿o that the value of the thynge Å¿tolen bee aboue the value of twelue peÌ ce. AlÅ¿o a libertine that is to Å¿aye, a free man that Å¿ometyme was bonde, yf hee beecome vnkynde or churliÅ¿he, the Ciuile lawes reduce hym into hys former Å¿tate of Å¿eruitude againe. But by the lawes of Englande he that is once made free, be hee grate or ingrate, is aiudged to enioye his freedome Å¿tyll. There be other like caÅ¿es allÅ¿o not a fewe, whyche at thys tyme for breuities Å¿ake I ouerpaÅ¿Å¿e. Neither in theÅ¿e twoo caÅ¿es doe I diÅ¿pute the excellencye of the foreÅ¿ayde lawes,
Å¿eeynge the qualities of theÌ requier no great Å¿earche. And I doubte not but the quicknes of your witte is Å¿uche, yt it can Å¿ufficieÌtly diÅ¿cuÅ¿Å¿e the Å¿ame.

TVnc CaÌcellariê°. SuÌt et alij caÅ¿us noÌnulli iÌ quibus differuÌt leges antedictae, Vt qia legê­ Ciuiles iudicaÌt furtuÌ manifeÅ¿tuÌ ê reddicioÌeÌ quadrupli, et furtuÌ noÌ manifeÅ¿tuÌ, ê dupli recoÌpenÅ¿ationeÌ expiari. Sed leges
Angliae, neutrum facinorum illoruÌ mitius quam committentis morte puniri permittunt dummodo ablati valor duodecim denarioruÌ valoreÌ excedat. IteÌ libertinum ingratum leges ciuiles in priÅ¿tinaÌ rediguÌt Å¿eruitutem: Å¿ed leges Angliae Å¿emel manumiÅ¿Å¿uÌ, Å¿emper liberum iudicant gratum et ingratum. Alij quoque Å¿unt caÅ¿us huiuÅ¿ce modi non pauci, quos iam Å¿tudio breuitatis pretereo Et ne
que in hijs duobus caÅ¿ibus predictarum legum preÅ¿tancias ego iaÌ deÅ¿cribo, cum noÌ maguÌ Å¿it iÌdaginis
eorum qualitates nec diffido ingenij tui Å¿olerciam eas Å¿ufficieÌter poÅ¿Å¿e rimari.

div.head: Â¶The prince regardethe not the caÅ¿es nowe rehearÅ¿ed. Cap. 47.

div.p:
NO nor it booteth not good Chauncelloure herein muche to tarye, quod the prince. For though in Englande aÅ¿well open as pryuy theeues are commenlye putte to deathe, yette ceaÅ¿Å¿e they not there from Å¿tealynge, as thoughe theye hadde no feare of Å¿o greate a puniÅ¿hemente. Howe much leÅ¿Å¿e then would they wt holde their haÌds froÌ thefte
if thei foreÅ¿aw once yt ye puniÅ¿hmeÌt were mitigated? And godde forbid that hee whyche once hathe eÅ¿caped miÅ¿erable Å¿eruitude Å¿hould euer after tremble and quake at the threatnynges of bondage, Å¿peciallye vnder the coloure of ingratitude or vnkindnes Å¿eeynge the kyndes of ingratitude are Å¿o manye that they can Å¿kante well be numbred: and mans nature in the cauÅ¿e of liberty or freedome more then in other cauÅ¿es requireth fauour. Wherefore at thys tyme, good Chauncellour I beÅ¿eeche you hartelye medle no more withe the examination of any Å¿uche caÅ¿es. But now explane & opeÌ vnto me why ye laws of England being Å¿o good
Å¿o fruitefull, and Å¿o commodious, are not taughte in the vniuerÅ¿ities, as the Ciuile and Cannon lawes are, and whye in the Å¿ame none are commenced bachelers and doctors as in other faculties and Å¿ciences it is accuÅ¿tomed.

PRinceps. Nec expedit Cancellarie in hijs multum Å¿uadere quia licet in Anglia, fures clandeÅ¿tini et manifeÅ¿ti paÅ¿Å¿im morti plectantur, non ceÅ¿Å¿ant ipÅ¿i ibidem omnino pÌ dari ac Å¿i penam tantam illiminime formidarent. QuaÌ to tunc minus Å¿e abÅ¿tinereÌt a crimiÌe
si penam preuiderent mitiorem? Et abÅ¿it a Å¿eruitute Å¿emel euaÅ¿um, Å¿emper deinde Å¿ub minis tremere Å¿eruitutis, maxime ingratitudinis colore, cum ingratitudinum Å¿pecies, vix poterint pre multitudine numerari et humana natura in libertatis cauÅ¿a, fauorem Å¿emper magis quam in cauÅ¿is alijs deprecetur. Sed iam Cancellarie, obnixÃ¨ te imploro, vt amodo amiÅ¿Å¿Ã³ plurium caÅ¿uum huiuÅ¿modi examine, michi edicas, quare leges Angliae tam bonae, frugi, et optabiles in
vniuerÅ¿itatibus noÌ doceÌtur, vt Ciuiles Å¿imiliter et canonuÌ leges: et quare in eiÅ¿deÌ noÌ dantur baccalariatus et doctoratus gradus vt in alijs facultatibê° et Å¿cieÌtijs eÅ¿t dari coÌÅ¿uetum.

div.head: Â¶Here the Chauncelour Å¿heweth why the lawes of Englande are not taughte in the vniuerÅ¿ities. Cap. 48.

div.p:
In the vniuerÅ¿ities of Englande, quod the Chauncellour, Å¿cieÌces are not taughte butte in the latine tonge. And the lawes of that land are to be learned in three Å¿euerall tonges, to wytte, in the EngliÅ¿h tongue, ye french toÌgue, & ye latine tongue.
In the EngliÅ¿he tongue, becauÅ¿e that law is moÅ¿te vÅ¿ed, and longeÅ¿t continued amongeÅ¿t the EngliÅ¿h men. In the Frenche tongue, beecauÅ¿e that after the French menne vnder William the conquerer of Englande hadde obteyned the lande, they Å¿uffred not theire men of lawe to pleade their cauÅ¿es, but in the tongue whi â¢ he theye knewe, and Å¿o doe all the men of lawe in Fraunce yea in the courÅ¿e of parliament there. LykewiÅ¿e the Frenchemen after theire coÌmyng into EnglaÌd receaued not the accoÌptes of their reuenues, but iÌ their own language, leaÅ¿t theye Å¿hould be deceaued therin Neither had they delyte to hunte, & to excerciÅ¿e other Å¿portes & paÅ¿times, as diceplaye,
and the hand balle, but in their owne proper tonge. Wherfore ye EngliÅ¿he meÌ by much vÅ¿ing of their coÌpanie, grewe in Å¿uche a êfectnes of the Å¿ame language, ye at this day in Å¿uche playes & accomptes they vÅ¿e the Frenche tongue. And theye weare wonte to pleade in Frenche, tyll by force of a certeine Å¿tatute that manner was muche reÅ¿treyned. But it could neuer hether to be whollye aboliÅ¿hed, aÅ¿wel by reaÅ¿on of certein termes, whiche pleaders do more properly expreÅ¿Å¿e in Frenche, then in EngliÅ¿he, as allÅ¿o for that declarations â¢ ppon originall wryttes can not bee pronounced Å¿o agreably to the nature of thoÅ¿e writtes as in Frenche.
And vnder the Å¿ame Å¿peeche the fourmes of Å¿uche declaracions are learned. Moreouer all pleas, argueynges, and iudgementes paÅ¿Å¿ed in the kings courts and entred into bookes for the inÅ¿truction of them that Å¿hall come after, are euer more reported in the Frenche tongue. Manye Å¿tatutes alÅ¿o of that royalme are writen in Frenche. Whereof it happeneth that the commeÌ Å¿peeche nowe vÅ¿ed in FrauÌce agreethe not, nor is not lyke the Frenche vÅ¿ed amonge the lawyers of Englande, butte is by a certeine rudenes of the coÌ mon people corrupte.

Which corruptioÌ of Å¿pech chaunceth not in ye FreÌch
that is vÅ¿ed in England, for Å¿o much as that Å¿pech is there oftener written then Å¿poken. Now in the thirde of the Å¿aide iii. tongues, whiche is the latine tongue are written all writtes originall and iudiciall: and likewiÅ¿e all the recordes of plees in the kinges courtes, withe certeine Å¿tatutes alÅ¿o.

Wherefore while ye lawes of England are lerned in theÅ¿e three tonges, they cannot conueniently be taught or Å¿tudyed in ye vniuerÅ¿ities, where onlye ye latine tongue is exerciÅ¿ed. NotwtÅ¿tandinge the Å¿ame lawes are taught & learned in a certein place of publique or comen Å¿tudy more coÌuenient & apte for attaining to ye knowledge of them, then anye other vniuerÅ¿itie.

For this place of Å¿tudy is Å¿ituate nighe to ye kingez courtes where the Å¿ame lawes are pleaded and argued, & iudgementes by the Å¿ame geeuen by iudges menne of grauytie, auncient in yeares, perfecte and graduate in the Å¿ame lawes. Wherefore euery daye in courte the Å¿tudentes in thoÅ¿e lawes reÅ¿orte by greate numbers vnto thoÅ¿e courtes, wherein the Å¿ame lawes are redde & taught as it were in coÌmon Å¿choles.

This place of Å¿tudy is Å¿et betwene ye place of ye Å¿aid courtz & ye Citie of LoÌdoÌ, which of al thiÌgs neceÅ¿Å¿arie is ye pleÌtifulleÅ¿t of all ye cities & towns of ye realm So yt ye Å¿aid place of Å¿tudy is not Å¿ituate wtin ye citie,
where the confluence of people might diÅ¿turbe the quietnes of the Å¿tudentes but Å¿omewhat Å¿eueral in the Å¿uburbes of the Å¿ame Citie, and nigher to the Å¿aide courtes, that the Å¿tudentes maye daylye at theire pleaÅ¿ure haue acceÅ¿Å¿e and recourÅ¿e thether without wearines.

CAncellariê°. In vniuerÅ¿itatibus Angliae non docentur Å¿cientiae niÅ¿i in latina lingua: et leges terrae illius in triplici lingua, addiÅ¿cuntur, videlicet Anglica, Gallica, et Latina.
Anglica, quia inter Anglos lex illa maxime inoleuit. Gallica, quia poÅ¿tquam galli, duce VVilhelmo Angliae conqueÅ¿tore terraÌ illaÌ optinueruÌt, noÌ êmiÅ¿erunt ipÅ¿i eoruÌ aduocatos placitare cauÅ¿as Å¿uas, niÅ¿i in lingua quaÌ ipÅ¿i nouerunt, qualiter et faciuÌt oÌeÌs aduocati in FraÌcia etiaÌ in curia parliameÌti ibideÌ. CoÌÅ¿imiliter gallici poÅ¿t eoruÌ adueÌ tuÌ in AngliaÌ, ratiocinia de eoruÌ prouentibus non receperunt, niÅ¿i in proprio idiomate ne ipÅ¿i inde decipereÌtâ.
