que ipÅ¿i iÌ ludis hmÌodi et coÌpotis, linquaÌ loquuntur gallicanaÌ et placitare in eadeÌ liÌgua Å¿oliti fueruÌt quouÅ¿que mos ille, vigore cuiuÅ¿daÌ Å¿tatutiÌ quaÌ plurimum reÅ¿trictê° eÌ, t â¢
Ì in toto hucuÅ¿
que aboler â¢ noÌ potuit tuÌ êpter termiÌos quoÅ¿daÌ, quos plê° êprie placitantes in gallico, quaÌ in Anglico exprimuÌt, tuÌc qÌa declaratioÌes Å¿uê breuiae originalia, taÌ coÌuenieÌtâ ad naturaÌ breuiuÌ illoruÌ ênuÌciari neqÌuÌt vt iÌ gallicÌ
Å¿ub quali Å¿ermone declarationuÌ huiuÅ¿modi formulae addiÅ¿cuntur. ReportaÌtur etiaÌ ea qÌ in curijs regijs placitantur, diÅ¿putantur, et iudicantur ac in libros ad futuroruÌ
â¢ ruditioneÌ rediguÌtur, in Å¿ermone Å¿emper gallico. QuaÌ plurima etiaÌ Å¿tatuta regni illius in gallico coÌ Å¿cribuÌtur. Vnde accidit qdâ lingua iaÌ in Francia vulgaris, non concordat aut conÅ¿imilis eÅ¿t gallico inter legis peritos Angliae vÅ¿itato, Å¿ed vulgari quadam ruditate corrupta. Quod fieri non accidit in Å¿ermone gallico
infra AngliaÌ vÅ¿itato, cuÌ Å¿it Å¿ermo ille ibideÌ Å¿epius Å¿criptê° quaÌ locutus. Sub tertia vero linguaruÌ predictaruÌ, vz Å¿ub latina, oiÌa breuia originalia & iudicialia, Å¿imiliter et oiÌa recorda placitoruÌ in curiis reguÌ, etiaÌ et qÌdaÌ Å¿tatuta Å¿cribuÌtâ. Quare duÌ leges Angliae in his tribus addifcuÌtâ linguis, ipÅ¿ae in vniuerÅ¿itatibê° vbi Å¿oluÌ latina excercetâ lingua, coÌuen â¢
eÌter erudiri noÌ poteruÌt aut Å¿tuderi. Leges tnÌ illae, iÌ quodaÌ Å¿tudio publico ê illaruÌ appreheÌÅ¿ione (oiÌ vniuÌÅ¿itate coÌuenieÌtiore et êniore) doceÌtâ et ad diÅ¿cuÌtâ

StudiuÌ naÌ
que iÅ¿tud, Å¿itum eÅ¿t prope curiam regis, vbi leges illae placitaÌtâ diÅ¿putaÌtur, et iudicia ê eaÅ¿deÌ redduÌ tur, ê Iudices, viros graues, Å¿enes, iÌ legibê° illis peritos et graduatos. quÃ´ iÌ curâ illis ad quas oiÌ die placitabili coÌfluuÌt Å¿tudeÌtes in legibus illis, qua Å¿i iÌ Å¿colis publicis leges illae leguntur et docentâ. Situatâ etiaÌ Å¿tudium illud inter locuÌ CuriaruÌ illaruÌ, et ciuitateÌ LoÌdonÌ, qÌ de oiÌ bus neceÅ¿Å¿ariis opuleÌtiÅ¿Å¿imÌ eÅ¿t, oiÌuÌ ciuitatuÌ et opidoruÌ regni illiê°. Nec in ciuitate illa vbi coÌfluentiuÌ turba,
Å¿tudentium quieteÌ perturbare poÅ¿Å¿it Å¿itum eÅ¿t Å¿tudium iÅ¿tud, Å¿ed Å¿eorÅ¿um parumper, in ciuitatis illius Å¿uburbio, et proprius Curiis predictis, vt ad eas Å¿ine fagiagionis iÌ coÌmodo, Å¿tudentes indies ad libitum accedere valeant.

div.head: Â¶Here he declareth the diÅ¿poÅ¿ition of the general Å¿tudy of the lawes of Englande, and that the Å¿ame in nomber of Å¿tudentes paÅ¿Å¿eth certein vniuerÅ¿ities. Cha. 49.

div.p:
BVt to ye intent moÅ¿t excelleÌt prince ye maye conceaue a fourme & an ymage of this Å¿tudy, as I am able I will diÅ¿cribe it vntoo you. For there bee in it tenne leÅ¿Å¿er houÅ¿ez or ynnes, & Å¿omtimes moe,
whyche are called ynnes of the Chauncery. And to euerie one of them belongeth a C. Å¿tudients at the leaÅ¿t, & to Å¿ome of them a muche greater nomber, though they bee not euer all together in the Å¿ame. TheÅ¿e Å¿tudentes, for the moÅ¿t part of theÌ, are yongmen, lerning or Å¿tudying ye originals, & as it were ye elements of ye law. who profiting therein, as they growe to rypenes, Å¿o are they admitted into ye greater ynnes of the Å¿ame Å¿tudy, called ynnes of court. Of the whiche greater ynnes there are .iiii. in number. And to the leÅ¿t of them beelongeth in fourme aboue mentioned twooe hundrethe Studentes or theareaboutes.

For in theÅ¿e greter ynnez there can no Å¿tudient bee mainteined for leÅ¿Å¿e expeÌ Å¿es by the yeare then xx. markes. And if he haue a Å¿eruaunt to waite vppon him, as moÅ¿te of theÌ haue then Å¿o muche the greater will his charges be. Now be reaÅ¿on of this charges the children onelye of noble menne doo Å¿tudye the lawes in thoÅ¿e ynnes.

For the poore and commen Å¿orte of the people are not hable to beare Å¿o greate charges for the exhibition of theire children And marchaunt menne can Å¿eeledoome fynde in theire heartes to hynder theire marchandiÅ¿e with Å¿o greate yerly expenÅ¿es. And thus it falleth out yt there is Å¿cant any manne founde within ye roialme
Å¿kilfull and connynge in the lawes, excepte hee bee a gentleman borne, and come of a noble Å¿tocke.

Wherefore they more then anye other kinde of menne haue a Å¿pecial regarde to theire nobilitie, and too the preÅ¿eruation of theire honour & fame And to Å¿peake vprightly there is in theÅ¿e greater ynnes, yea and in the leÅ¿Å¿er too, beÅ¿yde the Å¿tudy of the lawes, as it were an vniuerÅ¿itie or Å¿chole of all commendable qualities requiÅ¿ite for noble men. There they learne to Å¿inge, and to exerciÅ¿e themÅ¿elfes in all kinde of armony. There alÅ¿o they practiÅ¿e daunÅ¿ing, and other noble mennes paÅ¿times, as they vÅ¿e to doe
which are brought vppe in the kinges houÅ¿e.

On the woorkyedayes the moÅ¿te parte of them applye themÅ¿elues to the Å¿tudye of the lawe. And on the holyedayes to the Å¿tudie of holye Å¿cripture: and out of the tyme of diuine Å¿eruice to the readynge of chronicles. For there in deed are vertues Å¿tudyed, and all vices exiled. So that for the endowement of vertue, and abandoning of vice Knightes and Barons, with other Å¿tates and noble menne of the roialme place theire children in thoÅ¿e ynnes, though they deÅ¿ire not to haue them learned in the lawes, nor to lyue by the practiÅ¿e therof, but only vpoÌ their fathers allowaunce.

Skante at anye tyme ys there harde among them any Å¿edition, chydynge or grudginge. And yet the offendours are puniÅ¿hed with none other paine, but onelye to be amoued from the coÌpany of their felowÅ¿hippe. Whiche puniÅ¿hement they doe more feare, then other criminal offenders doe feare impriÅ¿onment and yrons.

For hee that is ones expelled froÌ any of thoÅ¿e felowÅ¿hips is neuer receaued to be a fellow in any of the other felowÅ¿hippes And Å¿o by this meanes there is coÌtinual peace: & theire demeanour is like the behauiour of Å¿uche as are coupled together in êfect amitie. But after what manner & Å¿orte the
lawes are learned iÌ thoÅ¿e ynnes, thereof heere too make reherÅ¿all, it is not needeful, forÅ¿omuche as it is not for your eÅ¿tat moÅ¿t noble Prince to putte the Å¿ame in vre. Yet knowe ye this, that it is pleaÅ¿ant and delectable, and in any wiÅ¿e expedient for the learninge of the law, and worthy with all affection to bee embraced. But one thiÌg ther is that I would haue you to knowe, that neyther at Orleaunce, where aÅ¿wel the Canon as the Ciuyle lawes are taughte, and whether out of manye Countreys Å¿cholars doe repayre, nor at Angeo, or at Cane, or any vniuerÅ¿ity of France (Paris onelye excepted) are founde Å¿o many Å¿tudentes paÅ¿t chyldhoode,
as in this place of Å¿tudye, notwtÅ¿tanding yt al ye Å¿tudeÌtes there are EngliÅ¿he borne.

SEd vt tibi conÅ¿tet, princeps huius Å¿tudii forma & ymago, illaÌ vt valeo iaÌ diÅ¿cribaÌ. SuÌt naÌ
que iÌ eo deceÌ hoÅ¿ picÌ minorâ et quaÌ do
que vero plura,
quae nominantur hoÅ¿pitia CaÌcellarâ ad quoruÌ quodlibet êtineÌt centum Å¿tudentes ad minê° et ad aliqua eoruÌ maior iÌ multo numerus, licet noÌ oeÌs Å¿emê in eis Å¿imul coÌueniaÌt. Å¿tudeÌtes etenim iÅ¿ti ê eoruÌ parte maiori, iuuenes Å¿uÌt, originalia et quaÅ¿i legis elemeÌta addiÅ¿centes, qui in illis êficientes, vt ipÅ¿i matureÅ¿cunt, ad maiora hoÅ¿pitia Å¿tudij illiê° quae hoÅ¿pitia curiae appellantur, aÅ¿Å¿umuÌtur. QuoruÌ ma ioruÌ quatuor Å¿unt in numero, & adminimuÌ eorum, êtineÌt in forma pre notata, duceÌti Å¿tudeÌtes aut propeâª

In his enim maioribus hoÅ¿piciis, nequaquaÌ poteÅ¿t Å¿tudens aliquis Å¿uÅ¿teÌ tari minoribus expeÌÅ¿is in anno, quaÌ octoginta Å¿cutoruÌ et Å¿i Å¿eruienteÌ Å¿ibi ipÅ¿e ibideÌ habuerit, vt eoruÌ habet pluralitas, tanto tunc maiores ipÅ¿e Å¿uÅ¿tinebit expeÌÅ¿as. OccaÅ¿ione vero Å¿uÌptuuÌ huiuÅ¿modi tmÌ ipÅ¿i nobilium filij in hoÅ¿pitiis illis leges addiÅ¿cuÌt. Cum pauperes et vulgares, pro filio ruÌ Å¿uoruÌ exhibitione taÌtos Å¿uÌptê° neqÌant Å¿ufferre. Et mercatores raro cupiaÌt taÌtis onÌibê° annuis, attenuare mercaÌdiÅ¿as Å¿uas.

Quo fit, vt vix doctus in legibus illis reperiatur in regno, qui non Å¿it nobilis et de nobilium genere egreÅ¿Å¿us. Vnde magis aliis conÅ¿imilis Å¿tatus hominibê°, ipÅ¿i nobilitatem curant et conÅ¿eruationeÌ honoris & famae Å¿uae. In his reuera hoÅ¿piciis maioribus, etiam et minoribus vltra Å¿tudium legum, eÅ¿t quaÅ¿i gimnaÅ¿ium omnium morum qui nobiles decent. Ibi caÌtare ipÅ¿i addiÅ¿cunt, Å¿imiliter et Å¿e excercent in omni genere harmoniae. Ibi etiam tripudiare ac iocos Å¿ingulos nobilibus
coÌuenientes, qualiter in domo regia excercere Å¿oleÌt enutriti, in feri alibus diebê° eoruÌ pars maior legalis diÅ¿ciplinae Å¿tudio, et in feÅ¿tiualibus Å¿acrae Å¿cripturae, et cronicaruÌ lectioni poÅ¿t diuina obÅ¿equia Å¿e coÌfert Ibi quippe diÅ¿ciplina virtutuÌ eÅ¿t, et vicioruÌ oiÌm relegatio Ita vt êpter virtutis adquiÅ¿itioneÌ vicij etiaÌ fugaÌ milites, barones, alii quo
que magnates et nobiles regni, iÌ hoÅ¿piciis illis ponuÌt filios Å¿uos, quaÌ uis noÌ gliÅ¿caÌt eos leguÌimbui diÅ¿ciplina, nec eiê° exercitio viuere, Å¿ed Å¿oluÌ ex patrociniis Å¿uis.
Ibi vix vnquam Å¿editio, iurgium, aut murmur reÅ¿onat, et tamen delinquentes non alia pena, quam Å¿olum a communione Å¿ocietatis Å¿uae amoci one plectuntur, quia penam hanc ipÅ¿i plus formidaÌt quaÌ criminoÅ¿i alibi carcerem timeÌt aut vincula, nam Å¿emel ab vna Å¿ocietatuÌ illaruÌ expulÅ¿us, nuÌquaÌ ab aliqua ceterarâ Å¿ocietatum earundeÌ recipitâ in Å¿ocium quo ibi pax eÅ¿t continua et quaÅ¿i amicitia coniunctorum eÅ¿t eorum omnium conuerÅ¿atio. Formam vero qua leges illae in his diÅ¿cuntur
hoÅ¿piciis, hic exprimere non expedit, cum tibi princeps eam experiri non liceat. Scito tamen quod delectabilis ipÅ¿a eÅ¿t, et omni modo expediens legis illius diÅ¿ciplinae, omni quoque affectione digna. Vnum tamen te Å¿cire deÅ¿idero, quod ne
que durelianis vbi tam Canones addiÅ¿cuntur, quam Ciuiles leges, et quÃ´ a quam pluribê° regionibê° coÌfluunt Å¿colares, ne
que An daganis, aut iÌ Cadamo, aliaue vniuerÅ¿itate Franciae, preterquaÌ Å¿olum PariÅ¿iis, reperiuntâ tot Å¿tudentes infantiam euaÅ¿i:
Å¿icut iÌ hoc Å¿tudio licet ibi addiÅ¿ceÌtes oeÌs Å¿olum ab Anglia Å¿int oriuÌdi.

div.head: Â¶Of the eÅ¿tate and degree af a Seriant at lawe, & howe he is ereated, Cap. 50.

div.p:
BVt forÅ¿omuch as you deÅ¿ier to knowe, moÅ¿t gracious PriÌce, for what cauÅ¿e the degrees of bachelars and doctours are not geeuen in the lawes of Englande, as they are accuÅ¿tomablye geeuen in bothe lawes within vniuerÅ¿ities, youre maieÅ¿tie Å¿hall vnderÅ¿tande that though theÅ¿e degrees are not geeuen in the lawes of England, yet there is geeuen in them not a degree only, but alÅ¿o a Å¿tate no leÅ¿Å¿e worÅ¿hipfull and Å¿olempne then the degree
of doctours: which is called the degree of a Seriant at lawe. And it is geuen vnder the manner & fourme fo â¢ owyng. The lorde chiefe IuÅ¿tice of the commen benche by ye couÌ Å¿ell and aÅ¿Å¿ent of all the IuÅ¿tices vÅ¿ethe as ofte as he thinketh good to choÅ¿e vii. or .viii. of the diÅ¿creeteÅ¿t perÅ¿ones, that in the foreÅ¿aide generall Å¿tudye haue moÅ¿t profited in the lawes, and whiche to the Å¿ame IuÅ¿ticez are thought to bee of beÅ¿t diÅ¿poÅ¿ition, and their names hee preÅ¿enteth to the lord Chancellour of Englande in writtynge. Who incontinent by vertue of the kinges write Å¿hal charge euery of the êÅ¿ons elect to be beefore the kinge at a daye by hym aÅ¿Å¿igned,
too take vppon him the Å¿tate and degree of a Å¿erieaunt at lawe, vnder a greate penaltie in euerye of the Å¿aid writtes limitted. On the whiche daye euery one of them appearing Å¿halbe Å¿worne vpoÌ the holye goÅ¿pell of God to be ready at the daye & place then to bee appointed to receaue the Å¿tate and degree aforeÅ¿aide, and that he the Å¿ame daye Å¿hall geeue golde accordynge to the cuÅ¿tome in that behalfe vÅ¿ed.

Howe bee it howe and after what Å¿orte euerye of the Å¿aide choÅ¿en perÅ¿ones Å¿hall that daye demeane himÅ¿elfe, and alÅ¿o the fourme and maner howe that Å¿tate & degree Å¿halbee geuen & receued,
forÅ¿omuche as the Å¿ame can not Å¿o briefelye bee written as to the Å¿hortnes of this woorke is requiÅ¿ite, therefore at thys tyme, I will leaue theÅ¿e pointes vntouched. And yet I haue declared the Å¿ame to you ere nowe by waye of talke. But thys you muÅ¿t vnderÅ¿tande, that when the day appoiÌ ted is come, thoÅ¿e electe perÅ¿ons among other Å¿olemnities muÅ¿t keepe a greate dinner, like to the feaÅ¿t of a kinges coronation, which Å¿hal continue & laÅ¿t by ye Å¿pace of Å¿euen daies. And none of thoÅ¿e elect êÅ¿ones Å¿hall defraye ye charges growinge to him about ye coÅ¿tes of this Å¿olempnitie with leÅ¿Å¿e expenÅ¿es then the Å¿umme of foure huÌdreth markes
So that ye expeÌÅ¿es whiche viii. menne Å¿o electe Å¿hall then beeÅ¿towe will Å¿urmount the Å¿umme of thre thouÅ¿ande and two hundreth ma â¢ ks. Of ye which expenÅ¿es one parcel Å¿hall bee this. Euery of them Å¿hal geue ringes of golde to ye value of xl. poundes Å¿terling at the leaÅ¿t. And your Chauncellour well remeÌbrethe that at what tyme hee receaued this Å¿tate and degree, ye ringez which he then gaue Å¿tode him in fifty poundes.

For euery Å¿uche Å¿erieant at the tyme of hys creacion vÅ¿eth to geeue vntoo euery Prince, Duke, and archebiÅ¿hop being preÅ¿eÌt at that Å¿olempnitie, and to the lord Chauncellour and Lorde TreaÅ¿eroure of Englande a ringe of
the valu of .xxvi. Å¿hillings viii.d. And to euery earle and biÅ¿hop beeinge likewiÅ¿e preÅ¿ent, and alÅ¿o to the Lorde priuie Å¿eale, to both ye lordes chief IuÅ¿tices, & to the Lorde chiefe baron of the kinges exchequer a ringe of the value of xx.s. And to euery lord baron of the parliament & to euery abbott, & notable prelate, & worÅ¿hipfull knight being then preÅ¿eÌt, & alÅ¿o to ye maiÅ¿ter of the roles, & to euery IuÅ¿tice a ring of ye value of a mark And likewiÅ¿e to euery baron of ye exchequer, to the chaumberlaines, and to all the officers, and notable menne Å¿eruynge in the kinges courtes, ringes of a Å¿maller pryce, but agreable to theire eÅ¿tates to whome they are
geuen. InÅ¿omuch yt there Å¿hall not bee a clerke, Å¿peciallye in the court of the commen benche, but hee Å¿hal receaue a ring coÌuenient for his degree. And beÅ¿ydes theÅ¿e they geeue dyuers rynges too other of theire fryndes. They geue alÅ¿o liueries of cloth of one Å¿ute or colour in greate abundaunce not onelye to theire houÅ¿hold meanye, but alÅ¿o to their other fryndes and acquaintaunce, whiche durynge the tyme of the foreÅ¿ayde Å¿olempnytye Å¿hall attende and wayte vppon them.

Wherefore though in the VniuerÅ¿ities they that are promoted too the degree of Doctors do Å¿uÅ¿taiÌ no Å¿mall charges at the tyme of their coÌmeÌcemeÌt,
as in geuiÌge of bonnetes and other ryche gyftes, yet yey geue no gold: nor do beÅ¿towe any other giftes or coÅ¿tes lyke vnto theÅ¿e expenÅ¿es. Neither iÌ any couÌtrey of the world is there any Å¿pecial degre geuen in the lawes of the Å¿aÌe laÌde, but onely in ye royalme of Englande. Neither is there any man o â¢ lawe throughe out the vniuerÅ¿all world, whiche by reaÅ¿oÌ of his office or êfeÅ¿Å¿ion gaynethe Å¿omuch as one of theÅ¿e Å¿eriaunts. No man alÅ¿o be he neuer Å¿o connynge & Å¿kylfull in the lawes of the royalme Å¿halbe exalted to ye office and dignitie of a IuÅ¿tice in the courte of pleas before the kiÌge or iÌ ye courte
of the coÌmeÌ bench, which are the chiefe ordinarie courtes of the Å¿ame royalme, oneles he be firÅ¿t êmoted to the Å¿tate and degree of a Å¿eriaunt at law. Neither Å¿hall any man but onely Å¿uch a Å¿eriaunt pleade in the courte of yt commen benche, wheare all reall actions are pleaded. Wherefore to this Å¿tate and degree hath no man bene hetherto admitted, except he haue firÅ¿t coÌ tinued by the Å¿pace of xvi yeares in the Å¿aid general Å¿tudie of ye lawe. And in token or Å¿igne that all IuÅ¿tices ar thus graduat euerye of them alwayes whyle he Å¿ytteth iÌ ye kiÌges courtes, weareth a white quoyfe of Å¿ilke: whiche is
the principal and chief in Å¿ignemet of habite where with Å¿eriauntes at lawe in their creation are decked. And neither the IuÅ¿tice, nor yet the Å¿eriaunt Å¿hal euer put of ye quoyfe no not in the kynges preÅ¿ence, thoughe he be in talke withe his maieÅ¿ties highnes. wherefore, moÅ¿t noble prince, you can not hereafter doubt, but that theÅ¿e lawes, which Å¿o Å¿ingularli aboue the Ciuile lawes, yea and aboue the lawes of all other royalmes are honoured, and with Å¿o Å¿olempne a Å¿tate of Å¿uch as are learned therein, and do profeÅ¿Å¿e ye Å¿aÌe are worÅ¿hipped muÅ¿t needes be precioê°, noble and hieghe, and of greate excellencie, and of Å¿peciall knowlege and vertue.

SEd cuÌ tu princeps, Å¿cire deÅ¿ideres, cur iÌ legibê° Angliae noÌ dantur baculariatê° et doctoratus gradus Å¿icut in vtro
que iure in vniuerÅ¿itatibus eÅ¿t dare conÅ¿uetuÌ Scire te volo, qdâ licet gradus hmÌoi in legibus Angliae minime coÌferaÌtur datur tamen in illis nedum gradus, Å¿ed et Å¿tatus quidam, gradu doctoratê° noÌ minê° celebris aut Å¿oleÌnis, qui gradus Å¿eruientis
ad legeÌ appellatur. Et coÌfertur Å¿ub hac qÌ Å¿ubÅ¿equitur forma.

Capitalis IuÅ¿ticiarius de coÌi banco, de coÌÅ¿ilio et aÅ¿Å¿eÌÅ¿u oiÌm iuÅ¿ticiarioruÌ, eligere Å¿olet quotieÌs Å¿ibi videtur oport â¢ muÌ, Å¿epteÌ vel octo de maturioribus êÅ¿onis qui in pÌdicto genÌali Å¿tudio maius in legibus proficeruÌt, & qui eiÅ¿deÌ iuÅ¿ticiarâ optimae diÅ¿poÅ¿itionis eÅ¿Å¿e videÌtur, et nomina eoruÌ ille deliberare Å¿olet CaÌcellario angliae in Å¿criptis, qui illico maÌdabit ê breuia regis cuilêª cuilibet electoruÌ illoruÌ, qd. Å¿it coraÌ rege ad dieÌ ê ipÅ¿um aÅ¿Å¿ignatum
ad Å¿uÅ¿cipieÌduÌ Å¿tatum et graduÌ Å¿eruieÌtis ad legeÌ, Å¿ub ingeÌti pena iÌ quolibet breuiuÌ predictorum limitata: ad queÌ dieÌ
quilibêª quilibet eorum coÌpareÌs, iurabitur (Å¿uê Å¿aÌcta dei euaÌgelia) fore paratum, ad dieÌ et locuÌ tunc Å¿ibi Å¿tatueÌdos, ad recipieÌ dum Å¿tatuÌ & gradum predictos, et qdâ ipÅ¿e in die illo dabit aurum Å¿ecuÌ dum coÌÅ¿uetudineÌ regni in hoc caÅ¿u vÅ¿itataÌ. TnÌ qualit
er ad dieÌ illum quilibet electorâ predictorâ Å¿e habeb. nec noÌ formaÌ et modâ qualit
er Å¿tatê° & gradus hmÌoi coÌfereÌtâ et recipiuntur, hic inÅ¿erere omitto:
cum Å¿cripturam maiorem illa exigant, quam congruit operi tam Å¿uccincto. Tibi tamen ore tenus ea alias explicaui.

Scire tamen te cupio, qdâ adueniente die Å¿ic Å¿tatuto, electi illi inter alias Å¿olempnitates feÅ¿tum celebrant et conuiuium, ad inÅ¿tar coronationis regis, quod et continuabitur ê dies Å¿eptem, necquiÅ¿quam electorum illorum Å¿uÌptus Å¿ibi contingentes circa Å¿oleÌpnitatem creationis Å¿uae, minoribus expenÅ¿is perficiet, quam mille et Å¿ex centoruÌÅ¿cutorum
quo expenÅ¿ae quas octo Å¿ic electi tuÌc refuÌdeÌt, excedent Å¿uÌmaÌ. 3200. marc. quaruÌ expeÌÅ¿aruÌ ês qÌdaÌ inter cetera, hec erit. Quilibet eoruÌ dabit anulos de auro ad valeÌtiaÌ in toto quadragiÌ ta librarâ (ad minê°) monetae AnglicanÌ et bene recolit CaÌ cellarius ipÅ¿e, qdâ duÌ ille Å¿tatum & graduÌ hmÌoi receperat, ipÅ¿e Å¿oluit ê anulis quos tuÌc diÅ¿tribuit, quinquaginta libras, qÌ Å¿uÌt 300. Å¿cuta. Solet naÌ
que vnuÅ¿quiÅ¿que Å¿eruientuÌ hmÌoi teÌ pore creacoÌis Å¿uae, dare cuilêª cuilibet priÌcipi, duci, et archiepÌo iÌ Å¿oleÌnitate illa preÅ¿eÌti, ac CaÌcellarâ et TheÅ¿a. ang. anuluÌ
ad valoreÌ 26. s. 8. denarâ, et cuilibet comiti et epÌo coÌÅ¿imiliter preÅ¿eÌtibus, nec noÌ cuÅ¿todi priuati figilli, vtrique capitali iuÅ¿ticiario et capitali baroni de Å¿caccario regis aÌnuluÌ ad valoreÌ 20. s. et oiÌ dnÌo baroni êliameÌti, et oiÌ abbati et notabili prelato ac magno militi, tuÌc pÌÅ¿eÌti, cuÅ¿todi etiaÌ rotulâ caÌcellariae regis & cuilibet iuÅ¿ticiario anuluÌ ad valencÌ 1. marcÌ. Similiter et oiÌ barâ de Å¿caccÌ regis, camerariis, etiaÌ oiÌbus officÌ et notabilibê° viris in curâ regis miÌÅ¿traÌtibê°, anulos minorâ pÌcij, coÌuenieÌtes tnÌ Å¿tatibus eoruÌ
qib quibus
donaÌtur. Ita quod non erit clericus, maximÃ¨ iÌ curia coÌ munis baÌci, licet iÌ fimus, quin anuluÌ ipÅ¿e recipiet coÌuenieÌteÌ gradui Å¿uo. Et vltra hos ipÅ¿i dant anulos nonnullos, aliis amicis Å¿uis. Similiter et liberataÌ magnaÌ paÌ ni vniê° Å¿ectae, quaÌ ipÅ¿i tunc diÅ¿tribuent in magna abuÌ daÌtia, nedum familiaribê° Å¿uis, Å¿ed et amicis aliis et notis, qui eis atteÌ deÌt et miniÅ¿trabuÌt teÌpore Å¿oleÌnitatis predictae. Quare licet in vniuerÅ¿itatibus in gradum doctoratâ erecti, expenÅ¿as non modicas faciant teÌêe
creacionis Å¿uae, ac birreta, alia quo
que donaria quaÌ bona errogeÌt: noÌ tameÌ auruÌ ipÅ¿i coÌferunt aut alia donaria Å¿uÌptuÅ¿ue faciuÌt, his expeÌÅ¿is Å¿imilia. Ne
que in regno aliquo orbis terraruÌ datur gradus Å¿pecialis in legibê° regni illiê°, pÌterquaÌ Å¿oluÌ iÌ regno Angliae Nec eÅ¿t aduocatê° in vniuÌÅ¿o muÌdo, qÌ ratione officii Å¿ui taÌtuÌ lucratur vt Å¿eruiens huiuÅ¿modi. Nullê° eciaÌ, licet in legibê° regni illius Å¿cientiÅ¿Å¿imê° fuerit, aÅ¿Å¿umetur ad officium et dignitateÌ iuÅ¿ticiarii iÌ curiis placitoruÌ coraÌ ipÅ¿o rege
et comunis banci quae Å¿uÌt Å¿upremae curiae eiuÅ¿deÌ regni ordinariae, niÅ¿i ipÅ¿e primitus Å¿tatu et gradu Å¿eruieÌtis ad legeÌ fuerit inÅ¿ignitus. Nec birretâ illud iuÅ¿ticiariê°, Å¿icut nec Å¿eruieÌs ad legeÌ vnquaÌ deponet, quo caput Å¿uuÌ iÌ toto diÅ¿coope riet, etiaÌ iÌ pÌÅ¿eÌtâ reg. licÌ cuÌ celÅ¿itudinÌÅ¿u a ipÌe loquatâ Quare priÌceps pÌclariÅ¿Å¿imÌ tu amodo heÅ¿i tarâ noÌ potâis, quin leges iÅ¿tae qÌ taÌ Å¿igularitâ Å¿uprâ ciuiles leges leges etiaÌ oÌ niuÌ alioruÌ regnoruÌ honeraÌtâ et tam Å¿oleÌpni Å¿tatu eruditoruÌ et miniÅ¿traÌ tiuÌ iÌ eis veneraÌtâ pÌcioÅ¿ae Å¿it nobiles et Å¿ublimes, ac magnÌ pÌÅ¿taÌciae, maximae

div.head: After what maner a IuÅ¿tice is created, and of his habite and conuerÅ¿ation. Cap. 51

div.p:
BVt to the intent the Å¿tate of IuÅ¿tices aÅ¿well as of Å¿eriauntes at lawe maye be knowen to your grace, as I caÌ I wil deÅ¿cribe vnto you their fourme and office. In the commen beÌche there are cuÅ¿tumable v. IuÅ¿tices or vi. at the moÅ¿t. And in the kynges benche .iiii. or v. And as ofte as the place of any of them by deathe or otherwyÅ¿e is voyde, ye kynge vÅ¿eth to chooÅ¿e one of the Å¿eriauntes at lawe and him by his letters patents to ordeine a IuÅ¿tice in the place of the iudge Å¿o ceaÅ¿Å¿ynge. And theÌ the lorde Chauncellor of England
Å¿hall enter into ye courte where the IuÅ¿tice is Å¿o lackynge, bryngyng with him thoÅ¿e letters patents, and Å¿ittynge in ye myddes of the IuÅ¿tices, cauÅ¿eth the Å¿eriauÌt Å¿o elect to be brought in, to whoÌ in the open courte he notifieth the kynges pleaÅ¿ure touchynge the office of the iuÅ¿tice then voyd and cauÅ¿eth the foreÅ¿aid letters to be openly read. Whiche doÌe the maiÅ¿ter of the rolles Å¿hall reade before the Å¿ame elect perÅ¿on the othe that he Å¿hall take. Which wheÌ he hath Å¿worne vpon the holy goÅ¿pell of god, the lord ChauÌ cellour Å¿hall deliuer vnto him the kynges letters aforeÅ¿aid. And the lorde chiefe IuÅ¿tice of yt courte Å¿hall aÅ¿Å¿ine vnto him a
place in the Å¿ame, where he Å¿hall then place him: & that place Å¿hall he afterward kepe. Yet you muÅ¿t knowe, moÅ¿t noble priÌce, that this IuÅ¿tice Å¿hall theÌ amonge other thinges Å¿weare, that he Å¿hal indifferently miniÅ¿ter iuÅ¿tice to all men aÅ¿well foes as frendes, that Å¿hall haue any Å¿ute or plea before hiÌ And this Å¿hal he not forbeare to do thoughe the kinge by his letters, or by expreÅ¿Å¿e worde of mouth woulde commaunde the contrarie. He Å¿hall alÅ¿o Å¿weare that from that tyme forwarde he Å¿hall not receaue or take any fee or penÅ¿ion, or lyuerye of any maÌ, but of ye kiÌg onely nor any gyfte, reward or brybe of any maÌ hauiÌg Å¿ute or plea before
him, Å¿auynge meate and driÌke. which Å¿halbe of no great value. You Å¿hall alÅ¿o knowe that a IuÅ¿tice thus made Å¿hal not be at the charges of any diner, or Å¿olempnitie, or anye other coÅ¿tes at the tiÌe wheÌ he taketh vpoÌ him his office & dignitie, forÅ¿omuch as this is no degree in ye facultie of the lawe, but an office onely & a rowm of autoritie to coÌtinue duringe the kynges pleaÅ¿ur Howebeit the habit of his raimeÌt he Å¿hall from tyme to tyme forward in Å¿ome poyntes chaunge, but not in all the enÅ¿ignements thereof. div.head: The prince findeth fault with delayes that are made in the kinges courtes. Cap. 52.

div.p:

div.head: Delaies that happen in the kynges courtes are neaceÅ¿Å¿arie and reaÅ¿onable. Ca. 53.

div.p:

any vrgent cauÅ¿e Å¿o requireth, there is quicke diÅ¿patche made, lyke as in other partes of the world and yet not wt Å¿uche hote haÅ¿t as in Å¿ome other places, that the êtye be there by endammaged. For within the royalme of Fraunce in ye hiegheÅ¿t court ther, which is called the court of parliameÌt, there be certeiÌ proceÅ¿Å¿es yt haue haÌged there aboue xxx. yeares. And I knowe that a cauÅ¿e of appeale, which in that court betweene Richard HeroÌ an EngliÅ¿he merchaunt & other merchaunt meÌ for a traÅ¿greÅ¿Å¿ion made hath ben debated withiÌ the iuriÅ¿diction of that courte,

And I knowe other caÅ¿es ther lyke vnto theÅ¿e So that the lawes of EnglaÌd, as Å¿eemeth to me, cauÅ¿e not Å¿o gre â¢ t delayes as do ye lawes of that countrey. But to Å¿peake vpprightly, it is neceÅ¿Å¿arie that delayes be had in the proceÅ¿Å¿es of all actions
Å¿o that the Å¿ame be not to muche exceÅ¿Å¿iue. For by reaÅ¿oÌ thereof the parties and chiefely the partie defeÌdant, do often tymes êuide themÅ¿elfes of good defenÅ¿es and alÅ¿o of couÌ Å¿els, which els yey Å¿hould lacke. And in iudgemeÌts there is neuer Å¿o greate daunger toward as wheÌ proceÅ¿Å¿e goeth foreward with ouer muche haÅ¿te. For I Å¿awe ones in the Citie of SaliÅ¿buri before a certein iudge at a gaole delyuerie there with the clerk of the aÅ¿Å¿yfes, a womaÌ attaiÌted & burned for the death of her huÅ¿band within a yeare a â¢ ter he was Å¿laine. In the which caÅ¿e it was in the iudges power to haue reprieued or reÅ¿pected that womaÌs
arraygnement til the end of that yeare. And about a yeare after that I Å¿aw one of ye Å¿eruants of the Å¿laine man coÌuict before ye Å¿ame IuÅ¿tice of the death of the Å¿ame his maiÅ¿ter. Whoe then openlye confeÅ¿Å¿ed, yt he himÅ¿elfe alone Å¿lew his maÅ¿ter, and that his maiÅ¿tres hys wyfe whiche before was burned, was altogether innocent of hys deathe. And he for ye Å¿ame was drawen and hanged And Å¿till euen at ye pointe of death he lamented the womaÌ burned, as one cleare from that offence. O what perplexitie & remorÅ¿e of c â¢ nÅ¿cience it is to bee thought that this Å¿o haÅ¿ty a IuÅ¿tice hadde of thys deede which might iuÅ¿tly haue Å¿tayed the proceÅ¿Å¿e? He himÅ¿elfe (alas) often
confeÅ¿Å¿ed vnto me that hee Å¿hould neuer durynge his lyfe be hable to cleare hys conÅ¿cience of this fact. For manye times in deliberatioÌs, iudgemeÌts growe to riepenes, but in ouer haÅ¿ty proceÅ¿Å¿e neuer. Wherfore the laws of England admit eÅ¿Å¿oyne, and Å¿o do noe other laws of al ye worlde Are not vouchinges to warrant right profitable Are not the aydes of them profitable, to whom the reuerÅ¿ion of tenementes brought in plea belongethe, and whiche haue the euidences of the Å¿ame.

Are not alÅ¿o the aydes of coperteners êfitable whiche Å¿hall paye accordinge to the rate of a tenemente allotted to their coêtener by force of the law euicted
from him. And yet al theÅ¿e are delayes as you moÅ¿t noble prince by my talke at other times do wel knowe. And the like delayes to theÅ¿e do no other lawes admit. Neither do the lawes of Englande admyt tryeflinge and vnfruteful delayes. And if any Å¿uche fonde delayes Å¿houlde be vÅ¿ed they maye at euerye parliament be cut awaye Yea and other laws vÅ¿ed in the Å¿ame royalme, wheÌ in any pointe theye beegynnne to haÅ¿te theye maye at euery parliameÌt be refourmed. theye maye eaÅ¿lye be reduced to the preÅ¿ent perfection of goodnes. To the perfourmaunce wherof as ofte as equytye Å¿o requyrethe, euerye kynge there is bounde by an othe Å¿olempnelye taken at the tyme of hys coronation.

div.head: Â¶The lawes of England are right good, the knowledge whereof is expedient for kynges. Yet it Å¿hall Å¿uffice theÌ to haue but a Å¿uperficiall knowledge of the Å¿ame Cap. 54.

div.p:
I Haue wel & euideÌtly êceaued, quod ye prince, by ye êceÅ¿Å¿e of your talke good ChauÌcellour, yt thoÅ¿e lawz are not onely good, but alÅ¿o of moÅ¿t perfecte & excelleÌt goodnes. And if any of theÌ haue neede to be ameÌ ded that may quicklye bee done as the fourmes and
orders of ye parliamentes there do plainlye prooue Wherfore ye roialme is euer really or potentiallye gouerned by moÅ¿t excelleÌt and moÅ¿t worthie lawes. And I doubt not but that your inÅ¿tructions in thys our talke Å¿halbee profitable for the kings of Englande whiche hereafter Å¿hall bee: Å¿o that they haue noe pleaÅ¿ure in gouernynge by vnpleaÅ¿aunt lawes. For the vnhandÅ¿omnes of the toole or inÅ¿trumente werieth the workmanne: and a blunte pike or a dulle Å¿weorde makethe a cowardelye Å¿ouldiour But like as a Å¿ouldiour is encouraged to fight not onelye when hee hathe handÅ¿ome and fitte weapons in a readynes, but alÅ¿o much more when
he is expert and Å¿kilfull in warlike actes, accordinge to the Å¿aying of Vegetius in his boke of chiualrie, ye knowledge & connyng in martiall feats miniÅ¿treth boldenes in fightinge (for no man feareth to do that whiche he truÅ¿teth hee hathe well learned) in lyke maner euery kinge hath a ferueÌt zeale, & earneÅ¿t deÅ¿ire to ye maintenaunce of IuÅ¿tice, not only knowiÌg ye lawes, whereby ye muÅ¿t be don, to be moÅ¿t iuÅ¿t, but alÅ¿o beinge Å¿kilful in the forme & nature of ye Å¿ame. Whereof it Å¿hal Å¿uffice ye prince to haue onely an vniuerÅ¿all, a Å¿uperficial, & a confuÅ¿e knoweledge, the diÅ¿creete and determinate perfectnes, & deepe vnder Å¿taÌdinge of the Å¿ame beeynge lefte to his iudges.
So alÅ¿o oughte all princes to bee wel Å¿eene in the holye Å¿criptures of god, as Å¿ayethe vincentius BeluacenÅ¿is in his booke of the morall inÅ¿titution of princes ForaÅ¿muche as the Å¿cripture aboue mentioned Å¿ayethe that vayne are all theye in whom is not the knowledge of god and for that in the Å¿ixteen the chapter of the prouerbes it is thus written. Let prophecye or the woorde of god be in the lyppes of the kynge, and then hys mouthe Å¿hall not go wroÌ ge in iudgement. And yet is not a kinge bounde to haue profounde knowledge, and determinate vnderÅ¿taÌding in ye holy Å¿criptures, as it becommethe a profeÅ¿Å¿oure of dyuinitye.
For it Å¿halbe ynoughe for hiÌ Å¿uêficially to taÅ¿t ye Å¿enteÌces therof, as alÅ¿o of his lawes. Thus did Charles the great, Lewes his Å¿onne, and Robert Å¿ometime kinge of Fraunce whoe wrote thys Å¿equence.

Sancti Å¿piritus adÅ¿it nobis gratia: and diuers other princes, as the foreÅ¿ayde VinceÌcius in the fiftenethe chapter of his booke aforeÅ¿ayd plainly Å¿hewethe. Wherfore ye doctors of ye lawes do Å¿ay, yt an eÌ perour beareth al his lawes in ye box of his breÅ¿t: not for yt he knoweth all ye lawes reallye & in deede, but for that he vnderÅ¿tandeth the principles of theÌ, lykewiÅ¿e theire fourme, & theire nature: in whiche reÅ¿pect he is iudged to bee Å¿kilfull in all hys lawes.
Whiche alÅ¿o he maye alter, chaunge, and repeale. So that in him are potentiallye all his lawes, as Eue was in Adam before Å¿he was made. Butte now, good Chauncellour Å¿eeynge I perceaue mye Å¿elfe Å¿ufficientlye perÅ¿waded to the Å¿tudie of the lawes of England, whiche thing in ye beginninge of this worke you promiÅ¿ed to perfourme, I wil no loÌ ger trouble you in this behalfe. But thus I inÅ¿taÌtly deÅ¿ire you, yt ye wil iÌÅ¿truct me in ye priÌciples of ye law as you once began to doe And that you will teache me to knowe and vnderÅ¿tande the fourm and nature thereof. For thys lawe Å¿hall bee euermore peculiar to me amonge al other lawes of the worlde,
amonge the whiche I Å¿ee it Å¿hiene as lucifer amoÌge the Å¿tarrs. And forÅ¿omuch as I doubt not, but youre intent, whereby you were moued to this conference is fully Å¿atiÅ¿fiyd: bothe tyme and reaÅ¿on requirethe, that we make an ende of our talke, yeeldynge therfore laudes and thankes to him, whiche beganne, furthered, and hathe fyniÅ¿hed the Å¿ame. Whom we call Alpha et O, who alÅ¿o be prayÅ¿ed of euerye lyuinge creature. Amen.
